summary: A dark-haired woman (Laura Elena Harring) is left amnesiac after a car crash. She wanders the streets of Los Angeles in a daze before taking refuge in an apartment. There she is discovered by Betty (Naomi Watts), a wholesome Midwestern blonde who has come to the City of Angels seeking fame as an actress. Together, the two attempt to solve the mystery of Rita's true identity. The story is set in a dream-like Los Angeles, spoilt neither by traffic jams nor smog.

reviews.content: I don't know where to begin and I'm sure others will convey their emotions and reactions more articulately. I haven't watched a Lynch film since the ‘Blue Velvet' days, so I thought I knew what was coming, but….. actually I was lulled into a state of complacency. The beginning was slow and I was not cued into all the subtle flag posts. I remember thinking the colours and cinematography is now a bit dated & then wallop! I'm not even sure what happened. I was dragged into a cesspool of the mind & psyche and I was looking in all the wrong places! Lol! I'll need to re-watch sooner than later.

A thrilling masterpiece as only the great David Lynch could concoct, Mulholland Dr. benefits off of the perfect performances of Naomi Watts, Laura Harring, and Justin Theroux. Lynch's direction is the centerpiece, however. Without the guide and power of Lynch's style, every tiny little piece of the film would not be able to come together as a whole to give the viewers the full experience that a movie should.
A facinating, dream-like David Lynch film that tells an interesting story. A very eerie, edge-of-your-seat movie.
One of the 100 Greatest Films of All Time!!  Amazing!!

Mulholland drive has a unique narrative and is very surreal in its cinematic execution. The plot is borderline nonsensical until you understand what's going on but it's at least clear from subtext that everything isn't what it appears to be. The movie uses some super unnerving POV shots coupled with an ominous soundscape that become very fitting in hindsight. The movie isn't dramatic in a traditional sense, but it nevertheless has a satisfying conclusion if you can piece it together. Simply understanding the plot is quite the mental exercise and there is so much symbolism at play that there's likely a lot I've missed. I wouldn't say I enjoyed Mulholland Drive, but I understand why it's praised as a great cinematic accomplishment.

None of this film made any sense whatsoever. I had to Google it after to find out what exactly happened and you shouldn't have to do that after a film - it should explain things at least a very tiny bit but this explained NOTHING. One very overrated film that was nothing but a messy mixture of weird scenes that didn't connect and characters that never got explanations
I wanted the two hours of my life back that were wasted on this movie. I watched it to the end and was left with the feeling of: 'That's it?! Really!? I so don't care!'
While the movie had some interesting characters and enjoyable cinematography, the story line is too loose to be considered a great movie or worthwhile of a deeper analysis.
David Lynch's mind-bending thriller is slow, confusing, and weird, but Naomi Watts' solid performance makes it well worth a one-time watch.
It is magical. One of the best movies I've seen in my life.
Really dun gets why the rating is so high, just lousy drama to me...
The best acting performance from Naomi Watts!

This is the kind of impressionistic, dreamlike film noir that Lynch is peerless at.  This dream within a dream mehta stuff; much in the same vein as Inception; or any of the Nightmare on Elmstreet films....  The main thing this movie is remembered for now is the amazing confrontation scene at Winkies Restaurant; a stunning 2:00 minute set piece where Patrick Fisckler (Dan) confronts the Satan of his dreams; only to realize that that devil is all too real, and his fragile heart cannot bear witnessing him; cannot handle the stress and terror of it....  The famed Mulholland Drive jump scare has become one of the most famous in film history; renowned as the scariest scene of all time; and now has a life of its own thanks to the internet.  It also borrows a bit from the Twilight Zone's perchance to dream; which investigates the idea of a man being stalked by a figure in his dreams; which eventually gets the best of him.

This film is divided between sense and nonsense parts. The sense part (with bits of nonsense sprinkled throughout) is so good because it makes the audience really want to know where the story will go and the answer to the mystery. The last bit of sense left the film after Betty and Rita had sex. We are transported to a depressing and less interesting alternate reality. I can't help but think this is another Evangelion situation, where Lynch the creator, although already known for his surrealist style, try to make a coherent story for a TV pilot, but doesn't know how to end it. So he made the rest surreal and weird.

I thought Mulholland drive was an extremely confusing and annoying because of how much it jumped around and didn't make sense. I had to look up what was happening the whole entire movie and was disappointed. I also think there was stuff in the movie that really didn't add to the film whatsoever and should have been left out of the movie completely. For example, the sex scenes. However, the reasoning behind still giving it a 3/5 star review is due to the fact that it had me hooked from the very start and all the jumping made me want to know what the hell was even happening. I also found the cinematography very amusing and entertaining. I think that the casting was quite exquisite for this film. Naomi Watts did one of the best acting jobs I have seen in very long time in my opinion.

People throw the word masterpiece around. I'll defend that term this way: There is a dinner party near the end, a 5-minute scene. Our lead character (Naomi Watts) arrives, she sits, she talks, she observes, and it concludes with her shedding angry tears. Those actions themselves are not bizarre, so they could never take place in Lynch's surreal Eraserhead. But in MH, this scene is a powerful crescendo, made more so by 'bits of craziness' like an out-of-focus lens, a spanish-spoken sentence, puzzling attendees to the party and strange music - not to mention the identity switching the movie is known for. Yet this scene isn't even one of the more (in)famous scenes of the film. Turn the lights down, the volume up, put down your phone and take a ride on Mulholland Drive.

Mulholland Drive plays out like a dream, with shifting scenes colliding into each other without continuity or logic.  And yet it all holds together without turning into an incoherent mess, and somehow manages to nail the themes of trying to make it big in Hollywood while dealing with disappointments, toxic people and psychosis.  Anchored by a strong performance form Naomi Watts.
Naomi Watts delivered excellent and emotional performance here. This is a surreal Lynch film, but dialog is simple and communicating. You cannot miss every single shot... meaningful and beautiful.
One of or maybe even THE greatest film of all time.
Self immolation seems like a great alternative to watching this now that I've finally watched it.

Watching David Lynch's Mulholland Dr. is a lot like viewing a Jackson Pollock painting – you become immersed in the experience, entranced by the style and visual wonders, and walk away deeply satisfied and equally confused.  Like most of Lynch's films, you get the feeling that the joke is ultimately on the audience with Lynch sitting back and chuckling over the myriad of speculations regarding themes and plot.  It is a movie filled with odd camera angles, a typically eerie music score, mysterious characters, an indecipherable plot, and what seem to be deliberately stilted dialogue and performances.  And it is riveting from beginning to end, casting a spell that remains unbroken until you walk away and try to shake the cobwebs of confusion from your head.

A masterpiece of avant-garde film. The best part about the movie is that you will spend as much time thinking about the film as you spent watching it. Lynch pushes the boundary through a plot which exists in a non-euclidean space. Not for everyone, if you want a straight story then stay away.

A Masterpiece.  Not a dream, but a psychotic episode emanating from a very sick woman.  She views herself from a place of innocence and is unaware of her own destructive capabilities.  Is she totally at fault?  We see the sleaziness of Hollywood and its unrelenting corruptive influence.  To me, Diane Selwyn and Hollywood are deserving of one another, a match that is destined.  Despite the corruption, it is all about Diane in her psyche and this is where the destructive powers are thrust into the world violently.  The dark, shadow figure, the Devil, silencio, is everything merged and collapsed into a metaphysical black hole (the black box).  The only ending that could happen in Diane's case.  She understands, deep within her ID, the corrupt superficiality of it all, she desires it for herself, she cannot have it and is not capable, she engages in vicious self-mockery that ultimately leads to violent self- destruction.  THE END!

Mulholland Drive was interesting for a while. Then it got weird. Then it got pretentious. I've heard some people say that this is David Lynch's most accessible film, but I disagree. I think The Elephant Man or The Straight Story would be better options. Even Twin Peaks made more sense than this amnestic fever dream. It definitely creates a mood, but this bewildering mystery is too convoluted to unravel.
Somehow Lynch has a way of crawling into my mind and leaving me in an altered state. This one stayed with me for a good long while. Truly an all-time classic
David Lynch slowly plays with your mind in this mysterious contemporary Los Angeles crime drama.

What can be said about the film itself that hasn't been said better already?

This film changed my (early-teenage) life. If not for seeing it practically randomly, I likely would not have discovered so much of what I did after. It oriented me on a path toward beauty in a way that nothing else had to that point in my life, and I'm not sure that anything else has, to the same extent, after.
question, what did i just watch??
Highly entertaining, moody, suspenseful film.

I found Mulholldand Drive to be a fantastic film, having loved all of David Lynch's films seen personally so far (personal favourite being The Elephant Man, one of the most emotionally affecting films ever made) with the exception of Dune. For this viewer, Mulholland Drive is one of Lynch's best films and among the best films of the 2000s, but it is also one of Lynch's most love-it-or-hate-it films- from a love/hate him director- as seen in the reviews here. And it is very understandable why people would dislike it, it is weird (not unusual for Lynch), it is slow, the story mayn't be clear to some, the symbolism may go over people's heads and it does get confusing especially towards the end. And it has nothing to do with not getting it, it is just not for everybody's tastes and not everybody is going to connect with it. For those who love it neither of these are problems, admittedly it is a good idea to be acquainted with Lynch's style beforehand so that it doesn't come across as too much of a shock and also to watch it more than once. Justifying what was so great about Mulholland Drive, a good place to start would be the visuals, which are never less than scintillating with bold colours, symbolic imagery and some of the most striking cinematography of any film from this decade. The Silencio Club scene is so beautifully shot. The haunting retro score, thought-provoking dialogue and that it contains some of Lynch's finest direction and the best directing of all the films from 2001 are further things to like. The story is where those who dislike it are perplexed, granted there may be too many plot strands crammed in towards the end and not everybody's going to like how the ending is open to interpretation, but with me the thriller-drama story was gripping and I was captivated so much by the surrealist atmosphere, offbeat emotional intensity and sizzling suspense that the slow pacing didn't feel slow at all. It wisely focused on the relationship between Watts and Harring, and while bizarre it was very well handled. The cast carry the film brilliantly, especially with the sensational lead performance of Naomi Watts who has never been better than here. Laura Harring is enchanting and Justin Theroux is very good. In conclusion, while not for everybody's tastes for understandable (and quite obvious) reasons Mulholland Drive was fantastic in all areas. 10/10 Bethany Cox
Extremely beautiful cinematography combined with genius storytelling and amazing acting.

Mulholland Drive (2001) directed by David Lynch

This is the type of movie you get to see once in many years. It's an experience that feels apart from this world. It takes place in the crazy mind of David Lynch. It's one frenetic, chaotic, silent, suspenseful, vibrant and sexual movie, and that's what makes it so unique.

The story is very complex and filled with small details that help you complete the riddle. This is one of those few movies that by the end I was extremely confused with what had just happened, but was still able to call it a masterpiece. This felt like a fever dream in the most incredible way. It's also cool how I never knew which path the film would follow and that would just make me always want to know what would happen next.

The acting was also pretty dang good. Naomie Watts was definitely the star of the film, but Laura Harring did a pretty good job too. Somehow i really felt like this movie couldn't be done with other cast, which sounds funny knowing what happens in the film.

The way this movie was shot was very unique and surrealistic and created a dream-like atmosphere. The score was also jaw dropping and was able to play with our feelings like it was nothing.

Lynch is an incredible director and I'm looking forward to watch more of his work. It's probably the first director that in the same scene was able to make me drop a tear and go completely bonkers in the next second.

I thought it was fabulous. David Lynch is a truly unique director and I love how his films are different than almost anything else you will find out there. This film is very weird but you will enjoy if you can just roll with it.

An expertly crafted, twisted, deep and dark psychological thriller that will stay with you long after the credits roll. I found myself search for explanations right after the film ended, because it contains lot of euphemisms and allegories. Naomi Watts shines here with a fantastic performance. The direction is superb, the dialogues are fitting and film never feels stretched out. Recommended!

A twisty neo-noir with an unconventional structure that features a great performance from Naomi Watts as a woman on the dark fringes of Hollywood.  A surrealist dreamscape and the less sense it makes the more I couldn't stop watching it.  It is the grandest and silliest cinematic carnival in some time and its investigation into the power of movies pierces a void from which you can hear screams of a ravenous demon whose appetites can never be satiated.
The more times I watch this movie the more I appreciate its genius. Just watched it on the Criterion 4K UHD disc and it is superb!
David Lynch's thought-provoking and erotic thriller is one of the true masterpieces of the 21st century.  A hypnotic, dream-like experience that will stay with you long after the credits roll.

I'm not exactly sure what to say about this because the last few minutes has about a dozen twists and it finishes on a sour note.... but the build-up is great and the twists are captivating and the end isn't one to hate but... I guess I need to watch it again.
This movie symbolizes the strife and reality of making it in Hollywood.

It is a perplexing, beautiful film with a seemingly disjointed plot. But it's like a jigsaw puzzle that must be fit together, and even then is still open to interpretation on what is fantasy, reality or hell.
A challenging film for better and worse…still there is a lot to be had with Mulholland Drive.

What a strange trip that was. It's one of those movies that at first I was like, "what the hell is happening?" However, the more I think about it and after going down a rabbit hole about it online, I actually think it's great and kind of masterpiece in some ways.
It was pretty boring, I couldn't get into it. It dragged and the plot never really picked up for me.
While confusing at first, this movie was one of the most creative I've ever seen.

When you see it , you don't get a feeling of oh it's bad or good or disater or marvelous . It stays with us in our mind and instinct  which can't be expressed through words or through expression.  As said by Mr.lynch himself.

The movie just goes along alright and then there's Billy Ray Cyrus. And then about 3 fourths through the movie takes a left turn. And then it takes an even lefter turn. But I knew all along there wasn't something right with that old couple.

I knew it was a David Lynch film, so I'm not sure what I expected. But if I'm being honest, I really didn't understand Mulholland Drive at all when I watched it. I've since read some explanations, and thankfully it's becoming a little clearer, but that doesn't change the fact that it just wasn't very enjoyable to watch. Noami Watts's acting and dialogue is stiff and awkward - in fact, her scene-within-a-scene acting at her audition is better than anything seen in the rest of the film. It's certainly a memorable film, but I'm a believer that films should be enhanced by later analysis, not completely incomprehensible without it. I get why it's famous, but it just didn't really do it for me.
A master piece!! of DREAMS

Mulholland Drive is a simple suspense story which is shown in different way. Director used a few cheap thrill tricks to make the story confusing and the tricks worked.

I am still trying to figure the climax and will probably have to see it again to catch things I missed and which may help me understand it better. It is a very detailed plot that very slowly comes together. Editing work was great, jumping back and forth between scenes was done properly. Combined with smart use of music and sounds, it all helps to build suspense in our minds.

This movie demands alot of patience as you are seeing 2hr 30min dead serious drama. This is where main problem lies. Movie is so slow paced with dead serious plot and you might start getting frustrated and may loose patience.

Overall, it is movie which everyone might not love watching. Some will love it, some will hate it. This movie demands audience which love dead serious crap.

An amazing movie which I love very much, particularly in certain scenes, but contrary to most people, I don't believe it's Lynch's best, and it's probably my least favourite in his 'L.A. Trilogy'. It baffles me that so many people (such as film critic Roger Ebert) disliked Lost Highway, which I think is the better film, and loved Mulholland Drive. That being said, Mulholland Drive is still an incredible piece of cinema, and an absolute must see.

Naturally the drooling screengazers accustomed to watching infantile comic book blockbusters between twitter and fb postings can't stand this subtle, nuanced masterpiece by Lynch. M Dr. conjures up its own completely self contained and authentic reality, somehow infiltrating your mind and leaving you in an altered state. There are no mythological/psychological externalities so many of the pretentious "new wave" filmmakers rely on for subject matter. It offers you the freedom and challenge to interpret in your own way, based on your own experience. Which is exactly why so many simpletons find it so objectionable, they are utterly incapable of independent thought and need their films nice & simple with lots of explosions, clown suits and cgi. Its too bad hollywood can't learn from Lynch and others who refuse to compromise their artistic vision and sell out for the usual blockbuster mcmovie clown shows. For they truly are the most unreal, ridiculous absurdities.

Possible Spoilers Well, Miami Connection has almost a 70% rating by the users on this site, so apparently people like bad movies!!!  This one is about as bad, and more boring if you can believe it.  The scenes look like they are cut from different films and put together.  The plot makes no sense and about 2/3rd's of the way through, Lynch just changes the story (starting with the lockbox) making the previous hour and a half or so a complete waste of time, as if it wasn't already.  If you are a fan of this film, please do not recommend it to anyone else (such as a friend), as they will probably not be your friend anymore for wasting 2-3 hours of their life.  Seriously, the average person will hate this movie (Lynch seems to have a cult of fans who pride themselves on praising his work knowing its poor, but it's like being in an exclusive club).  A total mess, and the half star is only because I could not give a zero!!!
It is too confusing and at the same time too captivating. Actors are at their best and I really liked the story and the twist.

My favourite movie of all time, I've never felt a way about a movie as I did when this one ended. The sheer atmosphere of it alone is glorious, perfection from start to finish. Anybody that says it doesn't make sense either aren't paying anywhere close to enough attention or don't have the slightest amount of imagination, their reviews should be ignored completely by anyone deliberating whether to watch the film, this isn't a complicated movie in the slightest. The scene in Club Silencio is unbelievably powerful and I can never get tired of watching  the '16 Reasons' scene, that scene has always stuck with me for some reason. Absolutely fantastic film, can't praise it highly enough or be more irritated by the narrow minded reviews that drag its rating down, there's a reason it always features highly on lists of greatest modern films. An absolute masterpiece.

This is one of my all time favourite movies. The people who complain that it makes no sense have clearly missed the point and the types of people who need everything spoon fed to them and spelt out in a formulaic way.   It doesn't need to or try to make sense. You can choose to make sense of it if you want to but I honestly don't think it matters. It's just so evocative and beautiful. Pure art. It's a masterpiece in my opinion.
Hideous and beautiful, Mulholland Dr. leaves its mark on you.

This is hands down one the worst movies I've ever seen. I'd rather be strapped to a chair in a cell on a blacklisted CIA site and made to watch every horror movie ever made while being given copious amounts of LSD. 

Lynch wrote a shitty script that makes no sense when put together and executed. The characters were down-right boring, the acting was either half-arsed or overreacted and as for a thriller, the amount of thriller and suspense was negative: there was less than none. No matter how bad this movie is, people will still praise it for being different and "avant garde" and try to find all the different interpretations like an over-the-top English teacher. I saw a review where someone compared this movie to a banana someone left on the floor of a museum and people were crowding over it to admire it. I'd go further and say this is camel shit and you can't admire camel shit!

In essence, this movie is so shit, people think it's a revolutionary masterpiece. If you value your time like a normal person, go watch something good or do something productive. Hell, go stare at a wall and you'll watch something worthwhile and interesting.
I don't like the fact we need to guess what actually happened throughout the whole movie.

This movie is a collection of scenes that appear to be pieces for several different movies. The Watts character is presented at the end a possibly delusional to cover the inconsistence of the content. Watts does a great job but the Harring character seems post concussion during most of the movie.  and made up to look like a figure from a wax museum.  Hard to sit through. A vey small bit of erotic content for a movie that is not very sexy. Hard o understand its rating as 34th best sexy movie.

I think it takes some serious optimism to view this as a fantastic movie. Lynch would have to be an omniscient, intensely skilled director with uncompromising vision for the ending to feel like anything but an intentionally-confusing cop-out. He'd done a good job setting up an interesting TV pilot, albeit one with languid pacing, but to me there is no question he tried to make a strong, coherent ending & failed to do so, going with this jumbled mess instead. The most obvious interpretation (dream) is surely the one Lynch was going for; nobody is sure because he feels being mercurial about it allows for his unresolved plot points to be given a pass. I did find myself riveted by the movie (despite the slow pacing, particularly in the middle when they're trying to figure out who Diane is), but mostly because I could not for the life of me figure out what'd given the movie so much esteem. The crash scene was well-done but from the moment they introduced Naomi's character by way of some bizarrely poorly-performed dialogue with the old folks (both the couple from the plane & the landlord spoke like they were waiting for their turn to speak instead of having a conversation) I was attentive only to ensure I didn't miss what everyone had loved here. An optimist might say that the unnatural way they talked was because it's a dream, but I think not -- they weren't so uncanny as to be intentional, and the Cowboy actor was equally bad. One might also look at the symbolism & camera angles & music and see excellence, and perhaps there is some there, but this movie ranking among the greatest of all time reveals that the film critic community has an outsized proportion of masochists who like it when directors make them look stupid. This was a tremendous disappointment.

I'm not sure exactly what it is, but I am sure it's one of the best films I'll ever see. Naomi Watts gives the performance of a lifetime, the story world is super immersive, and in typical Lynch fashion you never know what to expect next

I am not a fan of David Lynch, so I can't really say I liked this movie. It definitely has some good points to take notice of though, for example the marvellous Los Angeles views the director manages to capture on camera, or the story itself (I had to read an explaination after watching it, it was a little too confusing). As for the rest, I find David Lynch's cinematography to be a little too extravagant, and -as a result- actors' performances to be unnatural.
It's still a must-see for anyone who loves the Seventh Art.
Man this movie was so weird and confusing.... That's why its good
The movie hits really hard into our jealousy.

0.5 star doesn't even come close to the real score I would give this piece of shit. Anyone who would recommend this movie to others calling it a good movie to waste 2 and a half hours of their life on deserves to go to hell after they die. It's honestly a miracle that Hollywood isn't just packed full with shit writers like David Lynch, given how you can apparently just slap random shit together in the name of abstract art cinema, and people would rate it 5/5 calling it one of the best movies they've ever seen. Best part is you don't even need to come up with an explanation for your script, these pretentious people love to find meaning out of nothing for you and call it a masterpiece because "it's a puzzle and there are 10 different interpretations". You know how someone once put a banana on the ground in an art gallery and people started crowding around it, thinking it's art and tried to extrapolate the artist's meaning? Yeah. The fact that this movie has a score of anything above 10% on this website should make you question humanity as a whole. Don't say I didn't warn you.

This movie was pretty good! I like David Lynch a lot, and I decided to check this movie out! I did like it. Would I recommend it, to someone who likes thrillers? Maybe not. It was a good thriller, but I didn't think this movie was anything shocking. It didn't really make me have much emotion. I found the movie slightly boring in the last hour. The acting was fair. I really did not like Naomi Watts in this film. I felt she was overacting! The movie did have a great story! The lesbian scenes were too much for the film, but overall it was a fair selection!

Cinema does not get much better than this a film noir entering a rabbit hole is the only way i can describe this masterpiece and you may have to watch it more than once i certainly did and loved every minute of it... a true real film classic !!!!

David Lynch's thriller fever dream is a nightmare that can be described as beautiful. The usually overlooked Naomi Watts is center stage and carries the movie through the Lynchian, ultimately tragic experience. It's a fantastically shot and acted film that makes some big statements about Hollywood, before the current climate. Great movie that should take it's place as a classic.
I don't understand about this movie

75%. The movie was intended to be consumed as a mystery and for the viewer to come to a conclusion on their own. Honestly the juice just didn't feel like it was worth the squeeze. This movie only becomes interesting after the first two 100 minutes. I usually love to uncover the story but the movie itself didn't do it for me. With that being said, maybe if i watched it when I was more ready for this sort of movie I'd enjoy it more.

Sorry but if it walks like a duck and quacks lika a duck then it is a duck. Unless of course you are David Lynch in which case you are the messiah and create a duck for pseuds who can then worship at the alter of the impenetrably bizzarre. This excludes the majority and makes them and him feel important.
Beautiful and horrifying. It's like being in a dream.

Disjointed, surrealist storylines are dangerous territory for filmmakers - directors like Tarkovsky and Lynch sit on the far edge of a bottomless pit into which many would-be auteurs have tossed an endless torrent of film class projects in an attempt to vault over into the rarified territory of 'pure cinema'. Unless you can convince an array of critics and audiences that your film doesn't reek of pretentiousness despite not adhering to conventional tenets of narrative progression and character, you risk being condemned as insufferably caught up in an exaggerated sense of self-importance. In Mulholland Dr., Lynch once again shows that he is more than capable of clearing that gap with the right material. While interpretations of the film are many and unconfirmed, I take its many interconnecting dreamlike sequences and uncertainty of identity to be a unified portrait of Hollywood itself, where preconceptions, ambitions, and practical experiences (both of disillusionment and success) collide in a confusing network of events, each vying for prominence in the mind's eye. Even the genre clash supports an interpretation of this type, alternating between conventional Golden Age noir, modern thriller, surrealist art piece, and intense romance; none is necessarily to be considered the 'correct' genre of the film, but each contribute heavily to the final product. No character exists in a vacuum (despite many seemingly unrelated events), and can tie into each other in completely unexpected ways. Even if its interpretations may not be fixed (which may anger some audience members), there is a relentless dedication to unpredictability that is sorely missing from much mainstream film in the present, and makes a first-time viewing a wonderful experience. Solid performances all around, and even a bizarre little cameo from Billy Ray Cyrus. Lynch sure does love putting female crooners in the midcentury style on center stage, having done so in some of his most prominent films (Eraserhead, Blue Velvet, and Mulholland Dr.). (4.5/5)
Fascinating and mysterious. Multiple viewings and research will uncover hidden themes in an already intriguing film.

It took me 19 years to finally get to watching this ... and it's everything that I had heard about it. I found the first hour and a half or so gripping, funny and rather brilliant; the last hour felt some combination of indulgent, bizarrely intense, boring and erotic. If that sounds like a contradiction in terms, then that's the point. It's clearly about dreams, fantasy, making films, watching films and celebrity culture. Or maybe it's none of those, about nothing other than itself. What is certain is the exceptional performance from Naomi Watts.
Boring movie that I'll forget about in 2 seconds.

A neo-noir mistery thriller with an unconventional narrative structure that deals with many themes worth analyzing such as the corruption in the entertainment industry, identity, sexuality and the difference between fantasy and reality. Those might leave some confused, but makes it a engaging and highly recommendable viewing experience and one of David Lynch's best directing efforts, and provides a well-crafted script and a poignant lead performance from Naomi Watts.
This weird-ass film touched me in places I didn't even know I had. Definitely one of my absolute favorites.

I cannot believe this only took $7m at the box office on its initial release back in 2001/2!

But then again this is David Lynch territory, and he doesn't make films with mass audience appeal. Not only that but his films are challenging and thought-provoking. You can watch some films without paying any real attention to the story because come the final 5 minutes you'll get all the answers you need - The End!

But with Lynch, he likes to play with you, like a kitten playing with a ball of wool. You think he will serve up the answers at the end of the film, but its not always the case. And even when he does you're still left pondering exactly HOW those answers were justified!

This is a film in the same league as Inception and Memento among a few others, where you're not exactly sure whether you're watching a protracted but hugely vivid dream sequence, or pure reality. And even though this film was perhaps less demanding than Memento, it still demanded your complete attention, with the possible need of a second viewing just to fit the final ambiguous pieces of the jigsaw in place.

One of the outstanding films of the 21st century!
A masterpiece. David Lynch's surrealism at its best.

This is my 4th David Lynch film, and so far I'd say it's his most interesting, narratively speaking.  I'd heard about how enigmatic, surreal, strange, and inexplainable 'Mulholland Drive' was for years.  Heading into it, I prepared myself to be either satisfied with the critical acclaim behind it, or vehemently disappointed and confused about it's non-linear narrative.  I'll say this: I really liked it, but not in the sense that I was conventionally entertained.  No, I really liked this because, not to be cliched, 'Mulholland Drive' is an experience through and through.  Movies like this encapsulate the concept of how some films aren't cut and dry stories, but rather experiences that you just have to allow yourself to be immersed in.  Let the experience take you places, ask questions, try to piece the puzzle together, and no matter how hard you try, in the end, you remain confused yet utterly hypnotized.  'Mulholland Drive' plays like a long, elaborate dream/nightmare.  Lynch composes his camera movements and shots to further emphasize the dream-like atmosphere and vibe the movie carries.  The facial expressions, pacing, ominous score, dialogue, lighting, and more are all combined to feel like you're vicariously watching a dream.  There's no way this movie's story (if you can call it that) has any grounds in reality.  Who was conspiring against Rita?  Was Betty set up?  Wait, Betty was Diane?  Rita's real name is Camilla?  Total mind-job.  The films final act pulls the rug from underneath its viewers at every turn.  If you think you've remotely figured out what everything meant by the last act, the last act pulls out more illusionary and surrealist tricks to eventually leave you with your hands in the air and your shoulder's shrugged.  Only a movie directed by a man as intelligent as Lynch can have this psychological effect on you.  'Mulholland Drive' is an abstract piece of art that teases you with potential answers to its puzzle, then yanks them away from you, forcing you to continue trying to make sense of everything.  I'll be re-watching this no doubt.

*After watching an in-depth analysis, I decided to bump this up to a 4.5.  If it holds up on a future rewatch, or is subjectively better (after everything makes more sense thanks to said analysis), it could very well be a 5.*
Bizarre and confusing, but once you figure out the sort of filmmaker David Lynch is, you get a better understanding as to how this movie unravels into a sad tale of jealousy and the lust for fame.

Originally this was shot as a pilot for an ABC-TV series. When it wasn't picked up, director David Lynch added an hour and turned it into a feature film. There are certainly lot of echoes of his success "Twin Peaks," but it's also easy to see why ABC wasn't interested.

Lynch has compared his concept to the often mysterious, inexplicable quality of life. If you prefer simple, linear story lines, a David Lynch movie is not going to be for you. And this one is quite out there. This was my second time seeing it and it still doesn't make any sense. For me it ends up baffling, frustrating, and plainly ludicrous.

If you want to watch it, and good luck to you if you do, it is available on The Criterion Channel, if you subscribe to that service.

Slip into a lucid trip on this winding, terrifying road high in the Hollywood hills, and leave your grip on reality behind for a magnificent, exasperating 146 minutes that defies conventional explanation, emanating from the mind-bending subconscious of American surrealist and postmodernist polymath, David Lynch. Transforming from a dark, mysterious TV pilot into a fantasia of illusion and identity as a feature film, this unsettling, psychosexual dreamscape forces viewers into the role of movie detectives, frustrating the spectator within us to search for a rational interpretation, and mystifies on a first, third or even fifth watch as 'a love story in the city of dreams', exploring themes of obsession, cinephilia and queer identity. Brilliantly spotlighted throughout are our two female leads in split roles, with a commanding and star-making turn from Naomi Watts as ingénue Betty, and Laura Elena Harring delivers a pitch-perfect performance as the helpless femme fatale Rita, making a mighty twosome that shine in intimate, erotic and most of all human scenes, no matter how strange their mysterious circumstances may appear to be. Bearing the hallmarks of classic Lynchian horror, like macabre imagery, tragic narrative beats and an intense, oestensible quality that disorients and disturbs, the Tinseltown neo-noir is considered one of the best films of the 21st century, inspiring thought-provoking conversation and almost-surgical dissection of its intoxicating sequences, thanks to its famed director's sensory style of filmmaking and visionary storytelling. Frequent Lynch collaborator and cinematographer Peter Deming is in top form capturing the uncanny in every frame, as every shot is carefully composed to drip with foreboding atmopshere and an avant-garde aesthetic, but Angelo Badalamenti's haunting and ominous score is the most memorable work in this masterpiece, acting as an emotional tour guide for delirious audiences while weaving genuine mystery into an already unsettling tale. As someone most eloquently put it, 'a beautiful experience'.

Another very peculiar and original movie by David Lynch. But it's an improvement over his 1986 film Blue Velvet, which was just boring and unengaging. The whole film feels like a dream, it's amazing how it manages to blur the lines between illusions and reality. It features amazing writing, and a very strong and great performance by Naomi Watts. Mulholland Drive is also full of symbolism, and the music is good too. It's a movie that tackles themes of illusions, guilt and desperation. But it's an art house movie for sure, it will only appeal to a certain audience, because the story takes a long time to develop, and only gets engaging enough after a good one hour. Overall, this is quite a surreal neo-noir experience, and for those who are fans of art house pics, this one has got to be seen!

This is a solid vision from an artist who has incredible ideas and visual notes in his head. This film feels wholly original to Mr. Lynch and I have ample amount of respect for that. Unfortunately, it just doesn't work for me on a personal level on how I generally watch films. It's the rare movie that made me question why I enjoy off putting and oddly structured films like Only God Forgives, 2001: A Space Odyssey and any Yorgos Lanthimos film, but can't enjoy this film. And while I don't think it's necessarily one specific reason, I do think part of it is just it's lack of coherence, not in narrative, but in pacing, tone and structure. It doesn't feel like one movie is being told from beginning to end. It feels like the assassin who comically has to kill 3 people because of unfortunate screw ups and the man who sees a scary figure outside of a diner don't belong in the same film because of how it's presented and when it's placed. I know that for the ultimate "meaning" of the movie, it was probably deliberate and that's absolutely fine. But for me personally, it's things like that throughout the movie that really make it hard to get into it's weird, dreamlike vision. All the respect to this film, I just didn't enjoy it.

#9 Naomi Watts & Laura Harring.

Mulholland Drive is the gift that keeps on giving. Like most of David Lynch's non-linear storylines, there is something new to be seen or deduced with each viewing. Long before Black Mirrors ‘Bandersnatch' got everyone's panties in a twist, Lynch had been inviting us all to choose our own endings by travelling through his unconscious as it unfolds on screen, and allowing us to dissect each alternate theory, no concept needing to be correct.

Mulholland Drive is no exception. Upon the first viewing I was left with the usual ‘what the fuck just happened' feeling. Granted, that reaction was much less obvious in comparison to the first time I saw ‘Lost Highway', some films are not meant to be explained. Both have people switching from one personality to the next and both focus on dreams.

The sexual element in Mulholland Drive may not seem that strong for a Sex Gourmet article. The sex scenes are not explicit nor lengthy and they merely allude to a full sexual encounter, however the mood that is created throughout the few close moments we see, and the talent of both Watts and Harring in these intimate scenarios, are worthy of discussion.

Betty (Watts) is a fledgling actor who has just arrived in LA to housesit for her Aunt who is working on a film abroad. Rita (Harring) has been in car crash and is suffering from amnesia. She does not know her own name. Rita, lost and confused, manages to sneak into Bettys aunt's home while the apartment is unoccupied. When Betty arrives, they have an awkward meeting in the bathroom, but soon become friends as they journey through a Nancy Drew like adventure to discover Rita's identity.

Betty is Rita's nurturing and empathic guardian throughout each twist and turn of the investigation.  With her Disney-like confidence, straight back and high blond curls, Betty is the optimistic soul in contrast to Rita's fearful, dark and mysterious nature. Rita carries physical secrets from her past. A large amount of cash, and a strange blue key. Upon finding a dead body after following a lead, they both are traumatised, and this penultimate step in their investigation leads to their first sexual experience together.

The scene is set in Bettys bedroom. Betty is in bed with freshly scrubbed face, pink pyjamas and gold hair shining nearly silver in the night-time light. She invites Rita to join her in bed to get a break from the couch Rita has been sleeping on. Rita removes her towel and she is beautifully naked as she climbs next to Betty in the large double bed. There is a look of slight awkwardness on Bettys face as she sees Rita in just her skin, but we see an appraising glance also mixed in with the shyness.

As they lie together, Rita looks up at Betty, her face open and earnest, and expresses her gratitude. There is a tangible feeling of love, kindness and trust as Rita leans over, whispers ‘goodnight sweet Betty' and kisses her on her brow. Betty turns her face up to Rita as she says goodnight and they join lips in the most tentative way. Both looking at each other in a different way than they had before.

From here, their coupling becomes more erotic than friendly, as they begin to caress and kiss each other with ardour. Betty's clothing now removed, they are pressed against each other, Betty softly touching Rita's full round breasts. The sound here is very emotive. With echoes of aroused hushed breath in the dark, their kisses become more intense and artful and it is very erotic. The camera is focused only on the upper part of their naked bodies, and as they continue and there is a real poignancy here. 

Upon first viewing, it may seem like a first-time encounter between two women, not necessarily remarkable apart from the fact that they look sublime together. As the film unfolds after this scene and upon watching for the second time, we realise the weight of this love scene. The shocking black of Rita's hair against Bettys gold as they kiss each other looks beautiful and the attraction looks authentic. Angelo Badalamenti's dark score adds significantly to the sadness that pervades this encounter.

Soon after this scene, both journey on one final escapade together in the hunt for Rita's identity. The film now takes its Lynchian turn. After an off kilter visit to a nightclub called ‘Silencio' (one the more remarkable scenes in the film) they both return home, Rita inexplicably finds a strange blue box which fits the blue key she had in her purse. Betty has now disappeared completely from the apartment despite Rita calling out for her. As Rita opens the blue box with the key, she seems to be sucked into it, and the scene fades to black.

The next scene opens with someone we think is Betty. She is in a shabby, cold apartment and dressed in a worn grey dressing gown. Despite having a striking resemblance to Betty, this woman is Diane (Watts). She has none of Bettys shine or confidence. He shoulders are slumped and her hair, dirty blonde and lank. She reminisces for a moment, and there is a flashback with her and love interest Camilla (Harring) who is Rita's doppelganger. Diane straddles Camilla on her couch in this memory, and a far cry from the modest and kind Rita, Camilla is lusty, half naked, heavily made up and cruel.

She plays with the mentally unbalanced Diane like a cat with a bird. So much so, it incites Diane and she begins to roughly molest Camilla as they lie on the couch together. There is so much angst and pain in this scene and we realise we may be looking at the real relationship of the fictional Betty and Rita. Diane is now the vulnerable and lost soul, while Camilla holds the cards and turns the handle on Diane's back, humiliating her in various moments only to show kindness shortly after, and pull Diane back into her cruel game.

The film is split in nearly two parts, the mystery of Rita's identity and a few other storylines that seem to go nowhere are nearly 80/90 minutes of this dreamy, confusing tale. The latter part shows the reality of LA, the cruelty of love and the destruction of both Diane/Betty and Camilla/Rita. There are multiple theories to be explored here. What is the purpose of the first tale and who is dreaming of who? Is it even a dream?

Shortly after we witness Diane and Camilla's near sexual romp on the couch, we see Diane alone in her apartment. Crying, desperately alone and furiously masturbating as the camera shows the wall in front of her in and out of focus. Possibly implying that the first 90 minutes of the film are nothing more than a masturbatory fantasy of Diane's as she imagines a superior life in Hollywood, better than her confused and horrific encounter of love with the unobtainable Camilla.

Mulholland Drive is a stark reminder on the significance of duality in a human lifetime. This concept is sometimes hard and painful to grasp. There is no existence without the clashing of opposites. We all strive for Utopia, peace, love and balance, when it evades us, we question why. There is no such thing as big without small, love without hate, peace without war.

From the black and white zig zag floors in Twin Peaks' Black Lodge, to the simplicity of contrast in hair colour, Lynch makes sure we know that pain and pleasure exist alongside each other, each opposite giving the other meaning. This is the human experience. We understand the greatest love and greatest agony, both beautiful in their reality side by side. Sex is the push and the acceptance. Actuality requires us to respect both sides of the coin.

We can apply these thoughts to Mulholland Drive. This is a beautiful, despairing tale of kindness, vicious love and sexual dominion, set perfectly in the mind-control mecca that is Hollywood – where dreams are manufactured.

8/10 – For mirroring the sexy dreams we wake from, at the very best moment.

One of David Lynch's most misunderstood films (they're all probably misunderstood). The film is structured as a mystery set in Hollywood, although, in typical Lynchian fashion, this version of Tineseltown is decidedly dark and skewed. The plot weaves together several strands: a young, fresh-looking Canadian girl who has come to La-la land in search of stardom; an established actress who avoids being murdered by an act of dumb luck and loses her memory as a result; and a director who is being forced by ominous powers to cast a particular woman in his movie. It's all intriguing stuff. The film is drenched in atmosphere. That shouldn't be a surprise. Credit the cinematography of Peter Deming and the score by Angelo Badalamenti. Mulholland Drive is filled with its share of "Twin Peaks"-ish moments. If you like David Lynch films chances are you'll enjoy this film although it will take a seating too many.

This is my personal favorite film of all time. There's nothing else quite like it, outside of David Lynch's own canon. But even within that canon, this is an excellent piece of work. Like all of Lynch's work, it's an acquired taste, but it rewards repeated viewing.

I had been warned many times in the past that Mulholland Dr. was a bit of an enigma that people struggle to understand, which made me extremely apprehensive. The film does start out with a number of disconnected scenes, and a lot of confusing elements, but I was surprised after watching for a little while that some of it actually played like a real story. I mean the acting was almost universally terrible, but at least a couple scenes threatened to make sense. David Lynch is never content with that kind of storytelling, though, so he’ll just randomly throw in a little person in a giant room, shown from 30 feet away for no discernible reason, or we’ll take a trip to a farcically dressed cowboy who speaks in ominous gibberish. It’s infuriating because things are shot well, and he is able to hire good actors, so I feel like he could make an amazing real movie if someone reined him in, but this is Lynch set loose. The final nail in the Mulholland Dr. coffin gets hammered in when there are only 45 minutes left and everything changes. Any slight shred of logic is thrown out the window, and it becomes a completely different movie. The two are linked through some images and characters, but otherwise Lynch gives the audience a big middle finger for trying to make sense of the prior hours of lunacy. Now we’ve got some new stupidity to deal with, and at this point I stopped caring and was begging for it to end. There is nothing I hate worse than doing homework to make sense of a film that was written so poorly that it couldn’t clearly articulate its own plot to the audience, but I made an exception this time simply because someone recommended it. Each article I read online was more and more infuriating. The general consensus seemed to be that the first 2 hours of the film were all a dream. That’s the kind of stupid nonsense that schlock movies do for a “shocking twist” at the end, yet we’re supposed to see it as genius this time because it’s made by David Lynch? No, I’m not buying into the hype. He’s a crazy person who likes to make crap up as he goes, and people assign it all deeper meaning themselves, because they want to believe he is an amazing auteur.

This is an utterly confounding experience that has more to say than most films made in the 21st century. The only David Lynch film I had seen previous to this was Dune (1984) which is a mess with some interesting parts. Fortunately this is considered one of his greatest masterpieces and I can understand why he is considered one of the most innovative directors of the latter half of the 20th century and the 21st century. I was aware that the film was going to contain surrealism and seemingly unrelated plotlines but I was not prepared for how funny, disturbing and just strange this film would turn out to be. It was an experience that I'm not sure I am ready to go through again for quite some time but I'm glad that I have seen something as original as this.

Betty Elms, Naomi Watts, is a Canadian inspiring actress who has recently moved to Los Angeles only to discover that Rita, Laura Elena Harring, is inhabiting her aunt's apartment and owns a strangely shaped blue key. The two set off on a journey that leads to a narcissistic director Adam Kasher, Justin Theroux, disturbing dreams about mobsters and a club where a crazy woman sings "Silencio." The third act plot twist comes seemingly out of nowhere and we are left wondering if what we had previously seen was all Betty's dream or if they are in an alternate timeline or any of a million other convoluted explanations to how these characters connect.

The way that I chose to interpret the film was that the first half was all Betty's fantasy as she takes on the more desirable features of Rita/Camilla and Rita comes to rely on her while in the real world their dynamic is swapped. The dinner table scene toward the end in which Betty's anger toward Camilla and Adam hints at her lesbian desire for her and we understand that her imagining Adam being attracted to her is more about her love and jealousy of Camilla than her attraction to Adam. The love scenes between the two woman also felt as though they weren't just exploiting the actresses to appeal to a male audience but trying to show the genuine affection between them.

The â~bungled heist' was also a funny and well choreographed scene that felt as though it was something out of a Shane Black movie. The execution of scenes that would feel as though they were extraneous to the plot if not for the third act twist were key to the film working. The scene set at the diner in which a man dies incorporates horror but as with the other seemingly unrelated moments keeps you on edge in your continual search for answers. Answers are never given but that would make watching and discussing the film far less interesting and the mystery is part of the point.

I am a complete plebiscite and you can read several really detailed analyses online of the various elements of the film but one of the things I really enjoyed about the film were the performances. I understand that most David Lynch films feature deliberate over acting but that works within the stories that Lynch chooses to tell. This is clear in the performances of Watts and Harring as Watts plays both an innocent ingÃ (C)nue and a washed up, jealous actress and Harring plays the dark, mysterious femme fatale who is easily manipulated. The very creepy audition scene which Watts acts in shows her working on two levels as we have seen her be a bad actress up until this point and yet during the audition she does a fantastic job and blows everyone away. Having a moment of Watts giving what would be considered modern acting in the middle of her outsized performance shows how delusional her character is.

A dreamscape of Hollywood from David Lynch.

Mulholland Drive (2001) is a not logically sound, nor is it conclusive in its character arcs as several characters and story lines disappear after awhile. You have to go into Mulholland Drive knowing that everything is simply an illusion in some form or another. The narrative makes standard sense for the first 2 hours, then the last half hour makes no sense upon a first viewing. I had to think about the finale and I realized what I had just watched was the reality and the first 2 hours were the dream all along. Mulholland Drive is a sad dream of a failed actress and scorned lover. It's like David Lynch venting out his frustrations for the types of people in L.A. He satirizes the filmmaking process and the direction's choices, while playing with structure so much that you are inevitably confused.

Mulholland Drive is certainly a slow burn, but one that flames into insanity with a satisfying flourish. I cannot stop thinking about this film as I appreciate its risks and madness all the more over time. To be honest, Mulholland Drive is not a perfect film as the slow pace can feel unbearable at times, characters are quirky for the sake of appearing dreamy and obscure, and a few effects do not really look realistic. However, the strong innovative direction from Lynch and the deep emotional and well thought out script leave the audience stunned at Mulholland Drive. How can you not be left shook from the powerful ending? Mulholland Drive asks you to undertake a journey in which your attitude must change and you must stop expecting the film to play out how you want it to, but rather attempt to understand what the film is showing you. The sheer amount of detail placed in every scene, especially as Lynch does leave you clues everywhere, while covering them up in plain sight with bizarre visuals and unexpected twists. The constantly shifting perspective keeps you engaged, while secretly undermining your sense of who characters are and which are actually important. Mulholland Drive is like a feast of red herrings.

Besides David Lynch's endlessly creative direction alongside his own gripping narrative, erratic and clever structure, and tear inducing emotional arc, the score in Mulholland Drive is quite beautiful. Lynch knows how and when to invoke lovely songs to lavish you in sound.

Lastly, the performances are key in Mulholland Drive. Naomi Watts gives her career best performance as an actress in Mulholland Drive. Her endearing charming Betty is also captivating in her audition sequence. Watts plays up the sweetness simultaneously with the madness of Diane. Likewise, Laura Harring gives Rita and Camilla a charming sultry appeal. Her focused anguish and sudden fear meld with stunning beauty and charming personality. She is the perfect foil for Naomi Watts laying on waves of soothing kindness and impressive expressiveness. I have to hand it to Justin Theroux as Adam. He embodies Lynch's frustrations with directing films in Hollywood.

Overall, I have to say that Mulholland Drive is incredibly frustrating initially. It was not for several hours until I realized the massive scope and vivid detail that went into Mulholland Drive. Lynch is clearly a mad genius with more ambition than nearly any other American director. I applaud his creative vision and technical skill at accomplishing a film of such profound emotion and straightforward narrative delivered in a mad structure.
I had a terrible dream. A dream that became reality.
My favourite movie of all time. It just bugs my mind and I LOVE IT!
Very much an Art style movie demanding attention from the viewer but rewarding it with a trip into darkest of the human soul. All involved are to be congratulated on a fine piece of work.

The good news: The film is drenched in atmosphere. That shouldn't be a surprise. Credit the cinematography of Peter Deming and the score by Angelo Badalamenti. Mulholland Drive is filled with its share of "Twin Peaks"-ish moments. This is why the atmosphere is so important to most movies but especially to this kind of films.  But, after a promising start and an engaging midsection, there's the third act to deal with. And it's not a pretty sight. Lynch cheats his audience, pulling the rug out from under us. He throws everything into the mix with the lone goal of confusing us. Nothing makes any sense because it's not supposed to make any sense. There's no purpose or logic to events. Lynch is playing a big practical joke on us. He takes characters we have come to care about and obscures their fates in gibberish. Some people will undoubtedly decide this is all very deep and will find hidden meanings in everything, but they're giving Lynch too much credit. This is not good filmmaking; it's immature and wasteful.(Amazing first two thirds, then cop out).

There are three ways to watch Lynch's neo-noir dreamscape 'Mulholland Drive'. Most common are for viewers to find it evasive and dismiss any true meaning behind its script. Secondly some try and cling on to all of it's possible meanings and end up feeling defeated. The proper way to watch, to truly enjoy this cinema, is to accept your own interpretations and decide what to absorb and what to exempt from the journey. Regardless of your mindset prior to viewing, you won't take your eyes off the screen and will be left with deep rooted curiosity... or anger. THERE IS NO RIGHT ANSWER when it comes to Lynch. Having seen the entirety of his work and having paid close attention to his almost non existing explanations of his projects, I promise you, he loves to fuck with us.

David Lynch's Mulholland Drive is a unique movie. Unique because regardless of what you consider- if you liked the film or not- you will think about what you just saw. It is a reactionary film in ways because it toys with your perception. Naomi Watts arrives in Los Angeles as a wide-eyed starlet who finds a mysterious woman, shaken and damaged in her apartment. With her career not going as desired she teams with this woman to solve the mystery of who she really is and how did she come to be in that situation. This is a psychological film with multiple layers and themes which might confuse you. Lynch is an auteur and all his films reek of atmosphere and this one is no different. You should try Mulholland Drive- I enjoyed it and will see it many times in time to come.

Mulholland Drive is not an easy film to sit through and one might even get tempted to get up midway and leave. But if you understand David Lynch and his mind you'll find a lot to appreciate here. At the top of my head is the stunning atmosphere. This film reeks of a certain "vibe" and even though the film is long it keeps this vibe all throughout. The soundtrack only helps and the acting from everyone involved is exactly what David Lynch likes it. The story is too convoluted to mention here but all I can say is this film is something of a challenge and you should definitely give it a shot.

Fortunately or unfortunately, I was inadvertently front loaded with the film's basic structure.  Had I not been aware of this, there's a good to very good chance I might have walked out.  While the performances were solid, the film is an overrated, over arched attempt at creating a mysterious look into the depths of a female actor's unconscious.  The result was a forced grown-up version of The Wizard of Oz.  The film had many gripping moments with beautiful subtleties from the performers but I walked away with an even further cemented conviction that Hollywood is a cesspool in a land of broken dreams.  Mr. Lynch should go and study Mr. Hitchcock's films if he wants to learn how to develop the art of true mystery.  It seems however, he would rather hit viewers over the head with a sledgehammer.  On another note, did anyone get reminded of Tales of the City?  Now that was a lovely piece of work.  Save yourself the agony and skip Mullholland Drive.,

A classic Lynch film in the sense that it's got you piecing together what happened hours after you leave the theater. Unlike some of his other films, however, Mulholland Drive contains perhaps one of the more accessible plot lines--even while set in its non-linear framework. It all kind of falls together into place, worth one or several more rewatches to fully grasp the intricacies. Naomi Watts also gives an exceptional performance in the leading role, and that coupled with the resounding humor and emotion of the film makes it one of my all time favorites.

The movie follows a fascinating crime adventure story set in Los Angeles for a while.  The many threads here have the makings of a great story centered on a newly arrived innocent young actress who befriends an amnesiatic crash victim with thousands of dollars in her purse.   It feels like a classic "edgy mystery action" movie like "True Romance"...until a reality twist reveals a much grittier, real, and petty version.  The story is challenging and requires interpretation, and viewers have to be looking for that type of experience to enjoy it.  The characters are interesting, and the performances are outstanding.  One of the more coherent Lynch films, in my opinion, this movie still has a lot of unexplained symbolism and scenes that can be pointlessly debated (yay) and really just bloat the running time.  Although overall I am positive, it bugs me that the reality shift comes at a point that seems unconnected to the events occurring at that moment - it just happens, like an egg timer went off.  Is the story telling here genius or lazy?  Some of each, I would say, but worth it to watch and find out what you think.
This is an excellent and unique film full of hidden meanings that deserves multiple viewing. I'm now flickering through all sorts of explanations on the web.

Mulholland Drive isn't for everyone, but then it is a given with David Lynch. But those willing to give it a chance might be in for a surprise. Moody and atmospheric Mullholand drive is unarguably Lynch's most commercial film although at more than 3 hours it tests the audience's patience. It also contains one of the most unintentional boo moments which occurs early in the film as a character after recounting a dream makes his way through a car park. No matter what you think, you are bound to ponder about this film long after it is over.  (A Lynchian nightmare).

Mulholland Drive is a beautiful work of art, and it's unlike anything you've seen before. This is perhaps David Lynch's masterpiece. That being said, it is a surrealist film. If you're expecting your typical coherent, easy-to-follow plot where everything is laid out or tied up at the end, this isn't that kind of movie. Let's put it this way: Mulholland Drive came out in 2001, and it's still being discussed as to what exactly happened. And Lynch being Lynch, he still won't spell it out for you. That seems to be his thing these days. He enjoys making surrealist films with the intention of each viewer having their own personal experience and drawing their own conclusions. In my opinion, Mulholland Drive is the closest thing to having an almost coherent storyline since Wild at Heart in 1990. It's his most intriguing work, I believe, and leaves the viewer feeling engaged with just a hint - a feeling that the mystery of what you just watched is solvable. It's easier to digest than Lost Highway or Inland Empire. It's a great, beautiful, tragic journey. Naomi Watts' performance is one of the greatest I've ever seen. She should have won an Oscar for Mulholland Drive.

This movie is highly over-rated.  It was originally a pilot for another series like twin peaks.  when that failed to be picked up the director made this movie from the bones of the pilot.  It is clearly seen in early parts of the film when several characters and elements are introduced and left hanging.  Of course the director was clever to save a failed pilot and make it into a movie, but it is nowhere near the masterpiece that people are suggesting.  The few main characters that the director takes and spins into the tacked on ending switch is part of a clever plot but you can see this was not planned based on how many of the early elements have nothing to do with this last minute switch.  If this was acknowledged I would have more respect, but the bait and switch of it all and how people lap it up make it really annoying to see that it was a quick rework of a failed pilot and nowhere near so fantastic master class of story telling.

David Lynch at his finest; Mulholland Drive is a surreal neo-noir art piece full of the red herrings, doppelgangers, and motifs Lynch is best known for. Naomi Watts is incredible as the suspiciously naive Betty Elms and Laura Harring does well as the mysterious Rita. I felt like the constant misdirection and eerie subtext created distrust with what you're witnessing, which perfectly captures the atmosphere of Hollywood.

This is actually a David Lynch production that I think I figured out.  I interpreted it as the price of fame, versus the harsh reality and what happens if you are not good enough.  Very enjoyable and more accessible than Lynch's other work.

I'm a fan of Naomi Watts' work, and there's a reason this film put her on the map. The high level of acting mixed with the creativity and originality of the script makes this film a MUST see! Make sure you're paying attention, because you don't want to miss a single detail until the credits role.

'Mulholland Drive' is effortlessly one of the best films of the 21st century. Genius director David Lynch takes his audience head first into a surreal, neo-noir world full of complex characters, nightmarish imagery and amazing soundtrack (everything you'd expect from Lynch) and after the credits close you feel like you have just woken up from a dream that is both terrifying and beautiful. Naomi Watts delivers one of the most unforgettable performances in film history and captivates the audience in every scene she is in, while being backed up from wonderful performances by Laura Harring and Justin Theroux. Angelo Badalamenti's haunting score greatly contributes to the atmosphere of the film, as well as several stand out songs such as "Sixteen Reasons" by Connie Stevens and "Llorando" by Rebekah Del Rio. While mainstream audiences may be put off by the slow-moving plot line and many unanswered questions, 'Mulholland Drive' offers a compelling and thought-provoking storyline for those who dare.
A Buddhist film which will leave audiences guessing WTF is going on the entire movie.

Claimed to have been left open-ended for interpretation on what had transpired in the film, it's actually not that much of a challenge from my interpretation on this puzzling, mysterious film based on its genuine unconventional narrative structure. Except that there are still a couple moments in the films that are puzzle pieces that can't be located easily till after another viewing, which signifies the surreal element to the substance. While it's quite engaging enough to be utterly entertaining without swerving into convolution territory, it adds into David Lynch's reputation after "Blue Velvet" with ways of attempting to disturb the viewers, with this film being more enjoyable and can be seen as a twisted relative to "All About Eve" regarding a popped-up comparison between the two as a letter to Hollywood. The most memorably striking quality that stood out is the music that emphasizes the aura of the scene. "Mulholland Drive" can be disturbing in some places, but it's surely worth seeing, and as a probable supplemental preparation to Lynch's other similarly-structured film "Inland Empire". (B+)

I have always had an issue with people who watch movies like this, get up from their seats, and say, "That was conceited crap," because either they felt stupid and insecure when they couldn't understand it right away, or they refuse to give it any thought beyond what they were thinking during the movie. A certain lack of effort seems to have become the norm here in the US and it really bugs me because people like David Lynch who in my mind are without a doubt, brilliant, are not taken as seriously as they should be because his movies require a bit of thinking to appreciate. Yes, this is a difficult movie to enjoy, but oh man, is it worth it when you do. I feel that I understand this movie enough (though obviously, I will never understand it completely, no matter how many nights I contemplate it before I go to sleep) after doing a lot of research  (Salon.com's explanation of this movie is really the best) to understand it to the extent that it is meant to and it is oh so rewarding because even if it is meant to be interpreted for the most part by its audience, its actual plot is intriguing, gripping, and really pretty brilliant. It isn't often that you find a movie with two plots that work this successfully with one another, especially when you're sort of making one of them up. With the knowledge I got from my research I can say that beyond the story, this movie is a pretty scathing statement on Hollywood and how the industry treats its workers (especially its directors and female actors.) while at the same time being sort of self-deprecating in a really funny way. This movie communicates so much so successfully, it's really pretty unbelievable. My only complaint is its gratuitous sequences of lesbian sex which I have heard defended a hundred times and I still have problems with. As a femme lesbian, I can say the sex in the movie is over the top and completely inaccurate. I cannot wrap my head around it being an artistic statement about sex scenes in other movies like people say it is or really anything other than for the enjoyment of the men making the movie. I understand that David Lynch has a reputation of putting actresses in situations like this, doing it almost to the point of humiliation, such as with Isabella Rosellini in Blue Velvet, which for this same reason, I somewhat agree with Ebert's reasoning for giving it such a bad review, even if I do love the rest of the movie outside that scene. That aside, however, Please, please watch this with an open mind and let yourself revel in the mindfuck for a while. It truly is a unique experience and deserves to be watched. I really cannot say enough about this movie. It is sort of infinite in a way. It's a real monster, but a monster you'll love for all of its complexities.

I waited a few days to write this review because I was so brought back by Mulholland Drive. David Lynch creates an extremely confusing ride. Their is almost no structure at all to this film. There are some good scenes and the film can feel sad and eerie at times but I think Mulholland Drive is too pretentious for its own good.

It contains true horror, true comedy, and everything in between. You'll laugh, cry and you'll be scared shitless. On top of that, it tells a beautiful story in the best way it could. Naomi Watts' great performance is the cherry on top.
Dashed dreams and expectation of Hollywood. This is a weird movie, but not as weird as I expected. Kind of brings to mind "Kiss Me Deadly" in a fantastical way.

Cult film from 2001 it appears but left me utterly confused at the end.
It took two viewings to get a faint understanding of events and even then after cheating and reading original reviews of the film from its release.
The film begins with an apparent car accident on Mullholand Drive in the Hollywood hills of Los Angeles
leading to the amnesia of a survivor (Laura Herring).
Herrings character (at this point unnamed) stumbles into the house of an aspiring Hollywood actress Betty Elms (Naomi Watts).
Betty with Herring who takes the name of Rita, after Rita Hayworth the actress try to solve the mystery of the amnesia meanwhile in other peripheral storylines that at first appear to have no relation to these events. People are shot, lesbian relationships develop, there is a Quentin Tarantino like director, casting sessions. The list seems endless.
There is a relationship to these pretty innocuous events that becomes apparent after studying the film you have just watched!
It takes a lot of concentration and detective work. Something that you won't expect from most films.
Director David Lynch delivers a film that is very thought provoking.

Having been familiar with Lynch's Twin Peaks TV series, this is just like a continuation of that same style. A noir thriller complete with mysterious femme fatale, strange characters and surrealist dream sequences, like it dark and strange turns while still keeping a glossy exterior.

A surrealist, neo-noir film that oozes with complexity and eeriness. The totality of this film is grounded not only on the protagonist's subconscious but on the viewer as well. You always have to read between the lines to discover how creepy and sad this movie is.
Can't explain any further, but two things for sure - Hollywood and unrequited love is like oil and water, and David Lynch is a peculiar, insane filmmaker to love.

Second time I watch this. It seems this time the story does make sense. The dvd version has a cut that makes more sense. It is simpler. It is still strange and dreamy. Now that I have heard more about lesbians, it makes sense that the blonde was lesbian from the start. The first part is off. Is it dream? It's not memory. Memory is the ending. What is the cube? Who is the old couple laughing at Diane/Betty? Many unanswered questions. My take is that, the poor Diane became insane after the contract killing, and that is the first part. Dreaming insanity from a guilty person. Guilty of contracting the killing of her love. Her egotistical love didn't die though.

This is David Lynch at the peak of his powers. The atmosphere is amorphous and moody, yet still manages a sense of dreamlike hope. We are all reeled into the angelic trenches of the city. The mysterious allure of Los Angeles has never before been so magnificently employed on screen. The acting is superb, the mystic score by Angelo Badalamenti is enthralling, and the twists and turns of the film turn us into obsessive detectives. The film is a puzzle, a riddle with endless interpretive answers. It perfectly rides the road of masterful surrealism, as opposed to another path of excessive abstraction (which some of his other works often do). This is a major classic, stamped into the record book of artistic achievement.
4.5/5.  I don't know if David Lynch is a genius, or insane, or both.  Watch it and tell me.

Mulholland Drive is ultimately a film that shouldn't really work, but does. At times implausible, sometimes brilliant, and occasionally plain weird. An unconventional structure will put off some, but it's overall feel and aesthetic is one which stays with you for a long time after.
