One of the best films of its' decade, Mulholland Drive is the kind of film that makes you discover something new every time you watch it. The fact that there seems to be no consensus amongst fans, viewers, critics, and scholars on the exact meaning of Mulholland Drive speaks to the genius of Lynch's film making. It's noir, high art, and eclectic enough for Hitchcock to be impressed if he was alive to see it.

One of the most bizarre, absorbing and fascinating psychological mystery thriller neo-noir films ever made. Upon repeated viewings, it will never make complete sense, but the ride is always oh so absorbing and fascinating, trying to figure out what's real, dreamed and who's who. Lynch at the top of his form.

Still can't get one particular scene out of my head. When Patrick Fischler and Michael Cooke's characters walk behind the back of the diner after Justin's dream description. Really displays Lynch's mastery of film-making and the horror/thriller genre.
The point where the Mulholland Dr TV pilot ends and the movie continuation starts is clear, a total pivot which to many is nonsense. I am huge fan of that turn and the way it all unravels.

I watched this movie for the first time years ago, and I basically despised it.  I felt like it was a grandiose vision by a director that had some sort of message to deliver, that I just was not privy to.  However, I re-watched the movie for only the 2nd time more recently, with an interpretation to the film that I found online, and it has since become one of my favorite movies of all time.  

Look, I am fully aware the notion of sitting and reading a "how-to" guide for disgesting a film may be daunting, shameful, or ludicrous to some, but if there were ever a director where something like this may seem to be not only acceptable, but possibly even preferable, that director would be Lynch.  This movie executes a beautifully told story, that intricately weaves and blurs the lines of fantasy and reality.  While it may take more than one viewing to fully digest just exactly what the hell it is that is going on in this movie, once you do comprehend it all, you'll want to watch it again and again.  Only unlike me after my first viewing, you'll be watching it again out of enjoyment, fulfillment, and the desire to see what little Easter Eggs and hidden messages you missed out on the first time round.
Completely unpredictable
One of my most fav Films,  visually stunning,  you won't take your eyes off it from start to finish, naomi watts brilliant,  cannot rate this film highly enough

You have to hand it to David Lynch: he knows how to mess with your mind. I'm sure in this beautifully directed film there is some connection between every strange and absurd thing, but part of its allure is it elusiveness and constant audience speculation. This is the mark of a really great film: people still talk about what it means. Classic Lynch style. At the heart of this mind-bending film (part of the colloquially titled Mind f*&k genre which Donnie Darko and Memento also belong to) is a tragic love story of broken hearts and dreams.

A movie should excel on a first viewing. Lynch puts so much detail,symbolism, and story into each shot that it practically begs a second view. I wont pretend like I understood everything, but I did enjoy the world that Lynch created. It was so dream-like, yet it felt like it was decaying. 

Watch if you are a fan of cinema or Lynch. Others may have a hard time grasping the ambitiously told saga of a young actress in Hollywood. I certainly did, but its refreshing to be challenged by a movie every now and then, especially one as well crafted as Mulholland Drive.

An energetic, ambitious and talented beauty arrives in LA fresh off the plane. She is confident that she has what it takes to make it big in the glam world of movies. A beauty who seems to be just a bit older is in a horrific car wreck. 

With no memory of who she is, she stumbles her way down from Mulholland Drive and into the apartment that the excited would-be-starlet is about to arrive. Once she arrives, David Lynch's energetic and experimental film forms itself into a rambling mystery. 

Think Nancy Drew meets Edvard Munch for an experimental journey on peyote through the land of hope and dreams of a Hollywood long dead. 

The inspiration for this film came from a filming mini-series that the network abandoned. Most filmmakers would have been at a loss, but David Lynch pulls together fragments of various subplots that lead our two protagonists on a danger and erotically-fueled journey of hope, dreams, tragedy, confusion and identity. 

This is a beautiful puzzle of a movie. No pieces are missing, but no amount of repeated viewing will ever allow for a full understanding of what is essentially a genuine work of art that applies just enough intelligence to mix with Surrealism and dark comedy. 

Of particular interest is a seeming erotic connection that leads us into one of the most intentionally comical views of lesbian sex filmed entirely from the viewpoint of a straight male fantasy. What begins as an intense erotic moment quickly turns to comedy and then transports us into a world of unknown horrors. 

A visual and aural lush experience. Best to simply allow it to flow over you. Again and again. Mulholland Drive is brilliantly deceptive and endlessly entertaining. 

Not to be missed.

This is a slow movie about the mind bifurcation. I find it a second Lynch's (director) attempt on a subject. The first one was his "Lost Highway" but I think in "Lost Highway" too little clues are given. I think "Lost Highway" splits in many meanings with almost no story left to the viewer. Here it is mostly the same, but the main story is somewhat preserved, which makes it a more complete in my eyes. I also think this film should be watched at least twice -- because on the first seening it is hard feel the full amount of inspiration which Lynch put in this movie.

Arguably the best and most exciting thriller of all time. With his slow pace and the scattered clues (like pieces of a puzzle), Lynch manages to bore you for most of the film, only to accelerate at the end, in a whirpool of images which are aimed to connect all pieces of the puzzle in one of the most amazing finals ever made in a film. Only at the end , with the whole tale ,you realize the genius of David Lynch and how he had played you for most of the film. A real masterpiece. Only David Lynch could have made such an intriguing story.

A dizzying, mind-numbing experience that is more laborious to sit through than to love, unfortunately. But when this film hits you, in the only way David Lynch can, you will be absolutely stunned and awed. In the midst of tedium, there is absolutely beauty, and genius on display. Certain scenes just make the film completely memorable. They contribute to the cult success that this film has gotten, and it's reputation as one of the 21st century's best films. But for this viewer, it just didn't resonate with me. Blue Velvet on the other hand, don't get me started on what that film did to me.
Fantastic in every sense of the word. Lynch turns Hollywood into the dreamland than many view it as.

I've never been the best at understanding movies. I mean, I'm a big fan of them, and probably understand them thematically more than a lot of other people, but sometimes, I'll admit, I get confused about certain implications of a scene, or a plot twist, or just what's happened dramatically in the film. One need not know particulars about property and water ownership to enjoy Chinatown, but I'll admit that I got a bit tripped up trying to understand all the real estate stuff that was going on.

Mulholland Drive is a movie I was warned beforehand I would likely not understand. The first three quarters or so - it's kind of hard to tell how much of the movie was devoted to each section since it's weirdly structured - I understood everything that was going on, and though I couldn't yet tie everything together or solve the mysteries, I had faith that they would be solved and I would understand them. It was easy to juggle the various plot lines. But then that last quarter happened, and nothing was as it seemed to be, and I felt the familiar sensation of not understanding what was going on. So I can understand why people don't get it. I felt like I only had a vague idea of what the ending meant. Afterwards, though, I read some plot summaries online, and I realized that I DID understand the dramatic situation. Things I felt unsure about turned out to be right, so I'm actually hardly confused about the movie. Most of it can be summed up in a sentence: a woman named Diane is depressed after failing professionally and in her romantic life, so she constructs a complex dream, a sort of fantasy of what she wished was going on. Most scenes that don't seem to have a specific psychological function in the dream are simply side effects, other pieces from her life given random configuration in her brain, just like dreams actually work.

Upon first finding out that the first two hours of the movie were a dream, I was a bit disappointed. There's always a danger when there's a big twist like that, because you get really invested in the plot, and the twist upends all of that. There's a part of me that wants to forget about the fact that it's all a dream and just find out why those mobsters(?) wanted Camilla Rhodes to get the part in the movie, or to find out Rita's true identity. Characters like the Cowboy were really interesting, and there's a certain degree of disappointment when you realize that there aren't going to be real answers to the questions posed at the beginning, within the context of this constructed narrative. We accept narratives in film as if they're real things that are happening, so in turn, we except the narrative within the narrative. It violates that implicit trust we have to upend that.

Mulholland Drive is different, though, I decided after some deep thought. First of all, there's tons of foreshadowing throughout, with Betty even saying she's in "this dream place." The telegraphing is set from the first scene, in which a weird, psychedelic jitterbugging scene is shown, and there's an odd camera hovering over a sleeping figure (we later find out is Diane). This foreshadowing throughout is critical, because what first appears to be "okay, really? That came from nowhere" turns to "surprising but inevitable."

The other big thing is that the first two hours are a pretty remarkable representation of a dream. There are plots that go dropped, and sequences interrupting the main story in odd ways. The viewer thinks these are subplots at the time, but you can imagine in Diana's head the way random scenes would be stuck between her main dream, just like real dreams. There are weird hallucinations, sexual fantasies, and semi-important characters who we later realize Diane may have met once and then repurposed for her dream. As an example, in the dream narrative, the main character is Betty, and she sees a waitress with the name Diane. In real life, this is flipped, and the waitress's name is Betty. So when Diane falls asleep that night, the first alternative name to call herself is Betty, since she vaguely remembers that name from somewhere. It's kind of brilliant. The main story may be more complex than an average dream, and more vivid, but it's probably the closest I've come to seeing a movie that actually depicts a dream in a pretty realistic way. That, ultimately, is what makes the ending of Mulholland Drive a spectacular twist instead of a cop-out.

Leave it to David Lynch, to tell a simple mystery tale through the haziest, free-form structure possible in blurring the lines between dream, nightmare, and reality. Nothing is inconsequential, no matter how little it plays into the plot development. After a while, the plot itself becomes a trivial concern in the art of storytelling. The images we receive, and seeing how the characters give and receive imagery, can be beautiful, disturbing, many times both. As per usual with David Lynch, his universe is truly his own -- Roy Orbison is the voice of God, one minor character can sense when reality is out of order, slapstick is the funniest style of humour, romance is never stable, and, most alluringly, the townspeople generally accept that there might exist a conspiracy or supernatural entity. No questions are asked. I always feel under the effects of hypnosis, even at the movie's tensest moments.
This is a movie you don't want to admit you don't understand. And there is some lesbo action towards the end.

This is a movie that deserves - and probably needs - a second sight.
At first, for some reason, I perceived it more comic than dramatico (or whatever David Lyinch wanted to mean, even if any real meaning is in here). 
Actually, comic situations are many, for example the idiotic dreamer, scared literally to death by a child nightmare monster, is more comic than tracic, the cowboy is quite exilarant, the bumbling professional killer, and more.
As David Lynch is a transcendental meditation practitioner, I set myself in a meditation mood, before trying the second view. And, yes, something quite different came. IT is not necessary to understand, and probably, it is better to not try to understand. As with meditation, any attempt to follow a rational thinking is distracting.
David Lyinch needs to be perceived, not understood. Loose your toughts free, let your own imagination accept the impressions this movie can give to you - everybody his own impressions, and enjoy.
However, I keep thinking that, in writing and directing his kind of movies, Mr. Lynch has a lot of fun, and for sure a lot more when he reads  what critics and other people see in them, and probably he spends some time loughing on the oddest interpretations.
Scary in a way that few films can be, intriguing in a way you can't describe, it's a singular experience. Full review later.

After viewing Mulholland Drive for the second time, something like 10 years after the first viewing, it does not seem as confusing this time. I have been a fan since Blue Velvet and Twin Peaks. This time it seems that the film has scenes which should have been edited out, such as the man who had the two dreams, the thug who shoots several people, the Silencio segment, plus some shorter other unnecessary scenes. It should have been pared down to the parallel lesbian love stories. The blue box, and the blue keys are symbols without reference points within the two love stories. Frankly, I found some of it silly, the Cowboy, the spooky looking homeless fellow behind Winkies' cafe, who somehow winds up with the blue box. The first time I saw this film I was left with a creepy sense of unease because of the sight of Diane Selwyn's corpse. That scene really freaked me out. This time I was left with s profound sense of sadness at the fate of the young Canadian actress whose Hollywood dream becomes an unbearable nightmare.
This is the best film of the 21st century and David Lynch's best work. The symbolism is great. The characters are odd (in a good way). The story is fresh and innovative.
Plays like a dream within a dream, within a dream, etc....
Strangely fascinating!
I could not make sense of this movie Maybe it is suppose to be that way. I did enjoy the erotic scenes.
Films need to be more like this.
sorry, it went right over my head.
WOW just wow. A couple of scenes scared the shit outta me and the movie left me bewildered and depressed for days. So tragic.
Although the film is mysterious, suspenseful, and mesmerizing, there are moments of terrible acting that mar Mulholland Drive's cryptic narrative.

Barely harmed by some of its ways to conclude characters and its story, Mulholland Drive is an entretaining tale with an amazing cast and with an ambience thats thrilling, scary and just plain amazing. The pace at which the story is told and how the mystery is treated make this film one of my favorite horror/thrillers from the hand of a director that knows exactly what stories to tell and how to tell them, and I was not dissapointed.
I don't even know if I am supposed to take it seriously. It all looks so ridicolous and unpleasant. The plot is just confusing and pointless. I guess I am not a Lynch fan.

A dark, complex, and unforgettable journey into the surreal and ominous realm of Hollywood.

Full Review: http://www.movie-blogger.com/movie-review/dark-and-complex-thriller

David Lynch is without a doubt, one of the most individual and bizarre talents we have working to date. His career spanning from short nightmarish movies to oscar performance winners, from music videos to mind bending thrillers, oh and lets not forget Twin Peaks, the cult TV show due for a third season in 2016. Much like Twin Peaks, Mulholland Drive was originally a concept for another television show, however after it was denied, Lynch went ahead and turn his maniacal idea into a film. The outcome? A slick and twisted thriller, that begins as a tense fuelled roller coaster from hell and transends into an even deeper level. Betty moves to Hollywood in hope of fufilling her dream as an actress, until she can get on her feat her loving aunt puts her up in a lush apartment, while off on a film project of her own. Here Betty finds Rita, a victim of a serious and obscure accident, plagued with memory loss, Betty and Rita go on the hunt to find Rita's true identity. The further down the rabbit hole we go, we are introduced to a whole host of characters in this world, most notably Adam, a big time film director, who is having quite a day and a gun for hire, who just has the worst luck ever. All is nowhere as it seems and soon the female duo find themselves in a dangerous game, where both lives are at risk. The first hour of this film is really hard to adjust to if your not accuainted with previous Lynch outings, dialogue is cheesey and blunt. Images and metaphor run rampant throughout and at times you are left questioning your sanity. However as the film draws closer to its conclusion, like most of the best puzzles, everything slots right into place. The cast are all wonderful in bringing the erratic characters to life, Justin Theroux is hilarious and arrogant as the big shot director who just cant seem to get his way, his scenes deliver the comic releif and believe me, in this film its needed. Naomi Watts is Betty and she manages to play the part so over the top with innocence that you cant help but fall in love with her niavety for danger. Laura Harring also puts in a desperate and distraught tour de force with the character of Rita, subtle and brooding, she is the films anchor. The music by Angelo Badalamenti is haunting and spine tingling and really brings Lynch's world to life, enjoying flits of jazz from time to time to keep the beat going. Visually this film is like a mesh of Hollywood meets arthouse, its dizzying camera and obscure focus pulls merge wonderfully with gorgeous and noirish shots that really give this film a sense of polish and attention to detail. The film however does have one upsetting factor and thats its final act, not because its bad, in fact its the ending that makes you realize just how well crafted a film this is, however it becomes apparent that more time was meant to be spent fleshing out these characters and it becomes apparent that this would have enjoyed more success as a TV show. That aside, Mulholland Drive is a worthwhile and excellent addition to the Lynch collection, is it his best? No, but then who can be perfect all the time?

When I first watched the movie in 2001 I was still hoping Lynch had actually something to say, despite the disappointment with Wild at heart. I was surprised by the high rating and good reviews this movie got, but finally when I watched the movie again tonight on TV I got the point: hot, young, naked actresses and plenty of lesbian sex. Watts and Harring starring as the mysterious Rita and Betty go all the way, titillating the viewers with their antics.

Undeniably, both Watts and Harring really did a good job with the absurd script they got. But the script remains absurd. My personal take is that Lynch had a grudge against the Hollywood establishment and the whole movie is supposed to prove some point, such as how directors are forced to choose actors, even when they would prefer to cast somebody else.


It is pointless to summarize the plot, since the movie switches into a different one two thirds into the story. Anybody can interpret the complete lack of logic in whichever way they want and then "accuse" whoever does not "get" it of being dumb. The point is, there is nothing to "get", apart from Lynch frustration, unleashed on paying audience, a plot that does not make any sense and a couple of good actresses, only one of them actually making a career out of this crappy movie.


While Mulholland Drived propelled Watts into super stardom, Harring was left behind. Which seems unfair, but then again, perhaps fitting in Lynch's world where nothing makes sense. However, Mulholland Drive put me off Lynch's world once and for all.
P.S. I like fictional stories to make some sort of sense, since I get plenty of absurdity from real life. I think authors could make an effort to churn out stories with a beginning a middle and an end, even if not necessarily in this order. Creativity does not necessarily imply messy, self-involved narrative.

This was such a mesmerizing film that felt like being in a very complex dream full of mystery and sensuality, starring Naomi Watts and Laura Haring. They were both exceptional in their respective role(s), and worth excellently in the direction of David Lynch who once again knows how to make people think and go to places they've never even heard off. Moreover, the plot of the movie at first may seem ordinary but knowing its a David Lynch's film things are not always what they seem. Therefore the movie starts going many places and with different stories, but never bores you but it keeps you interested and amazed about this world this characters are. It's very fascinating to experience this movie and try to understand what's going on, even though you may never know, but by simply watching it it gives you a certain satisfaction because of how awesome and amazing this movie was, because it truly is a cinematic masterpiece like no other. 
~November 2, 2014~
Absolutely one of the worst movies of all time.  It was so confusing and a plot that made so little sense that it left you feeling that you simply wasted two hours of your life.
when you figure out it's structure , movie becomes a much simpler and shallower experience , however it's still a good movie with a nice twist .

I've seen quite a lot of confusing films that have similar plot-lines and situations. However, Mulholland Drive is a fascinating and eerie film that completely bends away from anything that you could ever think about. The film follows an optimistic woman who comes to Hollywood seeking fame. At the same time, an amnesiac woman seeks for help, and the two women befriend each other and go on a mysterious quest. What makes this film so wonderful, is its beautiful direction from David Lynch, and how it is presented in a dreamlike way. Mulholland Drive is a thriller at its best, and captures the true meanings of identity, and fear.
Hollywood and its denizens seen through a rotting jaudiced eye, Naomi Watts' unforgettable performance and Lynchian surreal menace seeping out of every scene - make this a must see
It's one of the all time great films. And one of the 21st century's very best
Mulholland Drive is a complex thriller that appears like a dream thanks to its structure. Not easy to undertstand you may follow all the clues scattered by David Lynch.
*beep* Lost connection in the last 20 minutes. Really need to watch it once again to understand its twistedly briliance.
Insane plot twist pretty much sums it up. Great female leads
Amazing movie for ones who love to have their mind twist over and over again (like me) ! David Lynch's masterpiece!

I appreciate a good commentary but movies still need to have a bit of coherence. I got weary of being intrigued after about an hour and just wanted things to start coming together, which they only mildly did in the last 10 minutes.
Excellent no great! Wait no...an astounding film! An astounding subliminal middle finger to Hollywood by David Lynch!

A surreal, mindbending, and complex masterpiece from David Lynch. The utter style and tone to this film is incredibly well done. The film itself is a lot deeper than one would think, and it is beyond extraordinary. This film is nothing like I have ever seen before. Mulholland Drive will take the title of one of the most twisted, unnerving, & weird films I have ever seen. And in that sense, it is also one of my favorite films of all time. 
An underrated masterpiece.
I was in awe when the credits started rolling in. Mulholland Drive is not a film for everyone, the story and plot are hard to follow, but if it can be interpreted in a certain way, there is much greatness inside of it.
This film experience was unforgettable.

are all of David Lynch's movies weird? the only other Lynch film i've seen is Eraserhead, and boy, i don't think i'll ever forget that one. this one was also very random and confusing - i assume there's a deeper meaning somewhere in all of it, just as i'm sure there is in Eraserhead as well... but i don't really have an inclination to watch this one over again to find out. however, i'll definitely be revisiting Eraserhead in the future.

86%
David Lynch mad e a good pilot for a shelved series and later on gate it a convoluted, misleading and at times immature conclusion to make it into a movie, which turned out to be the eye candy of many and the film had many interpretations, admirers and it became a cult film. I did not understand all of the film's twists in the endings, so I had to read the Wikipedia to understand the interpretations. Once I did the same I like it, but I have no interest to watch it again, quite contrary to most of the suggestions. When all the ideas are put together, it fails to tell why the director has given a good role to the character played by Justin Theroux in the first half. The beginning of the film and it's first half were linear, but it got kind of messy after that, but once put in order, it becomes both a mystery film and a psychological one. The film has a fine performance from Naomi Watts and there are a few stunning nude scenes. This is definitely a watch for those with interests on confusing films.

One of director David Lynch's greatest accomplishments.Mulholland Drive is one Great big dream that defies all dreams.Is it a nightmare?,is it a dream of  enlightment?,is it a dream of "making-it" in Hollywood possibly? ,or is it a dream of guilt and remorse?.I have seen many films about dreams but none have come as close to describing a real dream better than Mulholland Drive.It doesnt give us any actual answers to what is happening and why we are dreaming it is simply just giving us a thrill that makes us crazed and and amazed at the same time!.Though some may find it bizzare and confusing but there is true meaning behind it,and that meaning you will have to find out for yourself.A David Lynch masterpiece!
I cannot even begin to formulate a comprehensible idea of what I've just watched. Creepy. Surreal. Enchanting.

It begins with a car crash.  Everyone involved dies, except for one - a brunette in a black dress (Laura Elena Harring) that possesses looks that could kill with a perfectly timed bat of an eye lash and a shimmy of a hip.  Battered, bloodied, and bruised, she makes her way to a luxurious condo in Los Angeles, avoiding danger that she knows is around the corner.
	Betty Elms is an aspiring actress from rural Ohio.  When she arrives at LAX, there is a glimmering naiveness in her wide eyes that we can tell will surely be crushed - unless she actually is a soon-to-be-starlet.  As she is portrayed by Naomi Watts, it doesn't seem too far off.
	She plans to stay at her wealthy aunt's flat while attempting to get a job, but as soon she sets her bags down she finds a woman in the shower, that woman being the brunette in a black dress that survived the car crash.  That woman is an amnesiac, who decides that her name must be Rita after seeing the poster for the famous Rita Hayworth vehicle, "Gilda".  
	Most would throw Rita out.  But Betty is a cute blonde who wears pink sweaters, and there isn't a mean bone in her body.  The two become friends and later lovers, but it appears that Rita may be in deeper trouble than we might think.
	But then, Betty transforms into a bitter, cold woman named Diane, while Rita becomes Camilla, who takes pleasure in emotionally tormenting her girlfriend.  The previous story may not have been a mystery, but it feels like one.  We want to know what happened to Betty and Rita - yet at the same time, we can hardly wait to see what Lynch is going to give us next.
	"Mulholland Dr." etch-a-sketches its way through several seemingly unrelated events about Hollywood, and the results are poisonous, deadly, but full of sleek neo-noir attitudes.  Many of Lynch's films have been interesting to watch but cold to the touch, but "Mulholland Dr." may as well be his masterpiece.  Things are as disjointed as ever, but like his seminal TV series "Twin Peaks", there is enough mystery and enough human magnetism to draw us into a world of crime and corruption.
	There isn't a plot to speak of, only terrific performances by a game cast and individual scenes that don't come together but make a lasting impression.  Depending on Lynch's mood, there is either surrealism, hot on display, or scenes pulsing with texture that could fit into any commercial film.  
	The finest surreal piece comes from Betty and Rita's trip to a nightclub called the "Silencio", where they are given a show hosted by a supremely creepy ringmaster-y goon, starring a torch singer passionately lip syncing to song that makes Betty and Rita sob hysterically.  The finest real piece is shown through the former's audition for a role that she nails.  The scene is piping hot and full of sexual tension, but the second the casting director yells cut, we nearly forget that Betty was in an audition in the first place.
	There is a flawless balance between the crazy and the professional - Lynch is able to establish enough characterization that his moments of wildness don't feel cloying.  He never gets carried away.  You could say that the film is like a passage through a tunnel in Lynch's brain.  On one side is Edward Hopper.  On the other is Salvador Dali.
	Normally, Lynch's style overcomes his actors' performances, no matter how good; but Watts, in her breakthrough role, has never been better.  Surely, actresses are set-pieces in Lynch's films - just look at Patricia Arquette in "Lost Highway", who seemed willing to do anything, yet played two women who felt a little bit too much like comic book femme fatales.  But Watts doesn't ever seem lost in a Lynch's vision: she commands every scene she appears in.  As Betty, she glows.  Betty's hopes and dreams may be as big as her eyes, but Watts doesn't make her a one-dimensional Sandra Dee act-a-like that we want to hate.  And Diane, who is a depressive Veronica Lake post-career type, is a much more difficult role, but Watts hits it right in the kisser.  She possesses such talent that she is the only actor in "Mulholland Dr." that makes the scene all about her, not Lynch featuring her.
	Roger Ebert put it best when he said that "Mulholland Dr." is a movie you "surrender yourself to."  You can't walk in the door with a smart-alecky eye-brow arch; you have to leave your smarts and so-called intelligence at the door.  The film is a dreamy nightmare that engulfs you in its inexplicable jolts but hypnotizes you with its unpredictability.  David Lynch knows what he wants, and he gets it.

Atmospheric & intense, 'Mulholland Dr.' twists and turns on the viewer showing just what can happen when the mind & soul are distressed. Economical yet visionary, Lynch's direction (subtle) & writing (not so subtle) illuminate the hidden aspects of the human condition. Naomi Watts is excellent while the support players add much needed authenticity to Lynch's vision. Some of the sequences are especially disturbing while others are emotionally evocative and just unsettling. Frequent collaborator Angelo Badalamenti's score underlines the film's desire to keep the audience constantly on edge. Highly recommended, watch at night.

This is my favorite David Lynch film and is also one of the biggest brain teasers. Similar to lost highway, you have to figure out the structure of the film in order to begin making sense of this movie. Once you figure this out, the film is extremely interesting and has memorable scene after memorable scene with great performances and lots of twists. Though I am far from understanding this film completely, it is still an absolute blast.
in league with Bergman's Persona and Altman's 3 Women, equally haunting, mesmerizing and heart wrenching as those two great movies made by those two great directors.

It's either a brilliantly conceived stroke of perplexing masterwork, or it's an indecipherable mess with every appearance to be about something, even though it's secretly hollow. Either way, Mulholland Drive sticks with you, and forces you to think about it, no matter how maddening an experience it may be.

It failed to convince me to buy into the obsessive and compulsive journey to try and solve it!

The best I can do is admire this monument to insanity!
I'm not sure I understood it, but it was damn good!
A persons dreams  of being a better person.
Two words: Wow... and WTF. I would relish analyzing and discussing this film with anyone.

Extremely unorthodox and feverishly haunting, Mulholland Drive offers David Lynch at his very best! What we have here is a neo-noir, cynical Hollywood fantasy that is one of the most unique stories that has ever been told. One must pay attention to detail while watching, because every scene matters in this one...leading up to a finish that will leave you speechless!
Ive seen it 3 times,just i can say "great"
A maddeningly languid, somnambulant chore. Two and a half hours of anticlimax.

A great and mesmirizing narrative, mulholland drive remains a mystery too the audience, and David Lynch masterwork remains unlocked. Some might call it pretencious while others call it one of the masterpieces of our time. For me the haunting visuals and scenes make this picture truly unforgettable and contains one of the greatest scenes of all time. Great music in the background and astonishing performances.

Review In A Nutshell:

Has there anything been as intense or as thought provoking as Mulholland Drive? Only few films could surpass the ambition that this film tries to strive for, and most of those films are among the likes of Kubrick's 2001: A Space Odyssey and Bergman's Persona.

Mulholland Drive, on its surface, tells a simplistic tale about a woman who has lost her identity and gains a help from a stranger, whom then develops a close bond with and embark on a journey that would ultimately affect both of their lives. This was my perspective of the film during my first viewing, and even with that, I was highly satisfied with what was given to me. It was thrilling from start to finish, conjuring up this air of mystery that I was so desperate to solve, by the end of the film I wasn't able to crack the case as I hoped but it definitely held my curiosity and desperation long after the film has ended. It has created a mark on my mind that keeps growing and growing, and each day that I delay a revisit pushes me to the edge of insanity, constantly trying to solve it basing it only with my initial experience of the film.

I finally found time for myself to come back and visit Mulholland Drive, and this time I was determined to finally unravel Lynch's labyrinth, hoping to come out the other side understanding my experience and its purpose for existing.

Mulholland Drive is essentially a portrait of Hollywood, showing us the dark side of a place that is synonymous to fame, beauty and art. The film follows two women and their adventure takes us to the deepest and darkest parts of Hollywood, showing us the wickedness of the business and how it could break up relationships that one could easily mistake as unbreakable. Lynch doesn't hold back on his style but at the same time he ensures that his style remains relevant to the ideas and tone that he is trying to get across. The way he depicts the businessmen in Hollywood felt more real than what is actually shown in other films, and though the interactions between characters do come off as unorthodox, especially if one isn't used to the Lynch's aesthetic, it still captures the cruel and corrupt minds of these men.

The real meat of Lynch's tale is the dark journey one goes through when a fresh face enters the "land" of Hollywood, which in this case would be Betty/Diane. She is the pure example of a person who strives in the career in acting because initially for the love of the craft and to make a name for themselves in the business, but then loses their sense of innocence with the development of romantic relationships and the unjust ideals of the film business. This was an aspect of the film that was slightly blurred during my initial run through, as most of my focus was on trying to orient myself to the film's time and place and I was still taking in details of characters in order to understand each one's intentions and purpose. My theory for the film's first and second act is that Betty/Diane is dreaming of her past, her expectations, and her plans. It speaks so much about the character, and this was more obvious during my second viewing, by the end of the film we truly understand how tortured this character is. The parallels of the third act with the first two acts may not be clear at first but once you watch it understanding that it is told in Betty/Diane's perspective then the film delivers a more impacting experience.

Lynch sets the film out in a way that is definitely jarring and slightly frustrating during its first run through, but this issue is more to blame on the viewer for being impatient. The film requires multiple visits as Lynch assembles his film, especially during the film's final 25 minutes, in disorganized fragments; there were times that I felt the film's resolution was a recall to Kubrick's 2001: A Space Odyssey, providing a third act that doesn't explain itself and requires the perspective of the viewer to fuel its strength. The only way to have one's mind be aligned with the film's difficult storytelling is to provide the film the attention it deserves. One needs to constantly search for the little details in order to even remotely understand the small but significant scenes. Lynch isn't the type of guy, who would spoon-feed the film's story, and once a person is aware of this, then it is then one could gain a more satisfying experience.

Though I now consider this as one of the best films of all time, I still don't comprehensively understand it; scenes like the one that took place in Silencio is still not particularly clear to me, but I my grasp definitely got tighter as compared to my initial viewing. There is definitely an emotional and spiritual core present in these scenes that I haven't quite reached yet, and the closer I get to it, the more satisfied I become.

Peter Deming's cinematography was brilliant. He has produced a hypnotic and dreamy style that establishes the film's tone and atmosphere, and still retaining that Lynch-ian quality that sets his films apart from other filmmakers. The photography's top achievements would be the horror driven scenes which includes, the event at Silencio and the film's ending, where dark and gloomy blues just dominate the shots.

Angelo Badalamenti has worked on many of Lynch's films, and his score for Mulholland Drive is arguably his best. One can immediately indicate that the score is by Badalamenti as it contains this sense of creepiness to it that other composer have failed to achieve. Only in rare occasions do the score dominates the film, and when it does it doesn't come off forced or manipulative. Badalamenti is more concerned with creating that sense of uneasiness in the atmosphere, not knowing what could be lurking in the next corner and hyping up the horror even in the most stable and simplistic scenes.

The film's acting is carried by both Naomi Watts and Laura Harring, playing Betty/Diane and Rita respectively. Both actresses dominated the scenes they were in, shaping their characters exactly the way Lynch has expected them to and ensuring their performances heightens the film's ideas and connects with the film's style rather than displaying a sense of ego and proving to us that their acting is "natural" and "effective". Both of these actresses display strong chemistry with one another and this chemistry allows intimate scenes to bloom which immerses us in their relationship. If this connection wasn't well established, then the film would have easily fallen apart and come off as lifeless. Justin Theroux as Adam Kesher was surprisingly great in the role. I expected a wooden or shallow performance from the actor but he was able to insert some personality to the character, even if it doesn't challenge and pushes the actor's abilities to the limit.

Mulholland Drive is a masterpiece and has welcomed me to Lynch's filmography with open arms. This film was so great that it would be difficult for me to separate my feelings towards this film when reviewing the director's other films. This is definitely a film I would immediately recommend to anyone when they ask for films to watch as I personally believe that everyone needs to at least give this film a watch at least four times in their lives.

David Lynch's 'Mulholland Drive' takes a maniacal and mystical vision inside the story behind this. With a splendid directing and amazing performances, Lynch's visionary look is incredibly and totally sensational!
I'm still mulling over this film, so the score could go drastically up or down. some might say that's the mark of a great movie. Full review soon.
This shit was so fucking complex! Holy shit! I'm glad I watched it though. Worthwhile experience.
One hour of nothing surprisingly become one of the best thrill movie i`ve ever watched.

Interesting, but I like my movies to make more sense. This film was just too dreamlike without any rational logic. The visuals were fantastic and the cast was great, especially Naomi Watts. It was fun to see Ann Miller again. I like most of Lynch's films that I've seen--especially Blue Velvet and Dune (the four hour version that Lynch wanted), but this one was just too far out there for me.

Soooo. That was Mulholland Drive. Huh. It doesn't cause THAT much anger in me like Passion Of the Christ, which is a good thing. I don't have much to say about this experience that's what it is an experience. Let's try to understand what this experience is about. Betty (Naomi Watts) an aspiring actress is taking care of Rita/Camilla (Laura Elena Harring) a beautiful amnesiac who wonders to Betty's door after a car-crash. What proceeds is a neo-noir style erotic thriller of conspiracy, murder, discovery, lust and intrigue. Oh, I'm sorry that's what would happen if the David Lynch didn't hammer in this avant-garde ridiculousness.
M-A-S-T-E-R-P-I-E-C-E
Perhaps, David Lynch takes too much freedom over his cast. But the rest is bizarre, dazzling and intense within a witty structure.

Surreal crime mystery that gets weirder but not necessarily more wonderful as the overly long feature progresses.  This was intended to be a television series and you can see elements of this in the production, despite this it is well acted and offers something different to the audience than the usual mainstream features.
The only example of a film that abandons chronological order, structure, sense and taste and still comes out deeply satisfying...

Mulholland dr. is one of David Lynch's most acclaimed and widely speculated works.  It is a deliberately confusingly structured film that dives head first into a heady mix of conventional noir, hollywood satire, existentialist horror, philosophical musings,  To break down the core dual narrative of the film based on it's late game twists and character outlines would be a massive disservice to the odd, unsettling, funny, painful, ODD experience of actually watching it.  I will not touch on the plot as there is almost no plot explanation that can happen without ruining some aspect of the film.  It is comprised of two major acts (dual narrative) and a series of seemingly unrelated metaphorical scenes, and semi related surrealist scenes that comprise a very skewed and unsettling whole.  Perhaps the thing I enjoyed most about Mulholland dr. in comparison to Lost Highway or TP. Fire Walk With Me, is that Lynch never seems to take all of this too seriously, even when tugging the heart strings or delving into horror.  This film walks a dangerously fine line between hollywood meta-commentary and satire, and outright noir thriller/horror, without ever completely becoming either.  Following a couple of twists, the final act of the film becomes nearly laughably absurd, as the already confusing reality/dream/metaphor timeline becomes even more obscured in a series of nightmarish yet campy scenes.  The film ends on a note where I didn't know whether to laugh, cry, shit myself, or pretend I never saw it.  At the end of the day Mulholland Dr. works on many levels, as a surreal rollercoaster ride, as a puzzling noir, as an extended dream sequence, as a satire, yet never as a conventional narrative; if you are a viewer who values the journey more than the destination, then hop on board the crazy train.

Genuinely one of the best films I have ever seen. Trippy, seductive and enjoyable elusive, go out and buy Mulholland Drive. It is the most mainstream of Lynch's filmography - that and Dune - and features an incredibly dark and omnipresent score from Angelo Badalamenti, strong chalk-and-cheese chemistry from a refreshing Naomi Watts and femme-fatale Laura Harring and impressive cinematography. Whatever your theories are surrounding Mulholland Drive, it may be that this insidiously unforgetful film is really just an abstract piece of art, but is undeniably nonsensical in the best of ways.

But that's already what I knew David Lynch for. I knew how he would have made these films with such a surrealist style (which that does remind me quite a bit about the style of the great Spanish filmmaker Luis Buñuel), and that overall impresses me.

Full review at filmbroadcaster.weebly.com
David Lynch is a fucking master and a big wtf at the same time. Loved it
Even when you find yourself wondering what on earth is happening, David Lynch's masterful direction keeps you captivated and determined to figure out every aspect of the puzzle.
Lynch needs to make more films like this. He is truly an artist.
Quite confused with the movie at first and had to get some insight into it. After understanding it to a certain extent a little more, I thought this was a really amazing movie.
A brilliantly confusing masterpiece.

I love surrealism, let me start off by saying that. Un Chien Andalou, the paintings of Salvador Dali, and even Lynch's own Lost Highway are in my opinion some of the greatest works of art to be released. I just don't like it when it's thrown in at the last minute like in Mulholland Drive. It's an outstanding mystery film for about an hour and a half, and if it had stayed that way, then I would consider this to be one of my personal favorites and one of the most atmospheric and well-directed films ever made since 2001: A Space Odyssey. However, about ten minutes before the ending, a weird twist involving a box and what I think might be a parallel universe happens and it feels as if Lynch just got bored writing it and decided to use the ending to a different movie instead (the actors are literally playing different characters with different names and different personalities, the plot goes from a missing identity noir to a lesbian love story, and there's an incoherent mythology thrown in for the hell of it). Perhaps if I saw it again, I might see what Lynch is going for, but at this moment, it just seems lazy and incoherent.
One of best movies i watched ever.

Some of Lynch's former work made me kind of resistant of watching this.  I expected to come out of this film disappointed.  But instead I got an incredible thrilling artistic piece of cinema.  This time Lynch makes sense and every scene and trick actually matters and contributes to the film.  It has a mysterious conclusion that still has me thinking.  It's an original masterpiece.

I really wanted to like this film more which I probably would have if I understood what was happening all the way through. Iffy acting toward the beginning but the way everything is constructed once you understand is remarkable.
Nothing is what it seems. That's the lesson to take away from this one. Perhaps too open-ended and not as good as I expected, but it's still a very interesting film. 8/10

Stop, drop, and watch this ! David Lynch cobbles episodes from his cancelled TV show with newly filmed footage, and stirring up a ground-breaking masterpiece with colorful, dizzying, and mysterious editing. Mulholland Drive is one of the rare occasions where you are frozen in awe after watching a film that is beyond definition and unlike any other film ever made. Naomi Watts and Laura Harring maintain the film's mystery giving real performances that benefit from Lynch's complex writing of characters. Mulholland Drive is the first film that feels like a dream, and equally, makes you as frustrated when it ends as when an excellent dream does. If you love 50's era Hollywood,watch this film immediately! Lynch evokes the classic feel of Sunset Boulevard without making it a period piece, and contemplates on the difficulties of having a successful career in Hollywood.

I could spend the next ten years trying to figure out what everything means. While this is mildly frustrating, the intricacy and deliberateness of this movie is a true testament to David Lynch's genius.

One of the most complex and disorienting movies I've ever seen. There's no closure in the end and it's very hard to decypher the film yet impossible to dislike it. It definitely set a new standard for psychological thrillers.
I might rate Mulholland Drive higher and even call it a masterpiece ... if I actually could see what it was about.
Mulholland Drive movie create interest what next. great portrait of suspense.
I don't remember much of this film, it's been years. But I know a lot of the plot was pretty bad.

Mulholland Drive is a masterpiece and one day it will be widely rated as such. It is a perfect film, filled to the brim with ideas, it has more ideas in one scene than most films have in their entirety. Dream-like, sensual, ironic and sometimes downright funny, it's almost impossible to define. Watch it, possibly at night, in a darkened room, in silence. It will stay with you forever.

Interesting and intriguing for the most part, but nearer the end the movie grew confusing and failing to understand what was going on caused some boredom. I did enjoy picking out symbolism and deducing what actually happened later on (after I'd finished watching the movie). Lesbian sex scenes were unnecessary and put me off somewhat.

Fascinating story-telling about the crumbling and eventually paranoid world of a Hollywood actress. Many cues crisscrossed in the movie, confusing in an intriguing way. David Lynch did a great job and so did Naomi Watts.

Stands alongside 8 1/2, Sunset Blvd, Contempt, and Lynch's own next film Inland Empire as one of the best movies about movies ever made. Naomi Watts gives a towering, fearless performance as two women (or two sides of the same woman?). I don't want to spoil anything about the movie for those who haven't seen it. I will only say that Lynch fans should love it, but even Lynch detractors may find some things to appreciate here. One of the finest films Lynch ever made right here, folks.
This film just fucked my mind.

An alluring and complex dreamscape that plays out like a twisted Alice in Wonderland on acid, David Lynch is arguably the most important filmmaker of the last thirty years, and this is yet further evidence of his undeniable genius.
Although stated to be an intentional incomplete film, Mulholland Drive's jagged plot has more assets than the experimental nature the film is at it's core.
Entirely devoid of plot, David Lynch's mood driven Mulholland Dr. feels too unfinished, unrewarding, and unentertaining, despite it's slew of high end ratings.

Where do I begin with this movie? hhhmm, I would have given it a lower number of stars if not for the queer aftertaste i'm having after watching this movie. To me queer is good. If you're a fan of Kubrick, you would like this but i'm not remotely impying that Lynch is anywhere near to Kubrick's style of storytelling. Don't desperately pick up hints to decipher the movie cos you can't!! You have to drive up twice, thrice and quadruple times round Mulholland Drive to get into the right track!!
Wow, what a mind f@#k of a movie! David Lynch's 3rd masterpiece alongside Blue Velvet and Eraserhead
This film Is one of the very few films that can be described as a Masterpiece
Probably Lynch's best movie, it's surreal, dark mysterious and thrilling. One of the first masterpieces of the new millenium.
One of the weirdest movies I've ever seen.
Mulholland Drive is as confusing and unhinged as Lynch's films come, but it's also deep, intricate, poetic, and consistently intriguing
A film that requires more than one watch, but not sure if it had enough about it to warrant it.
Too surreal to be great

Mulholland Drive may not make much sense, but David Lynch directs the film so well that the atmosphere is captivating. The film is filled with dark humor, and puzzles, and subtle philosophy, and it all adds up to one enjoyable experience, and I'm not afraid to call it one of the best movies I've ever seen.
The movie would be better if it made any sense towards the end. It started out really good though The acting was great. The movie just didn't make any sense at all.
Incredible horror themed mystery movie that visually hooks you from beginning to end!

dream like nonsense with a first part that looked like weird characters trying to deliver a script that made no sence or relation. 
its the kind of movie that you must research on it to understand it and so you won't feel you just wasted your time on it.
second part was much better and kinda made sense despite the rushed ending all in all it's not a pop audience  type. 
rating 1 / 5

Americans getting shot at, to the extent that if you had a barbeque nearby the bits would land on it ready for cooking, such is the slaughter.  Dramatically filmed and acted bringing the core repulsion of blood and guts to the front of the line.  Actions taking centre stage over the words which blow mere bubbles in response.  Nibbles: Hot Vindaloo.
One of Lynchs best.  Weird and mysterious.

Confusing and exciting, Mulholland Drive is a mystery that makes the viewer work to solve this dreamlike (or is it nightmarish?) tale without ever giving a definite conclusion. As well directed and well acted as it is the real excellence of Mulholland Drive occurs after the movie as you debate with other viewers and go through the footage with a fine tooth comb on a second viewing.

this is the kind of movie that you watch over and over and each time walk away with something new. Like the world's largest onion, except there is no end. Lynch has made a thought provoking psychological thriller that gives you so much more than just a jump in your seat. An art that has been long forgotten in modern cinema.

An enigmatic, thrilling and twisted film. The story is great, it keeps you in suspense and is really engaging. The audience believes that it's following everything, until the plot has a surprising turn that may leave you very confused. This is the kind of movie that may have a lot of interpretations, just like Lynch loves to make them, and that's what makes it so intriguing. Also, the acting is excellent, the characters are interesting and the visual and sound department are stellar. Mulholland Drive is a weird movie that stays in your mind after you watch it.
An unique experience, in a good way. A marvelous film in many ways, you can be sure that it stays with you for years, including the always nagging question of what the fuck was going on?
I guarantee you won't understand it the first time around, but you'll want to watch it again to try and solve the mystery.

After many recommendations from friends to watch this film, i gave myself the chance to do it and i don't regret it at all, the film itself is like a labyrinth full of clues that actually leads you nowhere at the end of it, but it's a strange ride as it's mentioned in the film. The film is like a musical piece that goes in crescendo.

It is my first David Lynch movie. Though it brought such confusion to me at first-time watching, I thought it was brilliantly made anyway. When finally getting rid of all the questions in mind, every element in Mulholland Drive simply sticks in my head.
So very David Lynch. I miss him doing films.
This is the fucking movie
I think that was Lynch taking the piss out of Hollywood after getting only a couple of seasons out of Twin Peaks. If you don't want a linear story line, this is your movie.
It has some brilliant scenes, but as a whole it falls well short of Blue Velvet and even "lesser-Lynch" Wild at Heart.

With it's incredible use of symbolism and imagery, heartbreaking themes of love, loss and nostalgia, emotional performances and perfectly executed editing technique, Mulholland Dr. changed the way I look at film forever.

After finishing all of Twin Peaks and watching the mesmerising Twin Peaks: Fire Walk with Me, I was in desperate need of more David Lynch. And since the concept of a surreal Neo-noir sounded so original, it seemed like the ideal choice.
I can honestly say that although some of the surrealism proved a little too mesmerising for me, I did enjoy Mulholland Drive for many of the same reasons I had enjoyed Twin Peaks, mainly for its dark and glamourous atmosphere.
Although I can honestly say that I have so many questions from Mulholland Drive that I am annoyed not to have answered since I didn't connect to the characters as well as I did to the characters in Twin Peaks, and that it was a little too much of an experience in certain parts which made it difficult to remember what story aspect went in what chronologically appropriate place. And part of the is because the complicated production behind the film, since it was intended to be a TV series but ended up as a film. So Mulholland Drive has a lot of questions that it may or may not have intended to answer if it was turned into a TV series, but people who can't stand not knowing will find it to be too awkward or senseless to understand. To a certain extent I felt that, but bot enough to prevent me from enjoying the film. 
Mulholland Drive is some of David Lynch's finest work since Twin Peaks, because while the story has no guarantee of being sensible to viewers, it's what you'd have to expect from David Lynch, so fans of his will appreciate the glamourous intensity and utter darkness draped around the story in Mulholland Drive and his great directional work.
Frankly, Mulolland Drive is an example of a film that you will never understand but that you will like. If not for its surrealism, then for its excellent film style which benefits from an eerily intense atmosphere thanks to a darkly musical score, as well as haunting cinematography and grim lighting which all pay influence to the excellent visual style of the film. Mulholland Drive is an unforgettably haunting visual experience, and David Lynch proves that his talent continued on Ito the 2000's.
And Naomi Watts proves what makes her a talented actress in Mholland Drive, combining the image of her sexual innocence with her character's intellectual innocence, both of which are broken as she delves into the darkness of the Hollywood outskirts and she begins to experience the life of luxury and pleasure. She works well as a symbol of a human changing into a Hollywood person in Mulholland Drive, and combined with the surrealism of the film it assists in showing the darkness that a person becomes embalmed by when giving their lives over to materialism and pleasure. She manages to show off everything she has as an actress and as a woman, and as an Australian it gives me pride to see an Australian actress like her making such an ambitious move.
Laura Elena Herring also does a great job because she casts a strong sense of mystery over the entire film and assists in shrouding it into mystery and darkness, as well as sharing a strong chemistry with Naomi Watts which is an interesting blend of dramatic and erotic. She gives that haunting yet hypnotic presence that is common in David Lynch works, and every time she graces the screen, things instantly become mysterious, and so she works to ensure the dark exhilaration of Mulholland Drive is all in tact.
Justin Theroux also manages to make an impact, considering that even though his character doesn't get much time on screen he still manages to show off how acting stoic can also prove to be a strong form of physical acting, more specifically in his facial expressions than anything.
And lastly, Michael J. Anderson's mostly unseen presence is nostalgic and so twisted yet so great for a David Lynch film.

So Mulholland Drive is a creepy and mysterious surreal piece from David Lynch at some of his most recent best, even if it's sometimes too mesmerising for viewers.

David Lynch's magnum opus manages to be more accessible than most of his work while being just as powerful and intellectually challenging, further cementing his status as one of the all-time great auteurs.
Probably my fave Lynch experience (David Lynch films are to be experienced, not watched).
still figuring it out

My favorite Lynch.  I know it's a bit disjointed (due at least in part to its history as a failed television series), but it's my kind of weird. I just love David Lynch, and when that love meets Film Noir . . . well, it doesn't get much better.
This movie is awesome.  Check it out!

"Now you will see me one more time, if you do good. You will see me, two more times, if you do bad. Good night"

Mulholland Drive is considered by many one of the best films of the last decade (2001-09) and among David Lynch's best work. There is no denying that Lynch is one of today's most revered directors, but this is actually the first film of his that I've been able to see. Unfortunately I wasn't able to enjoy this movie as much as everyone else did and I'm ashamed to admit that Lynch is way to smart for me. While watching this film I felt that there were several scenes that didn't make much sense and that the director was just being pretentious showing his craft and great skills, but after reading the Hulk's critique of this film explaining every single detail in the movie I have to admit that Lynch was a genius and I just didn't get the movie in the same way others did. Looking back I realize that every scene has a meaning and the film is rich in symbolism and semiotics. Despite paying attention to the film I missed very important things that I can now see were really thought out by Lynch. I feel ashamed because I wasn't able to grasp the film in the same way Lynch would have wanted me to and I felt everything was pointless. The performances in this film are really great but I was never drawn into the film in the same way others were. I guess I'm not someone who cares too much about dreams or puts too much thought into them and their underlying meanings. What I did enjoy about this film were the satirical elements introduced by Lynch about the film industry in Hollywood. The characters were really well developed and the mood of the film is suspenseful at times. I also enjoyed the score of the film and thought it really added to the overall eeriness of Mulholland Drive. I might enjoy this film more if I watch it again now that I have understood most of the underlying meanings and symbolisms here, but I just can't gather myself to watch it again because I was never absorbed by the story and found everything rather dull.

Betty (Naomi Watts) is a young aspiring actress who has just arrived at Hollywood from a small Canadian town. Her aunt, a successful actress herself, has allowed her to stay at her home while she is off shooting a movie. When Betty arrives at her apartment she is surprised to find out that there is a young woman already there. This beautiful brunette is suffering from amnesia after surviving a terrible car accident right before she was about to get murdered and has decided to hide in the apartment after seeing Betty's aunt leave. She thinks her name is Rita (Laura Harring), but she can't remember anything else. Betty decides to help her and allows her to stay with her. In the meantime there are a few other stories taking place. On the one hand we have a director (Justin Theroux) who is looking for a lead actress to replace the one that has disappeared. The producers want to force him to choose Camila Rhodes (Melissa George), but he refuses. There are also a series of detectives (Robert Forster and Brent Briscoe) trying to solve a murder, and a hit man (Joe Messing) who is a little inept at his job. All these stories seem to overlap each other as everything is connected, but at the same time not everything is what it seems as the line between dreams and reality is a very thin one.

I love films that aren't told in chronological order like this, but I had trouble here putting all the pieces together. Now that I was able to understand it all I can see how brilliant Lynch was using all these different imageries. This is a film about transferring guilt and romanticizing love in an otherwise cruel and dark world. Lynch is always in control of his craft here, but he was way ahead of me and truly lost me. Naomi Watts had a breakout performance here, and she is now one of Hollywood's best known actresses, but this will be the role many will remember her for. Laura Harring is also great here as the needy and vulnerable character that Betty wants her (or fantasizes her) to be. Mulholland Dr. is a very complex and thrilling mystery that begins to make sense long after you've seen it. Is succeeds in the fact that the images stay with you and haunt you, but I really didn't have a pleasurable experience watching it. This is a very ambiguous film and Lynch has written a fabulous screenplay, but one that I wasn't prepared for. This is a very dark film that plays out as a contemporary film noir. Lynch was nominated as best director for his work here, but surprisingly it didn't receive any other nomination in 2001. The film has garnered cult status over the years and I understand why. I'm a little disappointed with myself for not enjoying this as much as I should have.

Rating: 5.9/10

"Now you will see me one more time, if you do good. You will see me, two more times, if you do bad. Good night"

1 for the history book.

Usually I would be frustrated by films that don't explain everything by the end but this is an exception. The fact that things are still open to interpretation is, in this case, a bonus element which means that the film continues after the final credits in the form of debate. I think I've got it sussed but I can never be sure and would still welcome alternative theories. It's possibly David Lynch's best work, made in his unmistakeable style with lots of quirks.
Watch it, wait two days, then watch it again

Hollyweird at its best. This movie started out with so much potential and then eventually became incomprehensible. Was a good thriller up to a point. The violence with comical twists reminded me of Pulp Fiction. Naomi was very good, no doubt about that. Got a kick out of seeing Chad Everett again, thought he was long gone to a nursing home. Good to see Ann Miller again too. Many scenes were very artistic and riveting, while just downright creepy at the same time.

The Emperor's New Clothes for film - If you like it - I know you're either lying or a douchebag. There is no real story. Seriously - to remake this movie, shoot 15 scenes with a really good crew/ production designer/ cinematographer, get a whole bunch of film students to make 3 minute shorts (These cannot stick to a common theme) and then let a couple of 9 year old's (whom can never speak to each other) do the editing after you've scrambled the scenes around. Oh. And don't forget the lesbian sex. Lot's and lot's of lesbian sex...

The movie shouldn't make the audiences confused and can't understand the idea behind

David Lynch is unconventional filmmaker, and people agree to put him in categories like "dark", "oddball" or even "ultraweird".  This surrealist neo-noir movie, written and directed by David Lynch is again following the style which will fit in these categories. Perfect cast for such a movie: Justin Theroux, Naomi Watts, and Laura Harring, fits well and has the right chemistry. In juxtaposition of cliché and surreal, nightmares and fantasies, the director is telling us, in nonlinear story lines, a story of an aspiring actress named Betty Elms, newly arrived in Los Angeles, California, who meets and befriends an amnesiac hiding in an apartment that belongs to Elms's aunt, famous retired actress. 

I really thought that almost everything in the first two thirds was close to perfect: camera work, sound and lighting, music, the movie even challenged me to suspend belief of what I am experiencing... until the last part where everything was blown away for me!  I know, you'll say, this is David Lynch, he does things his own way, but really reminded me on my grandma's little story when she wanted to say that someone staffed up the things... she used to compare those people to a cow which gives you 30 litres of milk a day, but at the end kicks the container and spills everything on the ground! That's how I felt David Lynch did it with this movie!  I was enjoying the "milking" (the building of the suspense and story- telling were simply amazing) but at the end I felt thirsty for a solid ending instead of the mambo-jumbo wanking. 

Lynch is surrealists, and his language of the unexplained is the fluid language of dreams... but there was no sense at the end. When Lynch declined to offer an explanation of his intentions for the narrative, I really think that he had no explanation, because he himself had no idea how to finish it effectively and at the end he choose to hide under the "art" umbrella. Just my opinion...

I enjoyed the work of David Lynch but at the end I felt like cheated, someone described it as "pulling the rug out from under us".
It's definitely weird as hell and makes almost zero sense, but it's also beautiful and mesmerizing. It's like one awesome dream.
"Mulholland Drive" is all dream.

Second time to watch Mulholland Dr. , and it really gave me a lasting impression on the interpretation on dreams. However, more clues and relationship should be revealed explicitly for a general audience as me.
Like Lynch's other films, Mulholland Drive is incredibly bizarre, but it is still a peculiar thriller, one that is strange enough to keep you watching and wondering until the end.
You know films where you don't see the twist coming and when it comes you think it pooped all over what the story was building up to.......? well.....this is one of them.

2 hrs 24 mins of the movie and a complete day of follow up reading of the crazy theories and then a re-watch, a study, to be exact, and then you begin to realize how awe-fckin-some David Lynch really is

Many won't like the fact that they can't make sense of this movie, but no one will deny the effective atmosphere that director/writer David Lynch is so good at creating. A true masterpiece in every way. Mulholland Drive makes the audience decide what they think happened rather than being handed an obvious conclusion. Naomi Watts delivers the greatest female performance in film history and Mulholland Drive ranks among the top 3 movies in history

From one of the most original American filmmakers comes an original movie that gives us an unsettlingly stunning insight on an artist's personal vision. A mystery set in Hollywood, more diffictult to explain on paper perhaps because it still exists as an abstract idea open to interpretation, with its glossy outlook and a darker inside, hysterical, macabre and overall strange story taking place in a sun filled setting. It is a treat which may be demanding for some, but anyone willing to let the filmmaker carry them will find the journey worthwhile.

David Lynch is not in the business of making everyday movies that spell out what is happening for the audience.  No, he has to make you think and be uncomfortable while doing so.  Nothing big is happening in this movie yet I was entertained throughout the two and a half hour running time.  Lynch's and Watt's greatness are on full display in this one.  Mulholland Drive is easily one of the best, most intriguing movies of the 21st century.

My favorite David Lynch film. An endlessly fascinating movie with a large variety of memorable scenes. Strong performances and a creepy atmosphere help give it a surreal mood. I couldn't stop thinking about it afterwards and initial frustrations were gone after careful reflection upon what happened during the film. This is a must-see.
Lynch's strongest.  Mulholland Drive's mysteries will entice.  Watts' performance is extraordinary and absolute.
Wild stuff right here.  Not for all tastes.
Interesting in more ways than one.
What the shit just happened to my brain?

I must warn you, if you have never seen a David Lynch film before, proceed with caution. I find that this film scares you for the sake of thrill, there is no direction with it. Mulholland Drive is an engrossing experience that while missing it's original intention is a still worth watching. The film was originally intended to be the pilot for a TV series that was not picked up. Eventually Lynch was payed by a french film studio to finish the story, so he slapped an ending onto the film and pushed it into theaters. As a film Mulholland Drive is a good experience, I only wish the plot could have been doled out at the lengthened pace that david Lynch originally intended.

This movie will never get old to me.

This blue box lacks a bow.
	Yes, my Proverbial Audience, if you watch Mulholland Drive, expect no packaged narratives.
	It's been an hour, and the thought wheels are still rolling on this one, which is always a good sign.
	There's only one question to ask.
	Are you willing to take the half hour afterward to find out what you saw?
	If the answer's no, rethink this one.
	That being said, there are probably fans out there who've never looked into interpretations of the plot. I couldn't live with myself, but there must be.
	I'm alluding to the disjointed narrative woven through David Lynch's writing and directing. His use of different shooting styles and camera angles is pretty amazing.
	For some reason it has a very 90's feel to it, despite its theatrical release in 2001.
	The film runs a little too long and is thoroughly confusing. It's not 'intentional obfuscation for the sole purpose of confusing the audience.' That's misleading, and I don't think it happens all that often.
	For years, I would have argued the pointlessness in the ending of Kubrick's 2001: A Space Odyssey. I still contend that it's an overall bore, and the dull slog is not worth the thoughtful and rather brilliant implications of the ending. It's perplexing as all get out, but now that I've read about what Stanley was going for, I can appreciate the virtue of his intent.
	Although I'm not a big fan of Blue Velvet, I appreciate what Lynch tries to do in his movies. 
	Even after understanding the common interpretations of the plot, there still remains a feeling like something's missing. It's very similar to how I felt after Blue Velvet, but my preference lies with Mulholland Drive.
	MD was originally conceived as a television show, and this is where much of the plot falls apart. Lynch had to compact a narrative intended for an entire season into a feature film. Many question whether the final film can be classified as a complete narrative.
	I wish I could answer that question. I'm not sure and have done too much research already. Perhaps I'll get back on that some day.
	I had to have the answer, and felt satisfied by it. I'm not necessarily ecstatic about the explanation but it works, and it's fine; an original idea at the very least. I found the plot development compelling regardless.
	Hey, I got a thing for elaborate high-stakes storytelling. I find it thought provoking and puzzling. I enjoy the whirlwind of disjointed moments, the coil and release of the tension spring.
	I adore the chase for comprehension, the errant cuts, the inexplicable in the real, the terror and indecision. Keeping the viewer on the edge of their seat certainly counts for something.
	Mulholland, I find, is reminiscent of Robert Altman's Short Cuts from 1993. Except not nearly as boring.
	It gives off a bit of a Pulp Fiction vibe (particularly in terms of the disjointed narrative). 
	I'm also reminded of Sharon Stone's character in Basic Instinct with Laura Harring's role as Rita. They're both portraits of the typical femme fatale who sexually prey on their victims.
	Naomi Watts is great in MD; she's playing a difficult role here and executes it convincingly. Really, I mean, this is some tough stuff!
	Overall, I enjoy Mulholland Drive. It's ghostly, ethereal and compelling. The material's gritty and tense, but befuddling.
	Despite the incomplete narrative, Lynch offers his audience a thought provoking experience unlike any other.
	Nonetheless, the story is mysterious and enticing, and if you like movies it's worth a shot.
	I'm finishing this review the following morning, and still thinking about it.
	What does that say about the film as a whole?
