Lynch's darkly noir juxtaposition of archetypes and nonlinear storytelling compels, captivates, but never satisfies. The director's choice to maintain the film as heavily interpretable apparently juices some film critics, but not this one. Even conceding that the painfully sonorous performances during the first third of the movie are purposely contrived (at least, one would hope so; if that is not the case, they simply become embarrassingly neophyte), Lynch's impenetrable narrative includes countless vignettes. Intrinsically poor they are not, but while they add colorful neo-noir visuals they hardly add up to more than the sum of their parts. It's interesting and experimental, but also frustratingly vague and not nearly as erotic as it wants to be. Furthermore, the perpetual avant-garde symbolism isn't titillating so much as tiring. It's a bit of a disappointment.
You're lying to yourself if you understand this film after the first viewing.

Worse than I remembered from the first time I saw it, though perhaps only because I vaguely remembered what I was letting myself in for.  Yet another of those films constructed on the principle that an absence of apparent meaning must be just as good as the presence of deep meaning...

Incredibly convoluted drama in which several lives are examined in the grungy Hollywood. A woman (Laura Harring) who is nearly murdered by several thugs in her luxurious vehicle until gets involved in a head-on crash in the hills. She stumbles away as her near-assailants either are killed or injured (not that clear) in the wreck and she loses all memory, including the knowledge of her own name. She meets an aspiring actress (Naomi Watts) who tries to help her find her origination, which leads them down a strange and dark path. The other story concerns a director's life (Justin Theroux) who is blackmailed into accepting the application of unknown actress or facing the alternative of getting into deep trouble. Another small plotline also concerns a hit man (Mark Pellegrino), the one behind the near killing of the amnesiac woman, who commits three acts of murder, which includes two innocent bystanders, and then just disappears. Such a weird story warrants a definite viewing from all viewers who like strange mysteries with REALLY disjointed narrations. Well-acted and includes a pretty memorable lesbian love scene. A little too hard to follow at times, but is never boring and is always interesting.
Another excellent film by Lynch. Worth watching 'for' the end, not everything leading up to it.

This is a near perfect film. In my mind the perfect film is a film that has philosophical meaning and metaphors behind it, but they are not needed to enjoy the film. A perfect film anyone can watch even if they don't understand the hidden meaning behind it. This film almost achieves this. I will state that the first three quarters of this film are some of the greatest film making I have seen of all time. The story is fantastic, if a bit confusing at times, the acting is spectacular, you really want to see what happens to these characters and you are interested in what they pay off might be. But then the last quarter of the film happens. Suddenly the last quarter happens and everything I stated earlier gets thrown out the window and every metaphor and artistic expression David Lynch was holding back was thrown into the quarter, making the film so confusing that it was incredible hard deciphering what was happening, who was who, what was reality. Even once the film had ended I thought I had an idea of what happened in the ending, but I still wasn't one hundred percent sure because of other things in the film. Upon finishing the film and thinking the film over I had to read around three different thesis papers on what actually happened in the film, to which I found out that I was somewhat right. And I say somewhat because there are some parts in the film that other people just have no clue what it ment, such as the blue box. Upon finding out what the ending really ment I really, really, really liked this film. The ending is amazing if you understand it. But that is the films biggest problem, this film came out in 2001, when the internet was still blooming as a flower and I can't imagine finding these papers online back then. If I was not able to figure out the film's ending, I think I would have liked this film a lot less. So it is really a 50/50 review. If you can understand the ending, or are going to take time out of your way to figure out the ending later, you will love this film. If you can't figure it out you will most likely not enjoy this film because it is impossible to make sense of the ending without trying to figure it out.
If you're in the mood for a movie that makes sense and offers any sense of closure, then pick something else.

The first half may be one-dimensional and linear but the second half goes beyond two or three dimensions and becomes a trademark mindscrew of David Lynch. And as for the second half containing anything linear? Heck no.

(Spoilers ahead) 

Words cannot do justice as to what I think about this film. It is like a puzzle that you can distinguish that all the pieces somehow fits together, but once put together, it still remains a mystery. There is more symbolism as opposed to a concrete meaning. This is a cerebral film that requires the viewer to be analytical, yet at the same time be open to many interpretations.

That is the beauty of this film. This is art and while the film is really good, I'm still left pondering. I could imagine every viewer will arrive at a different interpretation and I feel David Lynch's intention while making this film was to encourage people to come up with their own explanations. This film is bound to leave one very puzzled upon their first viewing, but upon further analyzation, there is a symbolic relationship that ties everything together. If you are still lost, I think the key thing to pay attention to is the cowboy. For some reason, that really helped me a lot in finding some sort of logical explanation for the events that occur in the film.

While I really do not know if there is a moral presented (or a point), to me, this film represents the demons that people have in the back of their minds. It's the elephant in the room that people don't want to confront or how one becomes in denial of its existence and how there is a good way to do that, as well as a bad way, but either way it has to be confronted. That to me seems to be what this film spoke about. Coupled with a foreboding atmosphere and odd imagery, this is a disturbing piece of high quality cinema that is shrouded with an aura of mystery bound to leave an imprint on one's psyche. I would definitely watch this again not just to learn more about the world created in this film, but to also be immersed in it again. 5/5
I wish this movie made more sense.  It had the makings of a truly good movie if it only didn't leave me feeling so lost.
I've only seen it once but it continues to haunt me. This film blew my mind! Lynch didn't break film barriers he took it into a another dimension. I can't wait to give it another spin.

Though stock-full of Lynch's trademark self-conscious weirdo pretentiousness, this is obviously a very high-quality, well-acted piece of work. I defy anyone watching (at least up until they 'open the box') to not come to the same conclusion.

In my review of Lynch's previous "Blue Velvet," my frequent complaint was that while I considered the film a rewarding experience; Lynch's continual interplay between the levels of the artificial and the morbid undercurrents of what looms beneath situated his film, thematically, as being too obvious. Lynch's film was utterly compelling when he entered his internal surrealistic landscape - and by returning to the surface the film ultimately lost its momentum. However, Lynch successfully rectifies such problems with his surrealistic masterpiece "Mulholland Drive." A film that takes us into Lynch's realm of a L.A nightmarish landscape; and rather than continually giving the audiences room to exhale by traveling back to the surface of a normal reality; Lynch just keeps digging until, as an audience, we are stranded in an accumulation of surrealistic imagery with nowhere to go. As with a film that contains such ambiguity; there have been many hypothesis' created to explain its logic - but do films always need a sense of logic? If "Mulholland Drive" contained all the answers, would the experience be better? Would've you and your friends been left in such a bewildering, confused state that you spent the next three days trying to make sense of what you just seen if the answers were viable? The answer is: No. For that sole reason, Lynch's efforts are amazing. To watch such a film you must leave logic at the door and simply immerse yourself in the mesmerizing imagery and music to be treated by an experience like no other.  

The story follows as so: A woman is involved in a car wreck. Seemingly delusional, she finds solace within the help of a hopeful Hollywood uprising star as they embark on journey for answers that takes them through the realms of reality/dreams and memories.

Lynch riddles his latest efforts with morbid visuals and humor that revolves around a number of core characters (if they actually exist or not it's difficult to tell). Obviously there is Betty (Watts), the protagonist, who has hopes in becoming the next Hollywood hopeful. Funny enough; Lynch characterizes Betty with peculiar characteristics: she inhabits wooden dialogue that resembles soap-opera principles and evokes the traits of the Hitchcock heroine. Then there's Rita (Harring), a woman who suffers amnesia from her car accident and seems to be constantly transfixed within a delusional/emotional state. Lynch portrays their relationship in an eroticism fashion of two seemingly obsessive persona's to the point where it's difficult to tell whether their relations actual exists or is simply a protection of Watts subconscious. In fact, this train-of-thought fits for many characters: the Cowboy (Montgomery), the director (Theroux), Coco (Miller) and Camilla (George) all seem to have a purpose - and while I do consider to have an answer to their inclusions, an answer would be superfluous due to the fact that the film is simply too ambiguous. Speaking of characters, Naomi Watts performance is simply amazing to watch with the transition of the two separate spheres within dreams and reality. She effortlessly portrays the soap-operish conventions for two-quarters of the film, and then dramatically/disturbingly switches to the emotional wreck that has lost her innocence (wink, wink).

Likewise to "Blue Velvet," it's quite astonishing just how much tension Lynch is able to create, as sense of dread looms around each corner of Hollywood's nightmarish landscape. With the brilliant use of continues POV shots, Lynch is able to create tension within the most subtle moments. Such an atmosphere lends to Lynch's commentary of the modern Hollywood climate: a world that has portrayed its initial values and has cemented individuals with limited autonomy. It sorta works as warped 'Sunset Boulevard."

However, the most impressive aspect of Lynch's latest efforts is that he portrays -quite possibly the most difficult aspect within all art aesthetics- the subconscious thoughts within the viewer's awareness. Similar to the likes of Bergman and William Faulkner's literature masterpiece "The Sound and Fury," Lynch displays macabre internal thoughts through a visual medium; beautifully displayed through the final forty minutes sequence; a sequence that cements a moment that Lynch's whole career has been moving towards. In relation to my previous statement, "Mulholland Drive" final segments accumulates a sense of surrealism and macabre visuals that simply hypnotizes you within a sequence that resembles the characteristics of a nightmare; and if you are willing to surrender yourself to such sequences, you'll be treated to a transcendent experience like no other.

**** out of ****

After one has seen David Lynch's "Mulholland Drive", the word "Silencio" has become one of the most haunting words in cinema since those spoken by Marlon Brando ("The horror...the horror") in "Apocalypse Now". It might be an irrelevant comparison overall, but both are films that linger in the corners of our minds. Both are less than conventional even if Lynch exists more on his own terms than Francis Ford Coppola ever did (although he is a fine filmmaker; his films can be enjoyed by pretty much all audiences with an attention span). He continues to surprise me as an artist; his films may all contain similar traits, but not one of them is truly "similar" to another. Lynch has enough feelings and images inside of him to inspire a respectable filmography; and so they have.

A black car drives along a winding highway not too far from Los Angeles carrying a mysterious yet beautiful dark-haired woman (Laura Harring). The driver pulls a gun on her and orders her to step out of the car. She seems confused to just what is going on, although it's not until some kids crash into their vehicle with their own and leave everyone but her for dead that we realize how normal things were before. She, still unnamed, walks into the darkness and finds her way to the city. She rests up at a random house. The next day, she is discovered while showering by the occupant of the apartment that she has stumbled to. That person is Betty (Naomi Watts), the daughter of an actress (who owns the apartment but is away on business) who aspires to follow in her mother's footsteps.

The black-haired woman, who identifies herself as Rita after seeing a poster for Hayworth's "Gilda" hanging in the bathroom, is an amnesiac. She can't remember who she really is. She and Betty look for clues in her purse but find only a blue key and a shit-load of money. They hide both of these things in a container that rests in the closet. The two are then engaged in a sort of relationship that keeps getting weirder and weirder; in part because it's so often interrupted by what seem like little vignettes in between, one involving a Hollywood director (Justin Theroux) and his partnership with a pair of mobster brothers (one of whom cannot be pleased by a cup of espresso) who apparently own the next movie he's making, insisting that he cast a woman named Camilla Rhodes.

For the most part, the film balances these two stories; although there are even smaller ones that fit themselves in there somehow as well. For instance, there's an early scene set at the diner called Winkies in which a young man describes to his older colleague a dream that he had involving a frightening man in the back of the diner, which becomes a sort of nightmarish reality by the end of the scene. And then there's a sub-plot involving an amateur hitman who may or may not have ties to the car crash at the beginning of the film. And then there's the Cowboy. It's confusing even for a David Lynch film but better because of it. The labyrinth-like structure of the narrative, which I assure you forms a coherent whole by the end but only if you pay attention and watch it more than once, is appealing to me.

Certain plot details are vital to how you interpret "Mulholland Drive". As usual, Lynch encourages each individual viewer to think for themselves; thus interpretation is key to the enjoyment of the film. Betty and Rita get tangled up in a romantic, sexual relationship somewhere within the last hour; and this is one element that plays a significant role in how I view the film. There's a common theory floating around that Rita is some sort of dream projection of the sort of person Betty would like to be, and that the film itself is all a dream. By the time it was over on my second viewing, I knew that was the theory I'd adopt. I also view it as a satire of this generation's cerebral dreams of fame and fortune; the Betty character is all that materialized into one silly blonde. Watts' performance is uncanny and over-the-top; although in the last act, surprisingly intense as well.

For someone to truly hate the film, I think it would either take too much thought or too little. I didn't allow myself to think too much into "Mulholland Drive" since I'd seen Lynch films before, and so I knew that you simply can't understand everything he puts on screen. You just have to kind of go with it, which is easy for me to do when a director is so passionately emotive and gifted in setting up an atmosphere with unforgettable imagery. "Mulholland Drive" has so much of that. Take, for instance, the employer of the mobster brothers who sits in a wheelchair in a dark room illuminated only by a single light (which shines on him) and talks through a microphone that connects to the inside of a glass cage of sorts, where the employees can speak to him through. And then there's the Rebekah Del Rio scene, which is just sublime. Finally, you've got a superb Angelo Badalamenti score to complete the ambience.

I love David Lynch's technique because he makes films so unconventional, surreal, and beautiful that they cannot be summarized as easily as most films. Is "Mulholland Drive" a mystery? Perhaps, we don't know for sure. Like everything else in the picture, it all depends on how you're seeing it. Either way, Lynch puts YOU in the role of detective and to me, that's more fun than anything else. His images and emotions are so resonant that the viewer - depending on what kind you are - has no problem with what Lynch is asking us to do. This is clearly one of his most multi-dimensional and personal films; a stunning evocation of present day LA and the different vibes that Lynch got, and still gets, from the place that he calls home. If its goal is to be chaotic, destructive, dream-like, disturbing, funny, and ultimately mind-boggling; then it's done the city justice.

Strange and suspenseful, it is at heart the story of one's demons and the pain of not having the person one loves. But of course you wouldn't piece that little madness together until the end... maybe. Lynch takes the viewer through one hell of a ride, only to leave more questions unanswered than answered as the film gets more and more surreal. This might take a few viewing to grasp.

Original 2012 Review:

From what I've gathered thus far, this is a director's heightened, darkened, paranoid Hollywood memoir.  Everything about this film is from the point of view of a Hollywood director who is saying something about artists working for 'the man,' the envy and desperation they're forced into, the mold that they have to cut pieces of themselves away to fit into.  Diane (or Betty, however you choose to look at it) begins her journey to Hell in the prologue (this is all very similar to my own Death Odyssey), her life fading into an ugly trip that will eventually have her chipping away more than a few parts of herself to fit into a mold; her extreme desperation, coming from the slums of life, can only forsee splattering a boldfaced message on that mold, exhausted from the routines she's forced upon herself, and that have been forced upon her.  

Ironically, this basis for a story is told amidst a framework antithetical to the consumer demand movie 'the man' would have you molding for, so we get to explore two extreme contrasts told within each other.  We get this indirect sense of Lynch's conspiratorial paranoia when we see 'the man' speaking from the control room, delivering orders from the top of a heirarchy.  We know nothing more of 'who' they are than Lynch himself, other than that we know these rooms and these people exist in some fashion, and they control our lives.

The film works because it's "hypnotic" (as Roger Ebert put it), but it's over-the-top in trying to be clever, and I believe most audiences will just feel too far removed, as even I did for the most part.  There's more than just an impression Lynch is making, and that's where he should've stopped himself, because the structure of the script acts as though it encodes some greater meaning that the audience can't access as much as they would if this structure was ignored.  It would've been more interesting to not loop the structure and return to scenarios from different angles, but rather continue moving forth with the same impressions in a spiral journey. abstract linear form.

Very impressed to see this one on the top 30 of the S&S critics' poll. So, what can I say about this movie? It's the greatest movie of the 21st Century as of right now. i just don't give this one a 5-star because it's too early, but soon it will be one part of the elite. People who think that Nolan brought complexity to the mainstream that's completely wrong, comparing Nolan to Lynch is like comparing Rowlings to Orwell. So I don't understand how come all Nolan's movies are on the top 250 on IMDB. Anyway, Mulholland Dr. is a masterpiece made by a genious who is sure about his rising potential, even with 60 years-old. He is the definition of art: he only does a movie when he finds a perfect idea, and that's why he hasn't made a movie since Inland Empire, he admited the lack of inspiration, that's a real artist, he doesn't make movies just to top box offices. And the result on this one is beyond perfect, I mean, everything about it it's special: the acting is superb; the cinematography is always a strong point on Lynch's career; the script and plot are both one of the greatest of all times. It's confusing, and everytime you see it you got to have a different opinion about it, if you don't the movie will mean nothing to you. The movie adjusts to your state of mind. Of course that there is a lot of nonsense imagery and symbolic objects, but that's part of the fun of watching Lynch, Bunuel, Jodorowski, Maya Deren, Chris Marker and all the surrealists the world has produced. A movie that sooner or later will be on the top 10 of S&S, just wait another 10 or 20 years.

It's gotten nearly impossible to tell if David Lynch films are artistic or just trying to be weird. I think this film was a bit of both, but overall I enjoyed it greatly. Most critics seemed to revile the film, which was originally shot as a TV pilot that was never picked up  and was then reshot to make it into a feature. That fact probably accounts for a lot of elements that never seem to go anywhere, like the mysterious "cowboy", the dwarf in the curtained room or the very fast appearance by Robert Forester. There's also parts that seem to be done only for style or off beat humor, rather than belonging to the greater whole of the film. However, despite all this, if you simply let the film was over you and take it in as a hallucinatory experience about Hollywood, it's a lot of fun and probably the best thing Lynch has done sine his "Blue Velvet" "Twin Peaks" days. And it's easy to say it now, but I do remember seeing this in the theater and being impressed with Naomi Watts, who this was her first major film role, and is terrific in the film.

When I look back at the movie, I think, how did I not realize that this was a dream? It really made no sense. A magical hobo that scares a guy to death? A car traveling at 100 miles per hour doesn't kill the girl in the back seat? Or the completely clumsy assassin? I didn't even realize it when they were at the play and the guy was saying "This has all been fake". And I think that's what makes a great movie. One that makes you feel vulnerable and utterly confused, but somehow satisfied at how you were tricked. The story was really interesting. How she pieced together parts of her day into her dream, it was pretty genius storytelling. The acting was great too, but lets just say that I am a part of the Lynch fan club now.

Well, I don't know if it's as good as previous Lynch films like Eraserhead, but it does have an interesting plot that for 3/4 of the film ACTUALLY makes sense. (unlike most other Lynch films) But after 3/4, things go all Lynchian and stop making sense, but not in an interesting way like Eraserhead. It's kind of like Lynch is on autopilot for the last part. Like suddenly he just said to himself, 
"Oh I forgot, time to stick on a surrealist ending!" It's just nonsensical, but unlike other Lynch films, not really in a good way.

What I'm trying to say is, the ending is a very generic "Lynch ending." Aside from the ending though, I did quite like the rest of the film, though I couldn't help but laugh when the Cowboy showed up with his eyebrow-less face, and when the woman was crying profusely, and then suddenly the camera pans down and reveals she's been masturbating all along.

In short, it's a good film, but not as good as other Lynch films. See Blue Velvet to get a better ending for a Lynch plot and Erasrerhead for an all out surrealist dreamscape.

This isnt a review so much as a theory about the movie. So big time SPOILER ALERT.



The Theory:

Betty(Diane) and Rita(Camilla) are dead when the movie starts. They are in some dream like, afterlife that is created, at least mostly created, my Diane's subconscious. Camilla's soul is drawn into this world by her guilt and by the power of Diane's desire. Its possible that, since their deaths, a similar series of events have played out a number of times before. Camilla is basically Diane's prisoner in this dream world.

Camilla's amnesia is probably part of Diane's desire to have Camilla dependent on her and to have power over her identity. The false identities of Betty and Rita are probably in place because Diane kind of hates Diane and Camilla, and wants the two of them to be somewhat different people. Remember the line Betty(Diane) rehearses with Rita(Camilla): "I hate us both!"

At Club Silencio the pair are given a big clue to the true nature of their world. In the club they discover a blue box that fits Camilla's blue key. After leaving the club they rush home to open the box. At this point Diane checks out, she goes back to "that sleep of death", she is not ready to face the truth. Camilla opens the box and learns the truth.

After the opening of the box we, and probably Camilla as well, see what really happened before Diane and Camilla died. This second part of the movie does not show events in chronological order. What happened, in chronological order, was Diane and Camilla met in Hollywood and began a love affair. Diane fell head over heels in love, but Camilla soon lost interest in a monogamous relationship with Diane. Camilla fell for Adam, the director she was working with. Camilla was probably having sex with one or more women as well because she is seen kissing another woman.

Diane took the break up very badly. She was already emotionally unstable, and that dinner party Camilla dragged her too pushed her over the line. Diane hired a hit man to kill Camilla. After the murder Diane couldnt live with herself. She lost her mind and killed herself.

After that I suspect its back to the airport for Diane, where she arrives in Hollywood, and back to Mulholland Drive for Camilla, where she loses her memory, and the scenario starts again. Perhaps these two will have to live out this drama again and again until Diane opens the box and learns the truth.
I think the old, blue haired woman sitting in the balcony of Club Silencio is a version of Camilla, a version who knows the truth. She sits in the balcony and watches these events play out. Perhaps she has already seen it several times. Im not sure how much of Camilla's behavior in life was due to sadism and how much was due to foolishness. But I do think Camilla's guilt is what makes it possible for Diane to hold her soul prisoner.


Characters and Loose Ends:

I believe characters like the Cowboy, the Castigliani Brothers, and the dwarf represent other worldly forces who are behind the scenes, pulling strings in the dream-afterlife-world. What I dont know is whether they are parts of Diane's subconscious or if they are something else. I cant figure out their nature because I cant figure out what they are trying to accomplish. Are they trying to rescue Camilla from Diane? Are they trying to keep the phantom world running in accord with Diane's desires? Or are they trying to do something else?

I think most or all of the other people in the first part of the movie are phantoms created by Diane's subconscious. One possible exception is Adam. Perhaps he was killed when Camilla was killed. Alternatively, since Diane found him intimidating in life, perhaps the phantom Adam created by her mind is powerful enough to challenge order of her world, at least until the other worldly powers put great pressure on him. Also there were a few other people in the audience at Club Silencio, maybe they are also ghosts living in that phantom Hollywood.

This is a really good movie. While most may not like how the movie doesn't quite explain anything, the movie is a visual work of art. The mind starts to bend while it will try to comprehend what is going on but for the most part, that is its purpose. The story is done very well. The acting is pretty good but Lynch allows the camera work to really tell the story. Definitely worth the rent.
Great in almost everything besides a few ineffectively bizarre visual choices (manly those awful brights fades and super-imposed frames).
Once you get to the end of the film and you recall the very first moments, the story becomes clear. It's a good statement about fame. It focuses on Hollywood.
I am still figuring it out....

A maddeningly brilliant nightmare that takes forever to decipher, even though some of the film's beauty comes from how complex it is. I know very few living directors who could create a scene as terrifying as the scene at Winkie's. Watts is superb, as is Harring, and after you watch the film, you won't be able to get it out of your head.

It was hard.
But in the end the script is INCREDIBLY WELL WRITTEN.
Lynch style at his best.

It's too tedious to try and figure out what everything means, but it kinda makes sense if you convince yourself it does. Regardless of the typical Lynchian confusion, the movie looks spectacular and is quite haunting and sexy.
Very weird movie. Typical David Lynch scenario with great performance. You have to let your imagination drive you in this one.

HATE. (Btw the first word in my Social Network review is "LOVE".) Oh here, I bet you want a quote. How's this? "If that damn dog craps in the courtyard one more time, I'm just gonna bake his little butt for breakfast!" Sorry, that's not a good quote. Sorry, it's not a good movie. This is gonna be one helluva rant. Now that I've seen it, I can finally add David Lynch and Mulholland Drive to my Bottom 10 directors/movies list...if I had one. This was beyond terrible, in more ways than I can count. I'd rather sit and watch the grass grow. I could prolly write books about how bad this is, just like how I could write books on how good Pulp Fiction is. I honestly don't know where to begin: the beginning, the "music", the writing, the acting, the plot, the camera, the length, the fact that I had to stop watching numerous times to gather the strength to get through this Boo Fest, the "mystery of it all", the critics and Lynchians adoring it, etc...this is a never-ending list, so I'll just stop here for the sake of time. I will now try to tell you what's wrong with each of these, then I will try my hardest to forget this abysmal excuse for a film. In the beginning, there's random people dancing...why? I bet David Lynch doesn't even know. The so-called "music" is not music. It's a lame attempt at dark ambience that comes off as just tones and noise. If you want some good dark ambience, go listen to Reznor's The Social Network. It's my favorite album of 2010, and it also won best original score that year. The writing is rather weak and unthought-provoking (is that a word? Well, it is now), and I'd say about 90% of the acting is over done. I was ashamed to see Naomi Watts failing in this, she's usually pretty decent (if you wanna see her really owning her role, watch the American remake of Funny Games). The plot, err, this one is impossible to do briefly, so I'll combine it with "the mystery of it all" and the critics. What the hell was Lynch smoking when he thought up this doozy? It's the most convoluted, nonsensical, incoherent garbage I've ever sat through. The "most terrifying" scene is the only one that made me laugh (other than the bouts of bad acting), cuz it's so ridiculous and not terrifying at all. I think I understand why critics and flocks of people love this movie. It's cuz they don't get it. Since it's so mysterious, they just accept that as brilliance instead of what they should accept it as, idiotic. I was worried I would lose brain cells for viewing this film. For whatever reason, the camera almost never stays still, even during simple conversations. You may get dizzy, which is always a plus, right? And the extreme close-ups, uhm, pretty sure only Wayne's World is allowed to do that haha. The movie is nearly 2.5 hours, and I almost never say this, but it was way too long. If you're gonna make a movie long, make it worth it, make it count. Think I had to pause it 4 or 5 times just cuz it was making me so angry. When people call this a neo-noir psychological masterpiece, it makes me want to give up on two of my favorite genres in film. Nothing else to say except UGH.

It made sense to me at first, but Josh kept saying "Just Wait" and then at the end I was like.......uh....wtf?  But Josh explained it really well so I got it after that lol.  Overall I liked it well enough

Lynch creates a hypnotic and surreal universe that combines old Hollywood film noir and his own delirious narrative structure. The result is something unlike anything you have ever seen before. A powerful experience.
The sequel to Sunset Blvd.

Maybe the best film of the decade. It reminds me why I watch movies. It's bubbling over with suspsense, symbolism, visceral thrills and emotional resonance. It made me more conscious of what cinema should do and what it can be; It understands what the Hollywood dream really leads to and reveals hidden truths about the human psychological displacement of guilt. Fluttering back and forth seamlessly between whimsy and terror,with Mulholland Drive Lynch reaches the unspoken, inarticulated depths of pure consciousness and metaphysical awareness. It's a masterwork of Art. There, I said it.
Mulholland Drive may not be for everybody it may confuse some of it audience, but the think Mulholland drive does is to entertain.

Mulholland Drive is Lynch at his best. A singular and seminal acheivement which crosses the boundaries of film to become a vivid waking dream (or is it nightmare?). Either way, it's one of the greatest films ever made.
David Lynch's classic opus masterpiece...a must see and has many layers...read the review at www.themodernword.com/mulholland_drive.html and watch it again...and again...and again!!

Of course we scratch our heads in bafflement at what exactly Mulholland Drive all means, is it parodying the life of Marilyn Monroe or some other tragic actress? Is this a Mobius strip phantasm reflecting parallel dimensions, a rumination on fantasy and broken dreams?  And what of the highly unpredictable ending and how much does it represent the protagonist's upbringing or her taking part in a jitterbug contest (???!!). And yes, all these points are all very well, but ultimately despite my admiration that the film has motivated viewers imaginations I am still left with how it has made an impression on me. It's not like I'm a film goer who equates the necessity to 'enjoy' a film in the sense that it should be a fun ride like in a fairground, but I do have a fairly important stipulation that a piece of art should have power. And Ultimately I wasn't completely won over by Mulholland Drive, I felt emotionally disconnected from its fetishism of Hollywood and quite bored with the purposefully ambiguous dialogue/plot. That it should transcend such barriers of quality control just because it's considered great art seems a ludicrous approach to film criticism, and thus I can only conclude that I didn't get Mulholland drive, not for the purposes of it being a surreal, satirical or even its confusing narrative but simply because I thought while it was at times interesting film it was defiantly not the masterpiece I had been lead to believe.

What do you, as an audience member, go to the movies for?  That is the question you should be asking yourself before you sit down and watch Mulholland Dr.  A bright-eyed girl with aspirations of being a movie star (Naomi Watts) and a car accident victim afflicted with amnesia (Laura Harring) are on two paths that are about to cross in a twisty story about mystery, dreams and Hollywood.  Now I can totally see how people can get frustrated with this movie, as it isn't for those who are sticklers for the traditional narrative structure.  I can appreciate a film that doesn't give into formula and tries something challenging, and this being my second viewing of Mulholland Dr., I did get more out of it going in knowing where the line between fantasy and reality is drawn (it's the second appearance of the cowboy).  That said, I also do believe a film should be able to stand on its own, without you having to do legwork on your own time to deduce the story at hand.  David Lynch has this way of making you feel unnerved and unsettled, even if you don't have your head fully wrapped around just what is going on.  He makes avant-garde films that are otherworldly, this being a fine example of one, and while some may describe this as being self-indulgent and inaccessible, I didn't have that problem because I viewed the majority of this film as if it were dream vignettes.  This boasts some haunting and positively breathtaking cinematography and a wonderful score to complement your head-trip.  If you're looking to challenge yourself, or just looking for a divergence from the mainstream, this is the film for you.
A surreal nightmare--darkly realized and frequently disturbing.
Freaky, as Lynch always is.
Haunting and thrilling but leaves you empty in a way. However, I love movies that leave the viewer open to interpret.
I saw this film a long time ago.   I think it deserves a second viewing because I cannot remember much about it.  I will update my review at that time.
Now there's two and a half hours of my life I can never get back. :(
If I wanted to be confused I would take drugs, but it has very strong audio visual rhythm.(I don't know what that means)
this movie is too mind boggling for words. i think i figured it out, but there are so many takes on this movie it's hard to say who is right. not for people who don't like thinking

I can go on and on when it comes to David Lynch's Mulholland Dr., really! You have to watch it and get lost in the illusion...you will never trust your own senses again. Be warned: if you aren't a great analytical viewer/thinker, don't watch it. It operates heavily on the dream logic and requires puzzle solving on the audiences part.
found it irritating and obtuse although my partner liked it much better than I did

Disjointed and dull in long sections, Mulholland Drive is a failed pilot of a television show with an ending stapled on it to make it a feature with some good moments and atmosphere, but you can't help but think "What if?".
What the heck just happened?
Though confusing, Mulholland Dr. is masterfully acted, near perfectly directed and a surreal look at broken dreams.

I should have wrote the review of this right after I watched it, so that I could even begin to pretend that there was a real plot. However, a month later it all just seems like jumbled non-sense to me. The latter is probably the more likely anyway. Mulholland Drive wasn't total garbage like Inland Empire, but it was still mostly just random stuff with artsy excuses. I just can't bring myself to even waste my time on a good review for this guys films anymore.

Brilliant, and essentially the only Lynch film I can tolerate.  It makes sense if you concentrate, and the cast of characters runs the gamut from humorously odd to completely fucking twisted infini-weird.

Betty (Naomi Watts) is a chipper young woman who's house sitting at her aunt's place in Los Angeles as she auditions for movies, but her path to stardom is sidetracked when she crosses paths with a beautiful amnesiac (Laura Harring) who's on the run from mysterious forces. The whole thing soon splits into dark symbolism, conflicting alternate realities, and a barrage of seemingly-unrelated subplots that converge in unexpected ways. David Lynch writes and directs Mulholland Drive with his famous eye for experimental sound, cinematography, and story structure. It's an astonishingly adroit riff on film noir and magical realism, but emotionally complex performances from Naomi Watts and Laura Harring also make this film into a sensual and deeply moving experience as well.
This could be my favorite Lynch film.  It's the most enigmatic out of all of them, and still leaves you enough to try and figure out what's going on.

I admit, I shouldnâ(TM)t be a fan of David Lynch films, because of the fact he often makes them up as he goes along, making very vague connections in an otherwise overtly artistic style. However, I canâ(TM)t help but enjoy this film, despite these thoughts.

David Lynch is a solid director, in terms of shots and angels, the film is very well made, with some wonderful shots throughout the film. The build up of a scene in the diner where a man discusses his nightmare has some amazing build up in direction.

I am also wonderfully impressed by Naomi Wattsâ(TM) performance throughout the movie. In one half playing Betty, a star-shining actress full of hope and obvious delight, and in the other Diane, a weary, worn-down broken woman, she plays both perfectly, switching ably between the two with ease, which is very impressive. Her use of sexual tension in her audition was shocking and amazing, a magnificently played scene.

Despite the good performances and the good direction, the lack of coherent script leaves me not enjoying it completely. I still think itâ(TM)s a good film, I just have unfortunate issues with it.
love this movie its so different..the first time i saw it i wanted it to watch it again as son as it was over...and i did
Reconsider how good it is every time I watch it. Worth the time.
Now, I'm truly confused about which is his magnum opus : Mulholland Drive or Blue Velvet or the season one's finale of Twin Peaks. Goddamn you, Lynch.

I hate David Lynch, but I really like "Mulholland Dr." I think it's a good collaboration between the satire and mystery of "Blue Velvet" and the nonsensical visuals from "Inland Empire". I also like that "Mulholland Dr." isn't as straightforward as "Blue Velvet" but no where near incomprehensible as "Inland Empire". "Mulholland Dr." also features some nice visuals (something always present in Lynch's pictures), a story that keeps your attention (something rare for Lynch), and effective performances that are equally wacky and emotional (something Lynch never seems to nail down in one film, which I like here). Overall, it's clearly his best and most interesting work, and that is saying something, coming from me.

david lynch films are just weird for the sake of weird. i've seen "mulholland drive" twice now. i hated it the first time, but decided to see it again, in case i missed something that would make it as special as many people claim it to be. after the second viewing, i feel i understand the story completely, but there are so many holes and too many coincidences for me to be able to buy into it. the film even tries to trick you towards the end that it's actually going somewhere and trying to make a point, but then the ending happens and you realize it's not. it's not just the lack of a point that makes the film so hard to sit through. the dialogue is often redundant and corny as hell, and just about everything the characters do is unbelievably dumb. obviously i'm not a fan of lynch's, but every film of his that i've seen, i've watched with an open mind, but i find his work, particularly this film and "inland empire", to be nothing more than pretentious dribble.
A mind bending masterpiece by David Lynch.
It seems, I will need to watch this again and again to build up my own understanding of the story!
a little strange, but not bad
Puzzle, Puzzle and more puzzle and then there is Naomi ...best act ever produced !!
You'll will be talking to yourself after watching this..!
A dark, twisted tale that confounds its audience as to its meaning.

I'm not really sure what I think about it, and I guess that was the intent. David Lynch is such an enigmatic director with a non-conforming sensibility that seems to me to embody the Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle on film in that you change it by merely perceiving it.  It's super weird with an eerie atmosphere of paralyzing fear and underlying deception.  I liked it a lot and would place it among his top films like Blue Velvet and Eraserhead and Wild at Heart, all of which it shares the same sort of quirky, surreal, voyeuristic, boundary- breaking style which Lynch has been working on all of his career. I do think it's possible to interpret it as a linear plot, and I read that Lynch said as much was possible although he refuses to fill in the details much the same way that Kubrick was about his films, which he felt spoke for themselves.  Naomi Watts and Laura Harring are fantastic. It's on my to see again and again list...

This is the third David Lynch film I've seen and the third one that I absolutely loved. It was mind boggling but yet for a good part of the movie it had a stable story to follow. It was dark and creepy and though not a horror it sent chills through my spine. David Lynch also didn't let anything out. Two scenes of lesbian intercourse, a masturbation scene, and a very detailed corpse. Except for David Lynch to this day no one knows what this film was meant to symbolize, that is up to you

I'm not sure what adjectives to use? This isn't a narrative film and doesn't pretend to be.  It's beautifully shot with so many memorable dream-like images and I find the dialogue to be utterly engaging.  The sound-track, colour palette, and performances entwine to create something so rarely engaging.  David Lynch's 'hypnotic rhythm' makes me understand why film can be so profound.
This movie is messed up. Whoever made this film needs major help.

"Mulholland Drive makes little sense" is a very bad review and only says things about the reviewer. Calculus doesn't make sense to me, but how does it sound when I state, "Calculus doesn't make sense?"
one of the greatest movies ever

So, finally watched this one (only took me a decade+ to get around to it).  It has a long running time and is slow to start but it's worth sticking it out.  David lynch I can sort of take or leave (I think he tries too hard) - and this is classic Lynch - but I think it's one of his better works.  I came close to getting most of it, but not quite -- had to read the cheats on IMDb lol.  3 - 3 1/2 stars
Don't even ask what is really happening in this film.  What's real and what's a dream?  David Lynch doesn't answer the question, but he gives his audience plenty to consider.
I didn't understand the second half of this movie at all when I watched it, but some reading on the internet cleared it up. This really is a masterpiece, though.

Can't exactly describe what I just saw. Focusing primarily on the acting and camera work, it was excellent, but the storyline just had too many twists and turns for a normal person. After watching I did read how it all made sense which brought up my thoughts on it,  but I still wouldn't be able to describe what I just saw to others.
To me it's more like Mulholland DREAMS than Mulholland Drive (according to the title it's Dr. and the title itself is a clue from Sir David Lynch). Five stars!

one of the most difficult movies i've ever seen!

I'd like to clear something up: Mulholland Drive does make sense. It makes a lot of it. It might take multiple viewings to understand it, but honestly, it's pure laziness to write this movie off as being nonsensical. There are so many valid and intelligent interpretations available online, it isn't that hard to figure out what this movie means. It's a truly beautiful, frightening, and deeply meaningful film.
This is a movie to surrender yourself to. If you require logic, see something else. Mulholland Drive works directly on the emotions, like music.  Chicago Sun-Times Roger Ebert

This movie was a sensual, suspenseful experience with fascinating twists. I loved the relationship between the women, and the actresses were excellent in their roles. It is heavily laced with rich undertones of eroticism, without it overpowering the storyline.
David Lynch's masterpiece, frightening and funny, it's quite scary to look at Hollywood through the eyes of Lynch.
Surreal multi-layered beautiful and inherently strange masterpiece from a man definitely born in the Twilight Zone.
the best psychological thriller i've seen.

And to think that I once thought that Memento was confusing as all hell! I wish I would've been able to understand Mulholland Drive because I think I would've truly enjoyed it. But in any case, the movie was still quite fascinating.
Probably one of my all time favorite films.
Mulholland Drive is a very odd movie in the best way possible. It is truly unlike any other movie on the market. Watch It.
Brilliant until about forty mins from the end where it dives off the deep end into LynchLand. One of his better films.
Lynch needs to make more films like this.

Breathtaking masterpiece from the absolute master of surreal and abstract cinema. It doesn't always work - my main concerns are the moments where it's obvious that this was a T.V. Pilot to Feature-length movie conversion, hence most of the excellent peripheral characters only get about 4 minutes of screen time. Bogus television networks really dropped the ball here by denying Lynch what would certainly have been a worthy television follow-up to Twin Peaks.
It's a confusing, sometimes derivative mess of terror and dread, but its got the signature Lynch written all over it.

Beautiful surrealist film giving any viewer a chance to retain their own interpretation without compromising any of its splendor. Consistently shifting dream sequences, mesmerising camera work, solid acting and Billy Ray Cyrus getting punched in the face. Do you need more?

About as baffling as any film you will see the first time you watch it, but on an essential second and possibly third viewing, the puzzle will be solved (pending on which theory you go for) and after that, its all about enjoying the film which just gets better and better on each viewing. Funny, scary, erotic, surreal and intriguing are just a few words to describe not just Lynch's magnum opus but without doubt one of the best films in cinema, past, future, or present, featuring a lead performance from Naomi Watts which just might be one of the best, if not the best, performances by an actress ever. Masterpiece is an understatement.
It's too weird to take seriously. But for some reason, I kept watching.
Hollywood can be a bizarre & utterly frightening place. Mulholland Drive is a foggy, cryptic piece of Los Angeles neo-noir.
This and Blue Velvet are just fucking awful.
Maybe one of my favorite movies ever. I can say with confidence that it is about broken dreams, but my analysis ends there. Everything else is sheer cinematic dopamine.
David Lynch manages to make red curtains, senior citizens, and sun bleached Los Angeles unsettling and at times terrifying in this movie.

i dont care if this film was trying to create a dream like state. it started off as a mystery thriller so promising, that when the dream like sequences did kick in, we were too hooked to the first half of the film, that the second half just leaves us in disappointment.
Weird but ultimately uninteresting

What we have here is a director (David Lynch) who one day decided he wanted to make a movie about lesbians, but that was too simple for him. So he thought he might just put some insane story that makes little to no sense at all in the mix of this whole love affair between these two ladies.

There's so much ambiguity to this movie that it's painful that I will never be able to fully grasp what it means. It absolutely raped my brain with no mercy, but I liked it. It was sexy, clever, and thrilling and I definitely want to watch it again.

Mulholland Drive is, of course, an offence against narrative order, but it is also an intoxicating liberation of the senses, a breathtaking odyssey into the poisonous neon-drenched city of dreams and its dreamers. This openly dreamlike picture, evocative of the greatest elements of the film-noir tradition, is an unqualified masterpiece, and David Lynch's magnum opus. Pure cinema.
While it does make some sense, I don't quite get it all yet.  It is definitely worth another viewing just to see its whole brilliance.
The most mind bending film i've seen, if you thought Donny Darko was a mind fuck then get a load of this!! Great lesbian scenes most add!! lol What a film, gets the brain working on overdrive!!

My favorite movie of all time, up there with Hitchcock's Vertigo, is the most fascinating puzzle ever done on the screen. A movie that requires the audience to have fun deconstructing it and constructing it. The brilliant part is that nothing is gratitious. All the pieces are there. Everything has a logic after you see it three times. As hipnotic as Vertigo, it's also another tale of obsession gone bad. The use of music, colors and symbols throughout the film will spark discussions among film students for years to come. It's the most original piece of American film making in decades. And you'll be thinking about it for a long time. Silencio... Silencio... Silencio.
I've heard so much about it I had high expectations. I love Twin Peaks but am not familiar with other work from Lynch; I'm guessing it's not for everybody. It certainly is not for me.
This wasn't a bad movie, though I got a bit lost towards the end. Did they swap places or something?
Wow...this sucked more than anything has ever sucked before!  One has to wonder if even the director knew what the story was.
Intoxicating and extremely-visual, this is a knockout of a friday night in. Naomi Watts is exuberant.
A tale of Hollywood dreams turns into a nightmare of schizoid paranoia and murder. A lush and beautiful surreal portrait of haunted Hollywood.

A masterpiece. One of my favorite movies ever.
David Lynch writes and directs it perfectly.
Naomi Watts gives an amazing performance and handles all the roles superbly.
The story is complicated enough and needs a couple of views to become understandable, yet you can't possibly understand it all; it's that weird.
Very highly recommended.

Unlike films like "Lost Highway" or "Inland Empire", "Mulholland Drive" was Lynch truly in love with what he was doing, which makes this immensely atmospherical and illogical film even greater than just the idea of it. I am aware that there is "a key to unlocking Mulholland Drive", but I theres part of me that doesn't want me to ever figure it out. It isn't just the fact that this film is "disjointed", it's HOW it's disjointed that ranks it among not only the greatest films of the 2000's, but of all time. It isn't just HOW the pieces are placed, it's WHAT the pieces contain! Some of these scenes are just so fulfilling to the atmosphere. "Mulholland Drive" creates a whole spectrum of how to structure a film as much as "Wavelength" (1967) did. I can't quite but it into words, but this is probably the biggest game changer since "L'Atalante" (my favorite film) was restored in the 50's.

David Lynch in Mythic Los Angeles  

According to David Lynch, the ideas which became this movie were based on ideas he'd had for a theoretical third season of [i]Twin Peaks[/i].  Instead of Naomi Watts, we would have had Sherilyn Fenn.  He has not, so far as I know, said if dear Audrey's fate would have been the same as the eventual direction the movie took.  It strikes me as unlikely, given Audrey, but it does explain why a character in the movie is named Diane, I suppose.  It hurts me a little to think of Audrey going through the end of this movie, but hey, at least she'd be out of that exploding bank.  I have put up with a lot of lunacy from David Lynch over the years, though I couldn't quite get through [i]Lost Highway[/i]--maybe I'll try again someday--and I would have followed him through that plotline.  Heck, I'm one of those people who likes about half of [i]Fire Walk With Me[/i].  And I would have liked to have seen where the theoretical TV show this would have become would have gone.

Obviously, there's not much point in trying to explain the plot of this movie.  Because David Lynch.  Broadly, however, we are watching the stories of Betty (Watts) and Rita (Laura Harring).  One night, Rita is in a car being driven to a location on Mulholland Drive.  The driver of the car stops it and is going to shoot her, but a drag-racing car smashes into it.  Everyone else is killed, and Rita--not her real name--stumbles away.  She has amnesia.  She ends up sneaking into the apartment of Betty's Aunt Ruth (Maya Bond), who is off on a trip to Canada.  Betty discovers Rita in her shower.  Betty herself is in town to audition for a movie.  She, like so many others, has dreams of being an actress.  However, she takes in Rita, and that's where everything starts to go wrong.  It's Lynchian going wrong, so it's hard to explain, but across town, there is a director (Justin Theroux) who may tie into this.  He is told by mysterious men that if he doesn't cast a certain girl in his film, he will suffer for it.

Even the bright, sunny bits with Betty seem like a dream.  Oh, a daydream, to be sure.  Just what every girl from small-town Ontario dreams moving to Los Angeles will be like.  When she goes to her audition, everyone is completely welcoming.  There are people there who have no reason to be other than to see her, personally.  But when Rita enters the dream, it is darker.  Richer.  Erotic in that peculiar way of film noir, where you can't trust the woman but you don't care.  And because Rita cannot remember her past, she brings no baggage to the relationship.  She is all Betty's, whatever that entails.  It just happens that it currently pleases Betty to play Girl Detective.  There are things it is better not to know, but Betty is an innocent, and life hasn't taught her that particular lesson yet.  Of course, even without Rita, it's not likely that Betty would have stayed an innocent long in Hollywood.

There were other interweaving bits to the plot, but to explain them would require understanding them, and I'm not at all sure I did.  There's the mysterious cowboy (Monty Montgomery).  The gangsters (Dan Hedaya and Angelo Badalamenti).  Dan (Patrick Fischler) and Herb (Michael Cooke).  I'm not sure David Lynch really needs a reason to include details like that, but let's say that it's to make the whole thing more dreamlike.  David Lynch's work has always struck me as looking into the ground between dream and reality, and this movie is no exception.  I don't think you're supposed to know what's real and what isn't.  I don't think Lynch is necessarily sure himself.  I think he's fond of "well, that seemed like a neat idea at the time," and I don't have much problem with that.  I have no problem with exploring the characters' psychology as part of getting to know the world they live in.  I think that's true more often than not even in the real world, much less in fiction.

Of especial interest to many of my friends is that the movie does have genuine lesbian eroticism.  Even bisexuality.  And it isn't played for shock value, I don't think, the way Laura Palmer's adventures were.  It just seems like two women clinging to one another for comfort in a strange and confusing world, and I think that's half of what most love is in the first place.  Of course, it turns out to be more complicated than that, but it's David Lynch.  No relationship in all of his work is exactly what it appears on the surface.  And that's also perfectly acceptable to me.  The relationship we see is only half the story in any situation.  Every pairing has secrets.  In this movie, the important thing to remember is that secrets can be dangerous to learn and dangerous to keep.  There are accusations of plagiarism floating around on this one, and I'd certainly say that some of Lynch's influences are more obvious than others.  I haven't seen [i]Persona[/i], so I can't say how much he borrowed from that.  But for all it's a relationship between two women, it's a relationship straight out of noir.

I disagree with some of the reviews that say that Mulholland Drive doesn't make sense; it is very surreal for much of the movie, but by the time the movie ends all of the pieces come together and it forms a single thought-provoking narrative of jealousy, identity, fantasy, and love. In my opinion, Mulholland Drive actually makes a great deal more sense than most other films by David Lynch, whose movies are often very abstract and unique. Like most David Lynch films, Mulholland Drive is very difficult to summarize in one brief statement, but if I had to simplify it, I would say it tells the story of an amnesiac woman who meets an aspiring actress named Betty and forms a close bond with her as they both try to discover the woman's identity. That barely scratches the surface of the plot, and the movie is far less straightforward in telling its story than that summary would have you believe. The movie is very much deserving of more than one viewing to fully understand and catch all of the subtle details contained within, and trust me, there are a great number of extremely subtle details. The movie is at times mesmerizing in its strangeness, but it is always thoroughly interesting, even in the most unusual of scenes, such as a scene at a diner early in the movie that should make you feel at least a little creeped out. This really is a deeply original and incredibly intelligent mystery/drama/thriller from the always wonderful David Lynch, and has to be seen to truly be believed. Mulholland Drive is an incredible, haunting film to watch and one that should remain in your memory for a great while as one of the best movies of the 2000s.

David Lynch really likes to fuck with your mind. Like really get in your head and start pushing buttons. He has done it before in his movies (Lost Highway), but Mulholland Dr. Delivers a really twisty story line that, admittedly, will leave you confused, but entertained with some superb acting, especially by Naomi Watts and Justin Theroux. Mulholland Dr. looks at two lives that clash together. One, a lady on the run in a car crash scared out of her mind looking to hide (Laura Harring). The other is a sweet lady from Deep River, Ontario who is trying to make it big in Hollywood (Naomi Watts). When their lives collide, the audience is taken into a twisted mystery that leads you through the Hollywood and the world of cinema. However, near the end, we get a Lost Highway/mobius-strip type twist which changes these two characters almost completely. At the end you are left wondering what was real and what was illusion. When David Lynch is on, he is absolutely on. He commands some great performances out his actors and actresses in this movie. Naomi Watts is absolutely stellar. It is completely amazing how she turns from a sweet, naive girl from Deep River, Ontario into an obsessed, mildly depraved woman who is love with Laura Harringâ(TM)s character. Laura Harring was great as the mysterious woman who falls into Naomi Watts. Justin Theroux is also hilarious and great in his role as a conflicted director. Lynch also directs some wonderful, surrealistic sequences. The most beautiful of all of them, though, is the pantomime theatre. The illusion of the singing is absolutely breathtaking and gorgeous. It is a real thing to behold and a work of pure art. Mulholland Dr. is another wonderful addition to the David Lynch collection. It has some great acting performances and some of the beautiful scenes any David Lynch film. Non-Lynch fans will be mildly satisfied with the ending but will love the performances. Lynch fans will absolutely love this film.
A little hard to follow, but a very good story if you give it some effort...and maybe a second viewing. If you like weird, unpredictable mysteries you will like it.

Mulholland Dr. is a wild ride and it's best to experience it without knowing anything the first time you see it. The plot is non-linear and the ending isn't typical Hollywood fare. Most of my friends hated it and thought it was a waste of their time. But for those who like it, the experience is up there with the best that film has to offer. If you are analytical and curious enough to watch the film two or three times in quick succession, you're the type of person who may end up loving this film. If you haven't seen it and think you fit that description, I hope you will give it a try.

Mulholland Dr. is my favorite film of all time. The prospect of seeing the Blu-ray both excited and scared me as I wondered whether the presentation would be worthy of the film.

It elevated it to a different level.

The story is full of mystery and unfolds like a detective story for the first two-thirds of the film. Betty (Naomi Watts), an aspiring actress, wins a jitterbug contest and uses it as an opportunity to fly to Los Angeles to seek out an acting career. Immediately after, we see a car crash in which Rita (Laura Harring) suffers amnesia and seeks refuge in Betty's empty home. The two soon meet and Betty tries to help Rita remember who she is.

The film was intended to be a television series and the first two acts were formed by the aborted pilot. Eventually, new funding allowed Lynch to finish the film and it evolved into an entirely different story. The plot isn't linear, and the distinction between dream and reality becomes increasingly blurred.

This is a complex puzzle that is very hard to take in on the first viewing and is therefore not for everyone. If you like fast-paced action and straightforward stories wrapped up neatly by the end of the movie, you probably won't appreciate the film. If you enjoy mysteries and being confused and unsettled, it may interest you.

It changed the way I watch movies.

This is the kind of film that possesses you. The best way to view it is to let it carry you along and wash over you. Save your analysis for repeat viewings. And if you have an inquisitive mind, there will be many repeat viewings.

I first saw this film without understanding all of it, but I found myself going over it in my mind and watching it again the next day. Then I wanted to tell all my friends about it. Over time, it has surpassed everything I have ever seen. It's full of intrigue and makes me feel so many different emotions. It's quite brilliant and Lynch's best work, although all of his projects are valuable and important.

Watching one of Lynch's films takes you on a journey into a different world. There's something not quite right with the world, but it's hard to identify exactly what it is. But it adds to the feeling of unease. In Mulholland Dr., he uses interesting camera angles to show you a glimpse of what is ahead. As a result, you become part of the story and see it unfold as the main characters do.

There's a lot going on in this strange world. We are shown several different characters, initially unconnected, with no explanation of their overall role in the story. This probably happened because the threads were meant to be expanded on in the television series. You will meet film directors, detectives, a hit man, and a whole host of minor characters.

The film is punctuated by moments of bizarre humor. Some of the comedic scenes make me laugh out loud, and that's not an easy thing to achieve. There are also moments of violence and mystery and ultimately true desolation.

The final act turns everything on its head. Betty and Rita become Diane and Camilla. It's initially confusing, but everything becomes clear when you think about what you have seen and felt. 

It's full of symbols and metaphors and has an underlying theme which examines the Hollywood industry as a whole.

Lynch creates a mood better than any director I have ever seen. The colors, settings and actions of the characters all enhance the atmospheric presentation, and Angelo Badalamenti's haunting score completes the experience. Mulholland Dr. has many of the elements that made Twin Peaks my favorite television show of all time. If you like one, you will almost certainly like the other.

I'm not going to expand any further on the plot, such as it is, because it may put you off seeing the film. It's complex, but it's very rewarding when you examine the experience after the fact. It's the kind of film that encourages people to develop their own theories. Lynch refuses to explain it, preferring that you develop your own idea about what it represents.

The film can be viewed as a series of interesting scenes. In fact, that's probably a good way to view it for the first time. The final act isn't a predictable occurrence. If you're someone that finds that refreshing, like me, then you should check out Mulholland Dr. if you haven't already done so. Several film magazines voted it the best film of the last decade. It's certainly something that can be appreciated even if you have other favorites.

Watching Mulholland Drive is like trying to complete a jigsaw puzzle with pieces missing. David Lynch's intentionally confusing thriller will split audiences into three general groups: those who leave entertained, those who leave frustrated, and those who leave not having a clue what they hell they just spent the past 180 minutes watching. To its credit the film is wildly intriguing, directed with great care by Lynch, and presented with gloss and style. Naomi Watts provides a stellar performance, and while the film itself may make little sense, there's something undeniably entertaining about this tale which is as twisting as its Californian namesake.

It's director David Lynch at his finest.
