I want to add my two cents about what is currently my big obsession: Mulholland Drive. Bought the dvd maybe a year ago, but only got round to watching it a few days ago. Kinda enthralled. Did some reading. Checked out a few theories. Got a few of my own. I admit that I have changed my ideas, and credit for extricating me from a blind alley or two goes to some of those whose blogs/reviews I've read, whose names evade me, I'm afraid. That said, I'm genuinely shocked that a lot that strikes me as bleedingly obvious (albeit not until I'd watched the dvd half a dozen times or more) hasn't entered the general consciousness of the critical community. So, I'm gonna share my words of wisdom with the rest of you.

Let me start by saying that prior to Diane Selwyn waking up, everything was a dream, leaving aside the jitterbugging and head moving towards pillow. The dream is indeed Diane's. It is impossible to make sense of the dream until after seeing the rest of the film. I am going to play around with this blog entry. I intend to edit it, add to it, rather than do the right thing, which is craft a final draft then release it into the wild. Don't have the patience for that. Y'all can see it emerge piecemeal from this thing I call a brain.

Where should I start? Suppose I tell y'all that the lesbian scene whose tenderness impresses so many of the film's fans is in actual fact a masturbation scene taking place in the head of a schizophrenic killer having a wet dream? In other words, both Betty and Rita are fragments of Diane's shattered consciousness. The Queen has left the building, as Mr Roque more or less pointed out when initiating his telephone chain call. "The girl is still missing" refers to Diane, who has surrendered her consciousness. Mr Roque represents an aspect of Diane's psyche, as do all the employees at the film studio, including director, Adam Kesher.

In the dream, Adam Kesher fulfills two functions. Most obviously, we witness Diane's attempt to rationalise how her dreams of becoming a movie star and great actress came to nothing. It was not that the director of "The Silvia North Story" did not want her for the part, did not recognise her extraordinary talent. She was frustrated because she was collateral damage in a war between the director and his employers on the one hand and a set of gangsters on the other. Ray, his manager (Robert Smith) and the other executive at the meeting with the Castigliani Brothers represent those diplomats who negotiate between the creative aspect of our personalities (represented by the director) and hard, objective realities. The top of the food chain of the latter is represented by The Cowboy. While you can attempt to tell the Castigliani Brothers to piss off, to shatter the windscreen of their limosene with a golf club, to resign to make a point, you don't turn down The Cowboy. Not if you know what's good for you. When he laid down the law, the light went out for Adam. As he surrendered with the words "This is the girl", his eyes met Betty's. This was love at first sight. Had Adam not been given an offer he couldn't refuse, and had Betty not cut short her embarrasing, inevitable rejection by going ahead with the ambition, she'd have no excuse for why her ambitions were thwarted. But Diane's subconsciousness has fashioned her alibi. And she feels better for this. From this point on, Betty and Rita are no longer interrupted from their mission of uncovering Rita's identity. They become convinced that she can't be Diane, as her neighbour didn't recognise her. However, the conversation the neighbour has is not one she had with either Rita or Betty. Rather this was one she had with those other two doing detective work, the two she refers to after Diane wakes up.

When they enter Diane's apartment, the stench of death is overpowering. And the corpse causes Rita to despair. She might not know what she has to do with it, yet. But she knows enough to run screaming into the fresh air, having let her inquisitive neighbour depart the scene. Rita and Betty know enough now to realise that Rita needs a new identity, and dying her hair the same colour as Betty's seems not a bad idea. They are now a partnership against the world with a secret. They are comfortable. They are in bed. They are one. This sex scene. I'm afraid this is a masturbation scene. Not so tender when seen that way. For Betty and Rita are both fragments of Diane's shattered personality. When Mr Roque says "The girl is still missing" the girl that everyone is searching for is the one who does not answer the phone. It is Diane. When Mr Roque with the words "then" and "and" informs an underling (I think it is Ray) that the studio was to shut everything down, what was being refered to was the suicide of Diane. The script of the scene that is faxed to Betty, that is the audition between her and her father's best friend, when it is rehersed by Betty and Rita is in actual fact words handed down to them from another part of the subconsciousness. This was an investigation of the pros and cons of suicide.

When Diane masturbated while crying, this was an expression of her having lost the ability to love herself. When Rita and Betty make love, that represents the moment when Diane's subconsciousness has reconciled herself, at least momentarily, with what she has become. But in her dream state, her anxiety ebbs and flows. At 2:00am, part of Diane's shattered ego calls out "silencio". She wants to die. She persuades the more innocent version of herself (the old, now renamed copy of an earlier version of Diane's operating system to be booted up when Diane's goes AWOL) to attend Club Silencio. That is where the alternative to living is explained. The beautiful singer can die but her song goes on. Death is not the end, if the memories linger, which they will do so long as they are sweet ones. On that realisation, Betty and Rita are in possession of the box to which they have the key. Things take a new turn...

From entering Club Silencio, they have not spoken a word and are destined never to do so again. From being reduced to tears and startled by the appearance of the box, they appear to be joined at the hip, their movements chorgraphed, marching in step. When they enter Betty's apartment, they act as if one individual with one mind. And when Rita retrieves the hatbox with her purse and the key... Betty has gone. She's fulfilled her role, which was to take Diane's shattered mind on a journey of recovery. Diane had been shattered and put back together so many times. This was the final time. Not having Betty to hold her hand as she opened the box, she does so anyway. The box open and the darkness at it's heart engulfs the world. Then it falls to the floor. There's nothing to hold it up, since this key has opened up the world to the illusory nature of Rita as much as of Betty. The falling of the box to the floor is heard by the woman who vacated the appartment before Rita squatted there, Betty's aunt. But that woman sees no box, nor anything else. The appartment is now deserted by the pair of squatters, who were ghosts, two fragments of Diane's disordered mind. And something else. That Cowboy. The one who made Adam an offer he couldn't refuse. Well, he's back. This symbol of harsh reality is here to inform the pretty girl that it's time to wake up. The pretty girl in question being the one who was still missing, according to Mr Roque. And what was the hard reality that woke her up? Nothing psychic or symbolic. It was the knocking of the door by her neighbour.

We learn that the two detectives called to see Diane again. Clearly they've called before. And, as we know from the stench of death Betty and Rita smelt, she's not going to escape the law forever. In her dream, she taught herself just how incompetent her hired hitman is. Whether or not this depiction is accurate, these are her anxieties. And they're not going away any time soon. And there's not a lot of time left. Having gotten rid of her neighbour, the next few hours are left with her brooding and day dreaming and hallucinating. The flashbacks allow us to decode those symbols from her dream we have not been able to so far. Names and faces were collected by Diane's subconsciousness to weave a tapestry to explain what her options are. She can be immortal by living fondly in the memories of... Who? Actually, she's all alone. But what about Irene and her companion? The pair who travelled to Los Angeles with her from Ontario. Actually, they came from further back than that. These are in fact her parents. They reenter his life because, being so small, they can crawl under the door. But when those knocking detectives enter and smell that stench of death, her parents will no longer be her best friends. She will have lost everything. She takes the cowards way out, actually the only rational alternative for her. She blows her brains out. And as the curtain falls for the last time, and silencio... We see her as happy as we saw her with her parents before the opening credits. But who is the other woman? Is that her lover? Is it Camilla? In my opinion, probably not. I do not believe that Diane loved Camilla any more than she was loved by her. There's was a sick relationship from start to finish.

When Rita tells Diane "I don't know who I am", they open her purse and find inside this symbol of female genetalia $125,000 on top of a blue key, a phallic symbol. Blue being symbolic of sex work. In my opinion, Diane was never more than a sex slave for Camilla, to be abused and humiliated. Possibly slave is not the right word. After all, Diane was selling her body. What price did she ask? She lived vicariously Camilla's film stardom. Camilla stole from her her dream. Not being able to live the life herself, she settled for attaching herself to the one who got it, and who got in undeservedly, according to her subconsciousness. We know from the story she told Camilla's soon-to-be mother in law (Coco), that Diane's never gotten over this. What is more, we learn why Camilla "This is the girl" Rhodes has a different face in her dream. Not satisfied with publicly humiliating Diane with her heterosexual lover (Adam), Camilla goes to great trouble to teach Diane that her role of lesbian lover has been usurped by another. "This is the girl" and it ain't you, sunshine.

As her replacement as lesbian sex slave moves out of the picture, in walks The Cowboy. One of the Castigliani brothers is seen staring menacingly at her. Both are merely memorable images her subconsciousness will use as raw material in her dream. The waitress's nametag "Betty" is something else that will come in useful, as will the blue key. Why did the hitman think is so funny to be asked "What does it open?" There's no definitive answer from the material. However, it's plausible to explain this away in his head as hilarity at her failure to appreciate that the sole purpose of this blue key is to act as a message, to let her know that the job's complete. But that's not how she interprets it. For her, as for the director (for Lynch), there's a symbolic meaning. It represents a nightmare. And Lynch takes us on a short detour which her subconsciousness is already fashioning for her. The alternative to the beautiful immortality of the dead singer is the living hell of the monster living alone and scaring normal people to death. That's her life if she doesn't take it. The face of the man at the counter is simply one more part the raw material from which her hyper-sensitive subconsciousness is preparing her dream. In the dream he says he's had this dream not once but twice before. Maybe the film is of a dream that Diane's had more than once. Possibly not. Anyway, this is most of what I've worked out over the last few days. Anyone care to pull these theories to shreds? I'd appreciate serious comments.

Mulholland Drive is David Lynch's greatest masterpiece and a fantastic visual film that taunts the audience with secrets and hints towards the films true story.  I was really intrigued when seeing this film and its like one big game of Clue, where we must use our hints to find out the true secret.  The cast was incredible, Naomi Watts steals her scenes and this was the movie that actually got her to the big time.  Laura Harring really haunted me with her performance and it really goes to show what a unknown female actress can do.  Justin Theroux was also fantastic and played his part very well.  But its the characters in Lynch's script that are the true genius.  We must piece up the secrets in this film to understand the characters and what is going on in the film, and anyone that understood this film fro the get-go is a better man than I. There's no doubt that a Lynchian film is an acquired taste, and even then it's still hard to understand exactly what it is that he's trying to say. He is a hustler. He lures us into a false sense of security with innocent characters and a cheerful atmosphere, but then turns his back on us when the mood changes. Don't bother asking questions; you'll get no answers. Lynch never feels the need to bother us with an explanation. He makes it our job to determine what happened, and that task borders on the impossible. The "twist" ending that Lynch supplies us with is a hasty and hackneyed maneuver -- a final and desperate attempt to tie everything together. The result is a chaotic and disorganized mess that many people mistake for "brilliance", which it is not. There is no logic at all involved. Lynch has one goal and one goal only, and that goal is to confuse us. Not even he understands what he is doing.
Some crazy shit here. Just whack.

Ever had one of those strange nightmares and hallucinations when suffering from malaria? I have. It's quite a trip. Much like this movie... You'll struggle to make sense of anything that goes on for about 2 hours. But as you approach the end, you'll begin to figure it out. And once you realize what's just happened... well... I'm afraid what's been seen CANNOT be unseen... This was too uncomfortable for me.

Mulholland Drive is mesmerizing, a real tour de force of a film. Though one could spend a lifetime trying to make sense of it all, I think the great Roger Ebert had it right when compared the film to a dream. The whole thing isn't a story, it's an experience. Lynch plays with his audience here, creeps us out, turns us on, draws us into a mystery that cannot be solved. As with many movies, my first viewing turned out to be unsatisfactory. Not because the film was bad, only because I kept waiting for an explanation to the whole thing. Now, going back, like to a dream once had, I was able to absorb the film like a sponge. One scene that stands out in particular is the diner scene. Never before have I ever been so scared of an image on a screen. The Exorcist is a terrifying film, but I've watched it a hundred times, and the visceral power it held over me is long gone. When I saw the figure emerge from behind the diner however, I felt my heart sink within my chest. There is little sound in the shot, no screams or clangs or clashes, no violins, only a soft organic whooshing, like the flesh of a corpse, reanimating. I've watched this diner scene as many, if not more, times than I've seen The Exorcist, and it gets to me every time. If I digress, it is only to show how well Lynch directs here. Returning to the main focus, Mulholland Drive is a great film, and anyone with an open mind hoping for a truly unique and satisfying movie-going experience will find it here.

I never, ever thought I would say this, but I watched this notoriously incomprehensible film again 10 years after the first time I saw it, and by God, it actually makes sense! And not just in some vague thematic way; when you see it the second time, you realize there's actually a perfectly sensible plot explanation for almost everything that happens in the movie. I don't want to explain it lest I spoil the movie for those who haven't seen it (or have only seen it once), but suffice to say my mind was blown by how much more sense it made this time.

The movie opens in a rather Twin-Peaks-y way with a chipper young actress named Betty (Naomi Watts) landing in Los Angeles for the first time to stay at her absent aunt's apartment. She meets a woman who is suffering from amnesia after a car accident, and together they try to solve the mystery of who she is. There's also a hip young movie director played by Justin Theroux who plays a key part. And that's all I have to say about the plot.

Naomi Watts gives an extraordinary performance (or group of performances, actually - you'll see) as Betty.  The role requires her to play in a lot of different registers, not just emotionally, but as if she were on different levels of reality at different points in the movie, and she pulls it off beautifully. Again, you might not pick up on how good her performance is until a second viewing. Laura Harring is also really excellent as the amnesiac woman. Theroux's part is a little bit dryer, but he's funny and likable in his own way here. 

I have to give full credit to David Lynch for making this movie as incredible as it is. You can put this alongside Blue Velvet and Twin Peaks as his absolute best work, and all three are really fantastic. There are still Lynch movies I don't like, but when he's really at the top of his game, he's a truly amazing filmmaker. It does take a second viewing to appreciate all the little clues and layers of reality Lynch is putting in front of you; you'll more than likely miss most of it the first time. But even if you don't like the movie the first time you see it, wait a while, then go back to it, and you'll be amazed by it. Obviously there are certain things in the plot that can't be literal (Club Silencio, for example), but just about everything here can in fact be explained either in terms of plot or of the characters' psychology. I feel like I've reached some new plane of mental capacity today. I feel like the guy seeing Jupiter in 2001: A Space Odyssey when he says, "My God, it's full of stars!", except I'm saying, "My God, Mulholland Drive really does work!"
An incoherent yet intoxicating exploitation of the mentally unstable wonderland known as Hollywood, and what it can do the human psyche.

Quite possibly the greatest film of the century so far, this absorbing masterpiece from David Lynch is just sheer perfection. Every single aspect of it is absolute genius. It is better to walk into this film with no knowledge of it beforehand, but in short it is a tale of love, hate, corruption and downright mystery portrayed grittily in the harsh reality of Hollywood. Lynch's direction and script are as always, fantastically surreal and thrilling, the performances from the whole cast, particularly Watts and Harring are played astonishingly well, not to mention the soundtrack, which goes perfectly hand-in-hand with the atmosphere of the film itself. I cannot fault it, and if you fancy yourself a film fan, this is a compulsory experience to watch.

Sure to confound the average or even seasoned movie goer, I'll admit to needing a little time to make heads or tails of things.  And to get it out of the way, I'll agree and say yes there is a coherent story here, but there are more stories that lack any coherency, but that also makes sense.  Off the bat this is a David Lynch film, which means you are in for a visual and narrative trip that you won't find anywhere else.  It weaves in and out of vignettes at a calculative pace, yet at first glance will seem haphazard, and even annoying at times.  But it comes to a conclusion no one will see coming and will stick with them for a while afterword.  Naomi Watts is incredible here, just knocks it out of the park.  The rest of the cast does great work too, but Watts' really stands out.  Hard to recommend to anyone but the true films buffs out there, or anyone wanting some really really different.

So this was what was going through my head while watching this:

"Hmm, pretty random start; maybe its significance will become clear later on in the film. Hot girl. Ooo. Did Naomi Watts really look like that 10 years ago? That dude looks creepy. WHY IS EVERYTHING SO MYSTERIOUS?!! The music is always so eerie, the suspense is too much to handle; there better not be anything popping out on screen or I'm gonna get a heart attack. Billy Ray Cyrus is in this? Who is this cowboy? This guy is speaking in such profound sentences, what does it mean? Everything is so mysterious, what is this leading to?!! [Then] Whoa, Whoa, oh. WHOA, WHAT?! Holy cr-what the h-isn't she her and isn't she h-what on earth?! I bet everything is going to come together in the end... [Silencio.]"

Everything was so mysterious. There is obviously lots going on in the last bit. I had no idea what happened (though there was no trouble following the first two thirds of the film), and still had no idea after watching it. Only after reading some articles did the general gist of it seem clear. Note that this film is open-ended and is up for lots of interpretations. And there are probably lots of cryptic messages and symbolism in this too. I honestly can't be bothered going too deeply into it. (I've only spent two or three hours trying to find answers.)

David Lynch really likes to fuck with your mind. Like really get in your head and start pushing buttons. He has done it before in his movies (Lost Highway), but Mulholland Dr. Delivers a really twisty story line that, admittedly, will leave you confused, but entertained with some superb acting, especially by Naomi Watts and Justin Theroux. 

Mulholland Dr. looks at two lives that clash together. One, a lady on the run in a car crash scared out of her mind looking to hide (Laura Harring). The other is a sweet lady from Deep River, Ontario who is trying to make it big in Hollywood (Naomi Watts). When their lives collide, the audience is taken into a twisted mystery that leads you through the Hollywood and the world of cinema. However, near the end, we get a Lost Highway/mobius-strip type twist which changes these two characters almost completely. At the end you are left wondering what was real and what was illusion.

When David Lynch is on, he is absolutely on. He commands some great performances out his actors and actresses in this movie. Naomi Watts is absolutely stellar. It is completely amazing how she turns from a sweet, naive girl from Deep River, Ontario into an obsessed, mildly depraved woman who is love with Laura Harringâ(TM)s character. Laura Harring was great as the mysterious woman who falls into Naomi Watts. Justin Theroux is also hilarious and great in his role as a conflicted director. 

Lynch also directs some wonderful, surrealistic sequences. The most beautiful of all of them, though, is the pantomime theatre. The illusion of the singing is absolutely breathtaking and gorgeous. It is a real thing to behold and a work of pure art.

Mulholland Dr. is another wonderful addition to the David Lynch collection. It has some great acting performances and some of the beautiful scenes any David Lynch film. Non-Lynch fans will be mildly satisfied with ending but will love the performances. Lynch fans will absolutely love this film.

"Everything you see here tonight is an illusion."

On the surface- a beautiful small town girl with hopes to be an actress moves to LA and starts living her dream. Her apartment hides a mysterious amnesiac woman who had survived a car accident. The young girl decides to help the woman since she has no where else to go. Soon they begin a budding romance. But all is not what appears to be as reality slowly warps into a fantasy world of love and illusion. 
Without the right openness of mind, this film will keep you lost. easily. It mixes a surreal dose of horror, suspense, confusion, raw sexuality, and the disoreintation of fantasy and reality. Is this really happening or is it a dream? That's the question you have to figure out yourself when having the pleasure of viewing this. The plot seems to have open-interpretations as even the smallest of scenes hold the powers to scare, amaze, and arouse. I must say this film is a work of art that challenges both the mind and emotion. 
Come see the movie. Ponder deep the secrets held in Hollywood Hills' very own Mulholland Dr.

This is definitely a film that you have to watch intensely and not do anything else whilst it's on.

 A psychological thriller that's more intriguing than scary. The film highlights the very dysfunctional realities of the characters in an extremely surreal way.

Multiple (seemingly unconnected) snippets of story lines run at once and lots of cryptical narrative (and imagery) runs throughout the film. Don't try to understand each storyline though, just let it flow over you.

The characters are strong (there are multiple) and at times it is hard to decide which are the "lead" characters, all with sinister undertones.

The end is
a) definitely not what you expect (although if you look back, the signs are there)
b) not a final ending. You could see this taking off in a different direction at a later stage.

The film deals with the darker side of lovers' jealousies, sexuality and insecurities. It also highlights the dual personalities/alternative realities that we all have inside us, the exterior view that we portray to the world and the lives we have at times wished for on the inside.

To start with, I thought the film would be sinister with some morbidity. However, it was fascinating, at times disturbingly unravelling, not a bit morbid, but very odd (in an enjoyable way!). The abstract way the actual filming was done added to the sense of the film not making sense v not needing to make sense (as it was unravelling as it should be). The close up views of eyes were wonderful and added to the delving intrigue.

The music played throughout was hauntingly beautiful and also very dark in places.  The spanish version of Roy Orbison's  "Crying" was stunning. http://youtu.be/cAbmfVzPHFg

It is a very dark, odd film, but enjoyable in a strange mixed up kind of way!

Will definitely watch this again!

Plot about a girl suffering of amnesia hiding in another girl's appartment trying to find out what happened. Both become (very) close friends.
The story development is very confusing, scenes change without apparent logic and some happen without having a clear explanation.
I know that David Lynch is a very acclaimed director, but I find this movie not to be one of his piece of arts.

Mulholland Drive is incredible. I'm very partial to Eraserhead and Blue Velvet, but this just might be Lynch's best. Dream sequences are very often portrayed on film, but they never really feel like dreams. Inception is a good example. It portrays the most concrete way of thinking about dreams, without actually creating the right atmosphere. It feels real, then crazy shit happens, you realize you're dreaming, that's it. I've never had a lucid dream, so I can't honestly say that it wouldn't be like how it's shown in Inception, but I'm pretty sure it wouldn't feel like an action movie. Mulholland Drive, on the other hand, creates the feel of dreaming so brilliantly that even thinking about it now feels like thinking about a dream. I've had dreams (more specifically nightmares) that exist in the same terrifying environment as Mulholland Drive. There's a scene where two people are talking in a restaurant about dreams and they go outside and this face pops out. That's one of the most startling and scary things I've ever seen. I freeze framed the face that pops out. It's really not that scary, it's not like the girl from the Exorcist, but it felt so real that I had to pause the movie and walk around for half an hour in a state of dread. It felt like a nightmare. It's weird, and thinking back on it, it shouldn't have been as scary as it was, but that's why it's so brilliant. One of my scariest dreams literally looked like a shitty Atari game. There were two dimensional zombies in it. It was the context, the fact that at the time it felt real, that made it so scary. Just for that scene alone, the movie should be given some sort of honor or award, but as it goes on it gets even better. Mulholland Drive makes a fantastic parallel between the version of the word "dream" that means the thoughts and whatnot that go on when you sleep and the version of the word used to describe ambitions or passions or goals. It's terrifying, clever, brilliant, extremely well acted (Naomi Watts is amazing), and an all around amazing movie that should be considered revolutionary in the way it creates the atmosphere of dreams on film.
I don't mind sleuthing through a cryptic movie but this one just didn't make sense. And not in the good "this didn't make sense" kinda way.
Seriously mind-bending.

Where to start. A very, very, very complex film that doesn't seem to make any sense. You may discard it straight away, but after watching this fine piece of cinema I feel that a darker and sinister meaning lies underneath the surreal facade. Hard to believe, I know. Yet this is Mulholland Drive's greatest strength, the power to mesmerize the audience without providing an illusionary story line to fall for. To question every motive, every detail of not just the movie but identity itself.

David Lynch challenges viewer's expectations of narrative and credibility by luxuriating in something else.
It's amazing how much sense it doesn't make, and how interesting that makes the film to watch .
Irrefutably a work of art, this is definitely not a film for the casual viewer, but the seasoned cinema goer will likely find a lot to love in this left-wing masterpiece.

Is fascinating when a movie gives you more questions than answers, and Mulholland Drive is a dream that begins very coherent and traps  the spectator into a nightmare with constant challenges. Is plagued of David Lynch singular directional touch and a vibrant performance by Naomi Watts. Confusing, weird, smartly enlaced, truly not easy to follow, is like a labyrinth, when you think that something is the exit you gets to a more difficult road. Open to hundreds of theories (and maybe thats the whole point), with a undisputed allegory to Hollywood dreams and the consequential madness, is so brilliant and maniacal that is no less than a masterpiece.
Mulholland Drive is your typical Lynch film: a puzzle. But this one has Watts at her very best. In the end of the film you won't know what hit you; and you'll like it.

Mulholland Drive is an absolute masterpiece from surreal director David Lynch, but it is not for everybody I guess. Some people are going to be irritated at the strangeness of this film, but others like me enjoy that strangeness and it serves to draw us into the mystery.

There is fantastic use of music throughout the film - extremely confusing, notably accompanied by groups of people outside the cinema scratching their heads and discussing the plot furiously. Basic summary (I think!): The film is a comment on Hollywood; good is turned to bad, light to dark, helpless to manipulative, and innocent to evil because of the corruption surrounding the industry, and the depseration and insecurity brought in by "wannabe" film-stars. The film actually starts in the middle of the story, the story ends in the middle of the film, then the end of the film goes right back to the start of the story, get that?!? Story appears to be: nice innocent girl becomes lesbian after meeting amnesia-suffering vulnerable woman, but this turns out to be a concussion fuelled dream by the amnesiac who is the reason the nice-girl slides down into a moral oblivion becoming a hit-man ordering protitute after she has lost numerous parts in films to said amnesiac (who also used to be her girlfriend), thus shattering original plot and making for some excellent contrasts at the end of the film. Plenty of Lynch-ness thrown in throughout to confuse - similarities so close within each sub-plot they seem to make it one story, but it isn't - e.g. in the dream the girls visit no. 12 and are re-directed to no. 17, then a similar situation in the real-life ending where the new occupant of no. 12 tells the occupant of no.17 she has had visitors, there are completely different visits but viewers automatically link the two, thus confusing even further the chronology of the film etc. etc! Great - a must see, at least three times to get to grips with it!!!

"Mulholland Drive" features great performances from both female actors, especially Watts and I can't understand why she wasn't nominated for Academy Award!

Oh and Attention BOYS!!! Film contains lesbian sex scenes... you're still here?! Go watch it :)
This is a strange and twisted movie.  Not easy to follow so don't bother trying to figure it all out but if you stick with it, it will stay in your head for a while.  Naomi Watts is great in this.

Ok, first off, I want to qualify my opinion as just that an opinion. I also want to admit I love artsy symbolic films. I went to art school and have traveled the world to see innovative works. This movie although I believe is closer to what happens when an "artist" is given too much respect and freedom in his creation. There are so many portions that seem unrelated to the story and way too many areas that feel like a Director just enjoying his power over young actresses. I see glimpses of creative genius buried in a mire of Hollywood crap. The first half of the film kept reminding me of bad Scinemax movies. If it is supposed to be poor Diane's fantasy this woman is seriously lacking in realistic situations or characters. It was borderline campy and ridiculous. Unless she was on drugs or skitzo the glue that holds a movie together or even a whacky dreamscape was completely missing. 

Compare it to the escapism fantasy situations in Pink Floyd the Wall movie. At least here... even with limited insight a viewer can understand it is an ongoing psycho-suffering of a young man in pain from his rock star lifestyle, drug use and cheating wife. 

In Mullholland drive you are never aloud to KNOW what the situation really is. I call this situation "The King has no clothes."
Just because a respected director known for symbolism and confusing plots, turns out a "movie" that was pieced together from something meant for a TV series, doesn't make it good or art.

I did enjoy moments. What can I say, I am a man. and the touching sex scenes did come off slightly believable for brief seconds. Nami's performance with this mess deserves some prase. But as story telling goes this guy needs to take a lesson from Spielberg, Hitchcock and Shakespeare.

At first this is hard to grasp. It soon becomes apparent this film is a dream/fantasy, weird convoluted script underneath which lies the real message. Its really the story of a girl who comes to Hollywood who dreams of making it big. A sexually confused episode within some pseudo dreamworld is intertwined with real world jealousy towards a succesfull actress. It's difficult to see where reality starts and where the dream ends which makes this really interesting to watch. The idea that making it big in hollywood is determined by connections rather than talent and the portrait of failed actresses working as waitresses across Hollywood's cafes, may ring true. Hard to say but that appears to be the tenet of the film. The opera singing scene emphasises the sad misfortune of Naomi Watts dilema. Also, great lesbian scenes, Naomi Watts is hot and talented. David Lynch's Mulholland Drive is a dream broken down into a motion picture. A film made out of a series of occurences and pictures that might or might not seem to have any purpose or meaning.

Lynch does not intend to tell a story, nor to entertain or terrify (even though he would be capable of doing all these things at the same time, i believe). He wants you to fill in the blanks and make it complete for yourself. Whether the film has a meaning or otherwise, you make that meaning yourself. That is the magic of Lynch!

A stunning film, and a true mind bender. Unfortunately, unlike films like "Memento", this one is much harder to figure out what actually happened. FULL REVIEW!
A host of bizarre and shady characters get up to weird and sinister goings-on in and around Hollywood in this frustratingly confusing thriller straight from the twisted imagination of director David Lynch. 

I must admit that I'm not overly familiar with Lynch's work to date. I've only really ever seen part of his bizarre cult TV show "Twin Peaks". I sadly didn't get all the way through it though; I was put off by its meandering plot and random characters. It was with some apprehension then that I came to watch Mulholland Drive, often quoted as being Lynch's best work for 15 years by top critics. I was expecting it to be very similar to Twin Peaks; full of weird and wonderful personalities with apparently no need to be in the story at all and a plot that was both random and confusing. My assumptions were right in many respects, although what I didn't expect was how much I actually enjoyed it. The film format works a lot better for Lynch then his creation been broken up into episodes, although even though it's only two and a half hours long I was thrown out at the end of the film frustrated and bewildered as to what it all meant. 

I tend not to describe the plot of films in my reviews (you can get a plot from anywhere), but with Mulholland Drive this would have been impossible. In what I'm guessing is Lynch's typical style the story is convoluted, twisting and contradictory. There's characters that don't appear to have any role at all (like the midget in the dark room, the crazy fortune teller lady and the burnt vagrant), and many of the characters change personalities and indeed roles half way through the film. The plot is so weird that I was left feeling annoyed and like I'd wasted my time after the film ended. I argued with my wife afterwards for an hour and a half about what had just happened and it resulted in neither of us being able to conclude or explain what we had just seen. I prefer to wait until all the clues have been given and then to have that eureka moment when it all comes together. But I found Mulholland Drive to be ever changing, and every time you think you've worked out what is going on the film changes the rules and you are left with gaping holes in your original theory. The copy of the DVD we watched also had a sheet containing "Lynch's 10 clues to unlocking this thriller", and I have to admit that watching the film with this list in hand made absolutely no difference when trying to penetrate the warping plot. 

From what I can understand after two views and researching the film on the internet I'm not the only one who doesn't really get it. At first I thought that the two main female characters were one and the same person, like two seperate aspects of a personality; one light and one dark. As the film progressed the two halves came closer to being the same (symbolised I felt by Rita even changing her hair and appearence to be more like Betty's), until the visit to the mysterious Club Silencio where the two personalities are changed forever and the lighter side is utterly destroyed with the discovery of that ominous Blue Box. I later changed my mind to the idea that the film was split into two halves; one half been "real" whilst the other half actually being a wishful dream of one of the characters (seperated once again by the visit to Club Silencio). However, I also suspect that Lynch made this film to be almost like a dream within a dream and the more I try to cement one of my ideas the more bits come off and spoil my theory. Either half of the film could be the dream half (although I suspect the later half is the reality myself), although knowing what I do of Lynch this could be the other way around or maybe even both halves are dreams, maybe dreams of the same person, maybe of two different people! It's clear from reading others' insane ramblings over this film that nobody really knows the truth, and I suspect Lynch is probably very proud of this fact. 

Regardless of the endless theories spun by people trying to understand the film it definately holds a terrible power over you. It's dreamlike and nightmarish all at the same time. I'm sure there is some symbolism of good and evil as well as some symbolic references to the shadows and hopes of human nature. Maybe I'm just reading too much into it (maybe not)!? Its impenetrable plot is very well shot, acted and directed. There is a classy feel throughout despite some harrowing scenes and a steamy lesbian sex-session (which Lynch may have added after seeing a very similar sex scene in rip-off porn flick "Twin Peeks"). The acting is incredibly well performed and the cast was evidently picked with care and attention. 

My only major complaint as stated already is the frustratingly confusing story, which may spoil if for many other viewers too (my wife being one of them). I can see the good film that this is, it's just hidden under the mental weight of it's own weirdness. 

THE VERDICT? 
Mulholland Drive is one of those films where the level of your own understanding will determine how much you get out of watching it. It's bizarre and perplexing, but also classy and well made. I guess watching it is the only way to find out for sure if you will like it or not!

all movies alot of people like because of there endings. but this movie makes them all seem kinder gardenesque. the best thing and most intriguing thing about Mulholland Drive is how unexplained and creepy it really is. everything seems so out of place awkward and earie. the movie continues to tease you with very suddle clue to figure it out. yet to make it even more mind bending you dont even know what 'it' is. this is what kept me interested in this movie because it continues to give you samples of what your looking for yet doesent exactly give you the full answer which began to frustrate me. never has a movie ever made me say 'what the fuck' so many times. but as with each passing scene and each passing moment the movie becomes alittle more fulfilling as it goes along. yet at a pace i didnt like, it seemed to be alittle to slow for me which in a odd way made me respect the movie all that much more. but i wont lie when the movie ended i still didnt fully grasp it. and id find it hard to beleive if anybody really did. so i suggest you go online as i did, and look up 'Mulholland Drive ending' theres a great site that breaks down the entire movie to the very last bit, so much detail you couldnt even imagine. the biggest clue i could give a way is the two hour mark.

Forget the hot lesbians. Forget the plot that has about the same consistency as a bowl of spaghetti. And just remember that movie is meant to be unconventional, non-sensical and a cinematic thrill-ride.

What is going on with the blue box? What is going on with the waiter at the restaurant? Who is the creepy vagrant and the mysterious cowboy? Most importantly, just what the hell is going on?!

A good movie is oftened defined by if it's re-watchable, as in, "It's a movie you can watch over and over." Well, Mulholland Dr. isn't a movie you'd like watch over and over, it's a movie you'd need to watch over and over. Mulholland Dr. rewards you for watching it repeatedly, as more clues to it's convoluted plot becomes more apparent. Once you watch Mulholland Dr. it will root itself into your mind as you embark on your own detective case, trying to make sense of it all.

But perhaps the plot is too misshapen and warped, and perhaps its all a little too... weird. Even for David Lynch. I sometimes get the feeling that I will never find out the truth about this movie, and it saddens me a little. 

At least Laura Elena Harring is in it.

Resisting all forms of synopsis and analysis in characteristically Lynchian fashion, Mulholland Dr. is cultish, it's cool, and I love every single second of it. Using a morally murky LA as his muse, Lynch paints a surreal, non-linear, WTF-filled foray into a tangled world of loser hit men, gangsters with questionable motivations, closeted lesbians and an in-over-his-head director. Feel lost yet? You don't know the half of it. Viewed by many as a satire on the shallowness and corruption of Hollywood, and there may be truth to that, but then again, it's Lynch, so the definitions never stick. The key to enjoying it is to not try to figure it out. Because you can't. The movie itself even takes about 20 to expain the twist. Just watch, enjoy the mind-bending surrealism and the fact things don't make sense. Naomi Watts and Laura Harring get it on, too

Still completely impossible to work out, this is a slightly easier film to watch than some other Lynchian releases through the years. Thrilling, surreal, strange and intriguing, it's not one for a rainy Sunday afternoon, but, if you manage to struggle through it, you'll want to watch it again. And again.
Now here's a movie that can literally blow the mind of. God Bless Lynch for this movie. Someone who consider himself intelligent should watch this.

David Lynch brings all his tell tale film making to life in "Muholland Drive," a look into film making, neurosis, and the powers that be. Have to watch in more than once to get an understanding of what is going on, and then you will still be left with questions. Chimerical, intriguing, confusion with questions still being asked. Take a drive and don't ask too many questions.

If you know David Lynch, you know that he enjoys darkness, surrealism, and submissive lesbians.  Well this movie is fllled to the brim with those things.  So if you enjoy all that, and if you don't mind that your movie doesn't make any sense whatsoever, you'll enjoy "Mulholland Drive," David Lynch's best film outside of perhaps "Elephant Man" (although I admit, I have not yet seen "Eraserhead," which some say is his best).  

When you pop this film into the DVD player, you have to prepare.  If you've seen any Lynch movie you know what I'm talking about, but it's is especially true for this one.

Step 1: Relax.  If you're irritated by something, wait until you're in a good mood.  If you're in a hurry, push "Mulholland" off until tomorrow.  The very, very slow pace requires that you're comfortable and patient and ready for anything.

Step 2: Open your mind.  You're not going to enjoy "Mulholland" if you just finished enjoying a sip of tea while watching "The English Patient."  In other words, lose the stuffiness, and get ready to suspend your disbelief in a big, fat way.  

Step 3: Kick everyone else out of the house.  That's right.  "Mulholland Drive" is best watched alone.  This is because when you watch films with other people, especially controversial and unusual ones like this bad boy, there's a natural tendency to subconsciously criticize or doubt your own judgements.  So lose the buddy/girlfriend/boyfriend/parent and butter some popcorn on a lonely night.  Trust me, it works better this way.

Now you're prepared.  So, what's the big deal? you ask.  I've seen lots of bizarre movies, I'm ready for anything! you say.  Well, take it from me.  As someone who has spent, shall we say, an unusually large portion of my young life and young income on watching films, and has probably seen hundreds more movies than the next guy, "Mulholland Drive" is a unique experience that requires a certain mindset.  And although some have said it benefits from a 2nd viewing, after seeing it for a 2nd time myself, I'm not sure this is true.

Why the extra precautions?  First off, there's not really a plot in Mulholland Drive.  Sometimes the film will suddenly switch gears to a strange place we've never seen before, mostly because it's a cool-looking place.  Characters will say things in conversation that don't add up.  A couple of characters here and there drop dead suddenly for little reason.  In the last portion of the film, there's a role reversal; suddenly one character becomes the other, without explanation.  Also, the entire world, or at least Los Angeles, seems to be controlled by a sick little man sitting in a chair about twenty feet from a microphone.  Oh, and don't forget the probably pointless lesbian sex, the cowboy who speaks like he's the grim reaper, and the (spoiler!) monster who may or may not live behind a diner's trash bin.  

Yep, that about sums up "Mulholland Drive."  Any questions?

To be honest, I enjoyed this movie the first time because I took the above precautions and of course, it surprised and haunted me, for which I gave it props.  The individual scenes are undoubtedly fresh and intriguing, which is what makes it great.  Its inventiveness alone is enough reason to appreciate it.  Most people either love or hate "Mulholland Drive," and I used to be one of the former.  But after watching it again, I realized that it might be a little pretentious and tiresome, so for now I'm taking more of a middle-road.  

Go see "Mulholland" because you have to.  It's already an icon in film history.  To boot, David Lynch was nominated for best director for this film, which I believe was justified simply because of its newness.  If you look very closely, the film might be cohesive on a wafer-thin level, something to do with dreamscapes and alternate realities and... stuff.  But critics worldwide agree: "Mulholland Drive" doesn't make any damn sense.  You don't watch it to see how it ends.  You watch it for the strange, jarring journey.

I've seen this film so many times it feels like a familiar piece of music to me even after a hiatus of several years.  I watched it again last night and enjoyed it as much, if not more, than I did initially.  Which was very much.  The film essentially works as a piece of music does, in a visceral and direct way, not according to the logic and rules of a screenwriting workshop or film school class.  The film cannot be appreciated easily by trying to force it into that box.  It never intends to explain itself or have an ulterior motive, I feel.  To focus on unexplained and unexplainable events and moments and to feel them without thinking is the best approach to appreciating this film.  There is no story in the conventional sense.  This feels refreshing to me because almost every story these days in a movie is ultimately boring.  I feel like I've seen every story before and I don't care about any director or writers special message, and don't need meaning and profundity shoved down my throat anymore.  I've seen too many movies and I just want an experience to hit me on a gut level.  That's the only unique and challenging thing these days.  This film, to me, gives the audience enough credit to allow them, by suggesting but not dictating, allusions to and suggestions of possible stories not carried out, that then become the seed of dreams, each one unique, in the mind of each viewer afterwards.  Unlike most "mystery" films, the "mystery" actually deepens, rather than cheapens, with subsequent viewings.  Everyone knows that the mystery is the interesting part, not the solution.  By creating a beautiful mystery and choosing to stay right at the razor's edge of curiosity and unknowing, Lynch creates a timeless thing that means something different to everyone.  Each person imagines different things because so much room is left by lack of explaining, both while watching and after viewing this movie, which makes it like an infinite number of movies in one, if a movie is the person's experience of it and not what's tangibly on screen for the duration.  A great and important film, much like almost anything Lynch has ever done.

I am still more than confused. SUCH a strange ending, I challenge you to see this without actually saying WTF by the end. But still a very enjoyable film to watch, but man does David Lynch have a screwed up mind.
Lynch's best film, simultaneously his most surreal and accessible mind-warper.

Mulholland Drive is a surreal nightmare.  The film is simultaneously beautiful, terrifying, convoluted, and unique.

For the majority of the narrative, the viewer has absolutely no idea what is going on.  That's the beauty of it.  Anything could be in store in the next scene - new characters get introduced with little or no explanation and increasingly strange happenings unfold.

The camerawork in Mulholland Drive proves to be almost as interesting as the occurrences in the film.  Rather than maintaining a static camera, Lynch often allows the camera to subtly "drift" up and down while characters are interacting (perhaps most notably during the first Winkie's Diner scene preceding a rather horrifying encounter).  The narrative is anything but ordinary, and so, too, is the camerawork.  

As the title suggests, most of the subsequent action in the film stems from an encounter at "Mulholland Drive."  However, the pivotal moment for the viewer comes at Club Silencio when we learn that "No hay banda! There is no band. It is all an illusion!"  Everything preceding this moment begins to unravel, and the viewer is left to pick up the narrative pieces.  Lynch doubles back on the majority of the film and adds new meaning to the strangeness and creepiness that the viewer has gone through.

Mulholland Drive is a demanding, intricately crafted film that exposes the dirty underbelly behind the Hollywood glitz and glamour.

Is it just me but - this movie had a good premise, but was simply a disjointed peice of crap? I liked the idea that the director 'glamourised' the actors during the dream sequence, and to show the link with hollywood glamour - and the confusion was well constructed, the 'evil' cavemen quite horrific - but it all just seems like a big muddle - justified by the premise - but can one simply say that a movie is good when 'I can justify why it's crap?' That's not art... It's just pure crap. It seems to me the director went on a tangent, with some themes he could tie in to the end by simply tacking on the "IT WAS ALL A DREAM" to escape the pure, disturbing convolution.

I'm not going to lie that when I first saw this, as the credits rolled, I had no idea what the hell I had just seen. It took a few hours of research and a re-watch for the power of this film to sink in. I fell in love with this movie as a result. It explores hope, dreams, the Hollywood culture, sexuality, and failure in ways that are both compelling and joyful to watch. Very little is ham-handed, and as far as mind-bending thrillers go, this surpasses even Donnie Darko as a top-tier film.

Rating: Full Price

I... I have no fucking clue what happened in this movie. I think it's about losing yourself in Hollywood but even that doesn't seem accurate, I'd recommend it just for the experience of "WTF did I just watch?". The worst part is I thought this movie made sense until the last half hour where everything got turned on it's head.

EDIT: I'll bump this review up, for whatever logic it doesn't offer, it does offer a nightmare , and it is worth a look to anyone who has the patience for it to slowly develop into a nightmare that sticks with you long afterwards.
Love it or Hate it,you simply can't ignore it !

Incredibly bizarre and confusing but still addictive, as most Lynch productions.

"What are you doing? We don't stop here."
Shady men in suits, bizarre Hollywood producers, a guy with a head too small for his body, cowboys, and...Billy Ray Cyrus. This is an excellent physiological thriller.
Plot: This being a David Lynch(Dune, Eraserhead, The Elephant Man, Lost Highway) film, the plot is extremely weird and complex, so I'll try to explain in the best way I can without giving anything away: A woman suffering from amnesia due to a mysterious car accident on the famed Mulholland Dr. meets another woman named Betty, who's aunt is famous actress who is letting her stay in her home while she's doing a movie. Now the two must uncover who the woman really is. There is much more to the plot, but I feel if say anymore I may ruin it.
As with all of Lynch's films, this is a piece of weird art but I didn't find it as confusing as Eraserhead. I've heard that a lot of people didn't get this movie and had to look on the internet for the explanation, but about twenty minutes before it was over the answer hit me like a brick and everything started to make sense after that. To be honest I really expected it to be much more complex, but the answer is right in front of you the entire time, you just have to look. The entire movie has a weird dream like atmosphere to it and just like Lynch's other films, all of the characters have something odd about them. I was surprised to see Naomi Watts in this. She plays someone who is completely different from the characters she normally plays and as usual she does fantastic. It was also pretty funny to see Billy Ray Cyrus in this. If you are a fan of Lynch, you should have already seen this and if you aren't afraid to let your mind go, this is excellent. Total Score: 8.3/10
Confusing but hey, its a Lynch film I personally loved it. It was scary it gave me a very creepy feel. It was suspenseful too, and I liked the mystery.

This film is an amazing dream-like experience. It's bold, innovative, and completely entertaining from beginning to end. I still think Naomi Watts deserved an Oscar for her amazing performance. Brilliant film through and through. One of my all-time favorites! I found a great analysis of Mulholland Dr. for those wanting to dig deeper into its symbolism and structure: http://entertainmentguidefilmtv.blogspot.com/2011/03/mulholland-dr-2001.html
Best movie i've ever seen! Really intense. It left me overwhelmed.

The film may be confusing and hard to interpret. But I find the film to be like a challenging and exciting jigsaw puzzle. It is difficult to say anything regarding the plot without giving much away. But I can say that the film had great performances from the cast especially Naomi Watts. Also, there is plenty of breathtaking visuals and concepts. What I love about the film is that is challenges the audience to really think hard and piece together all of the story elements to solve the mystery. David Lynch once again puts together a riveting, complex, and dark motion picture that is both exquisite and mind-boggling. With that said, I think that Mulholland Drive is one of, if not, the best of 2001.
